title: OUGS: Active View Selection via Object-aware Uncertainty Estimation in 3DGS
comment: 11 pages (10 main + 1 appendix), 7 figures, 3 tables. Preprint, under review for Eurographics 2026
summary: Recent advances in 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) have achieved state-of-the-art results for novel view synthesis. However, efficiently capturing high-fidelity reconstructions of specific objects within complex scenes remains a significant challenge. A key limitation of existing active reconstruction methods is their reliance on scene-level uncertainty metrics, which are often biased by irrelevant background clutter and lead to inefficient view selection for object-centric tasks. We present OUGS, a novel framework that addresses this challenge with a more principled, physically-grounded uncertainty formulation for 3DGS. Our core innovation is to derive uncertainty directly from the explicit physical parameters of the 3D Gaussian primitives (e.g., position, scale, rotation). By propagating the covariance of these parameters through the rendering Jacobian, we establish a highly interpretable uncertainty model. This foundation allows us to then seamlessly integrate semantic segmentation masks to produce a targeted, object-aware uncertainty score that effectively disentangles the object from its environment. This allows for a more effective active view selection strategy that prioritizes views critical to improving object fidelity. Experimental evaluations on public datasets demonstrate that our approach significantly improves the efficiency of the 3DGS reconstruction process and achieves higher quality for targeted objects compared to existing state-of-the-art methods, while also serving as a robust uncertainty estimator for the global scene.

AI.tldr: Introduces OUGS, an object-aware uncertainty framework for 3D Gaussian Splatting that derives uncertainty from primitive parameters, propagates it through the rendering Jacobian, and integrates segmentation masks to guide active view selection for targeted object reconstruction.
AI.motivation: 3DGS-based reconstructions of specific objects in cluttered scenes are hampered by scene-level uncertainty biased by background clutter; there is a need for a physically-grounded, object-centric uncertainty measure to improve view selection.
AI.method: 1) Derive uncertainty from explicit 3D Gaussian primitive parameters (position, scale, rotation) and propagate their covariance through the rendering Jacobian to obtain an interpretable uncertainty model. 2) Integrate semantic segmentation masks to produce an object-aware uncertainty score that disentangles the object from the environment. 3) Use this score to guide an active view selection strategy focused on improving object fidelity.
AI.result: Experiments on public datasets show that OUGS improves the efficiency of 3DGS reconstruction for targeted objects, achieving higher object fidelity compared to state-of-the-art methods, while also providing a robust uncertainty estimator for the global scene.
AI.conclusion: OUGS offers a principled, interpretable, and effective object-centric uncertainty formulation for 3D Gaussian Splatting that enhances active view planning and object fidelity without sacrificing global scene uncertainty estimation.

title: Case Study: Transformer-Based Solution for the Automatic Digitization of Gas Plants
summary: The energy transition is a key theme of the last decades to determine a future of eco-sustainability, and an area of such importance cannot disregard digitization, innovation and the new technological tools available. This is the context in which the Generative Artificial Intelligence models described in this paper are positioned, developed by Engineering Ingegneria Informatica SpA in order to automate the plant structures acquisition of SNAM energy infrastructure, a leading gas transportation company in Italy and Europe. The digitization of a gas plant consists in registering all its relevant information through the interpretation of the related documentation. The aim of this work is therefore to design an effective solution based on Artificial Intelligence techniques to automate the extraction of the information necessary for the digitization of a plant, in order to streamline the daily work of MGM users. The solution received the P&ID of the plant as input, each one in pdf format, and uses OCR, Vision LLM, Object Detection, Relational Reasoning and optimization algorithms to return an output consisting of two sets of information: a structured overview of the relevant design data and the hierarchical framework of the plant. To achieve convincing results, we extend a state-of-the-art model for Scene Graph Generation introducing a brand new Transformer architecture with the aim of deepening the analysis of the complex relations between the plant's components. The synergistic use of the listed AI-based technologies allowed to overcome many obstacles arising from the high variety of data, due to the lack of standardization. An accuracy of 91\% has been achieved in the extraction of textual information relating to design data. Regarding the plants topology, 93\% of components are correctly identified and the hierarchical structure is extracted with an accuracy around 80\%.

AI.tldr: An AI-driven pipeline converts P&ID PDFs into a structured plant design data view and a hierarchical plant model, achieving high accuracy in textual data extraction (91%), component identification (93%), and hierarchical structure extraction (~80%), by combining OCR, Vision LLMs, object detection, relational reasoning, and a transformer-based Scene Graph extension to handle heterogeneous data.
AI.motivation: To accelerate and accurate digitization of gas plant information amid energy transition pressures, reducing manual data extraction and enabling better asset management, despite lack of standardized documentation.
AI.method: Input is P&ID PDFs. The system uses OCR, Vision-Language Models, Object Detection, Relational Reasoning, and optimization algorithms. It introduces a new Transformer-based extension to a Scene Graph Generator to analyze complex relations among plant components, producing two outputs: a structured design data overview and the plant's hierarchical framework.
AI.result: Textual design data extraction accuracy of 91%; 93% of components correctly identified; hierarchical structure extracted with ~80% accuracy.
AI.conclusion: The work demonstrates a viable, AI-driven digitization solution that mitigates data heterogeneity and supports daily workflows for plant information management, with strong quantitative performance on design data and topology extraction.

title: Practical and Performant Enhancements for Maximization of Algebraic Connectivity
summary: Long-term state estimation over graphs remains challenging as current graph estimation methods scale poorly on large, long-term graphs. To address this, our work advances a current state-of-the-art graph sparsification algorithm, maximizing algebraic connectivity (MAC). MAC is a sparsification method that preserves estimation performance by maximizing the algebraic connectivity, a spectral graph property that is directly connected to the estimation error. Unfortunately, MAC remains computationally prohibitive for online use and requires users to manually pre-specify a connectivity-preserving edge set. Our contributions close these gaps along three complementary fronts: we develop a specialized solver for algebraic connectivity that yields an average 2x runtime speedup; we investigate advanced step size strategies for MAC's optimization procedure to enhance both convergence speed and solution quality; and we propose automatic schemes that guarantee graph connectivity without requiring manual specification of edges. Together, these contributions make MAC more scalable, reliable, and suitable for real-time estimation applications.

AI.tldr: MAC graph sparsification is made online-ready: faster solver, better step sizes, and automatic connectivity guarantees, enabling scalable, real-time long-term state estimation on graphs.
AI.motivation: Long-term state estimation over graphs scales poorly with current sparsification methods; MAC preserves estimation performance via algebraic connectivity but is too slow and requires manual edge selection.
AI.method: 1) develop a specialized solver for algebraic connectivity; 2) explore advanced step size strategies for MAC optimization; 3) create automatic schemes that guarantee connectivity without manual edge specification.
AI.result: Average 2x runtime speedup for MAC; improved convergence speed and solution quality; automatic connectivity guarantees; enhanced scalability, reliability, and suitability for real-time estimation.
AI.conclusion: These contributions render MAC more scalable and practical for real-time long-term graph-based state estimation.

title: A Lightweight CNN-Attention-BiLSTM Architecture for Multi-Class Arrhythmia Classification on Standard and Wearable ECGs
summary: Early and accurate detection of cardiac arrhythmias is vital for timely diagnosis and intervention. We propose a lightweight deep learning model combining 1D Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), attention mechanisms, and Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM) for classifying arrhythmias from both 12-lead and single-lead ECGs. Evaluated on the CPSC 2018 dataset, the model addresses class imbalance using a class-weighted loss and demonstrates superior accuracy and F1- scores over baseline models. With only 0.945 million parameters, our model is well-suited for real-time deployment in wearable health monitoring systems.

AI.tldr: A lightweight 1D CNN–attention–BiLSTM model classifies arrhythmias from 12-lead and single-lead ECG with high accuracy on CPSC 2018, using class-weighted loss and 0.945M parameters.
AI.motivation: Early, accurate arrhythmia detection is crucial for timely intervention; current models may be too heavy for wearable devices and struggle with class imbalance; a compact model enabling real-time deployment is desirable.
AI.method: Proposed architecture combines 1D CNN for local feature extraction, an attention mechanism to weight important segments, and BiLSTM to model temporal dependencies; applied to both 12-lead and single-lead ECGs; trained with class-weighted loss to mitigate class imbalance; evaluated on CPSC 2018 dataset.
AI.result: Outperforms baseline models in accuracy and F1-score; uses only 0.945 million parameters, suitable for real-time wearable deployment.
AI.conclusion: A compact, effective model for ECG arrhythmia classification is feasible, enabling accurate, real-time monitoring on wearables; potential for broader deployment with similar architectures.

title: Bridging Natural Language and ASP: A Hybrid Approach Using LLMs and AMR Parsing
summary: Answer Set Programming (ASP) is a declarative programming paradigm based on logic programming and non-monotonic reasoning. It is a tremendously powerful tool for describing and solving combinatorial problems. Like any other language, ASP requires users to learn how it works and the syntax involved. It is becoming increasingly required for those unfamiliar with programming languages to interact with code. This paper proposes a novel method of translating unconstrained English into ASP programs for logic puzzles using an LLM and Abstract Meaning Representation (AMR) graphs. Everything from ASP rules, facts, and constraints is generated to fully represent and solve the desired problem. Example logic puzzles are used to demonstrate the capabilities of the system. While most current methods rely entirely on an LLM, our system minimizes the role of the LLM only to complete straightforward tasks. The LLM is used to simplify natural language sentences, identify keywords, and generate simple facts. The AMR graphs are then parsed from simplified language and used to generate ASP constraints systematically. The system successfully creates an entire ASP program that solves a combinatorial logic problem. This approach is a significant first step in creating a lighter-weight, explainable system that converts natural language to solve complex logic problems.

AI.tldr: Translates unconstrained English into ASP for logic puzzles by combining an LLM with Abstract Meaning Representation (AMR) graphs, using the LLM only for simplification and keyword/fact generation while AMR-derived structures generate full ASP rules, facts, and constraints.
AI.motivation: ASP is powerful but has a steep learning curve; translating natural language into ASP can enable non-programmers to specify and solve combinatorial problems like logic puzzles, with an emphasis on explainability and reduced reliance on heavy LLM generation.
AI.method: The pipeline uses an LLM to simplify natural language, identify keywords, and generate simple facts. Simplified sentences are converted to Abstract Meaning Representation (AMR) graphs, which are parsed to extract semantic constraints. These constraints are systematically translated into ASP rules, facts, and constraints, resulting in a complete ASP program that can solve the problem without needing further human input beyond the initial NL description.
AI.result: The system successfully generates an entire ASP program (rules, facts, constraints) that solves a combinatorial logic puzzle, demonstrating feasibility of converting natural language to executable ASP with a lighter use of LLMs.
AI.conclusion: This work marks a significant initial step toward a lighter-weight, more explainable NL-to-ASP translation pipeline for complex logic problems, reducing reliance on large language models while maintaining correctness through structured semantic parsing.

title: Assessing Identity Leakage in Talking Face Generation: Metrics and Evaluation Framework
summary: Inpainting-based talking face generation aims to preserve video details such as pose, lighting, and gestures while modifying only lip motion, often using an identity reference image to maintain speaker consistency. However, this mechanism can introduce lip leaking, where generated lips are influenced by the reference image rather than solely by the driving audio. Such leakage is difficult to detect with standard metrics and conventional test setup. To address this, we propose a systematic evaluation methodology to analyze and quantify lip leakage. Our framework employs three complementary test setups: silent-input generation, mismatched audio-video pairing, and matched audio-video synthesis. We also introduce derived metrics including lip-sync discrepancy and silent-audio-based lip-sync scores. In addition, we study how different identity reference selections affect leakage, providing insights into reference design. The proposed methodology is model-agnostic and establishes a more reliable benchmark for future research in talking face generation.

AI.tldr: A model-agnostic framework to quantify lip leakage in inpainting-based talking-face generation, using three test setups (silent-input, mismatched audio-video, matched audio-video) and new metrics (lip-sync discrepancy, silent-audio-based lip-sync scores) to analyze how identity reference choices affect leakage and to establish a reliable benchmark.
AI.motivation: Lip leakage, where lips in generated footage are influenced by reference images rather than driving audio, undermines realism and is hard to detect with standard metrics; a robust, model-agnostic evaluation framework is needed to quantify leakage and guide better reference-design strategies.
AI.method: Propose a systematic evaluation with three complementary test setups: silent-input generation, mismatched audio-video pairing, and matched audio-video synthesis. Introduce derived metrics such as lip-sync discrepancy and silent-audio-based lip-sync scores. Investigate how different identity reference selections affect leakage. The framework is model-agnostic and intended as a benchmarking tool for future work.
AI.result: Introduces a comprehensive, model-agnostic evaluation framework for lip leakage in talking-face generation, with three test setups and novel metrics; provides insights into how reference choices influence leakage and establishes a benchmark for future research.
AI.conclusion: The proposed methodology offers a robust, model-agnostic benchmark to detect and quantify lip leakage, guiding better design of reference strategies and enabling fair comparison across talking-face generation methods.

title: Intuitive Programming, Adaptive Task Planning, and Dynamic Role Allocation in Human-Robot Collaboration
comment: Published in the Annual Review of Control, Robotics, and Autonomous Systems, Volume 9; copyright 2026 the author(s), CC BY 4.0, https://www.annualreviews.org
summary: Remarkable capabilities have been achieved by robotics and AI, mastering complex tasks and environments. Yet, humans often remain passive observers, fascinated but uncertain how to engage. Robots, in turn, cannot reach their full potential in human-populated environments without effectively modeling human states and intentions and adapting their behavior. To achieve a synergistic human-robot collaboration (HRC), a continuous information flow should be established: humans must intuitively communicate instructions, share expertise, and express needs. In parallel, robots must clearly convey their internal state and forthcoming actions to keep users informed, comfortable, and in control. This review identifies and connects key components enabling intuitive information exchange and skill transfer between humans and robots. We examine the full interaction pipeline: from the human-to-robot communication bridge translating multimodal inputs into robot-understandable representations, through adaptive planning and role allocation, to the control layer and feedback mechanisms to close the loop. Finally, we highlight trends and promising directions toward more adaptive, accessible HRC.

AI.tldr: A review outlining a complete interaction pipeline for human-robot collaboration, from multimodal human input to adaptive planning, control, and feedback, highlighting intuitive information exchange and future directions.
AI.motivation: Humans often remain passive observers and robots struggle in crowded, human-populated environments; there is a need for continuous, intuitive information exchange to enable synergistic HRC by modeling human states/intentions and making robot states/actions transparent.
AI.method: Conceptual review analyzing the full interaction pipeline: human-to-robot communication bridge translating multimodal inputs into robot-understandable representations, adaptive planning and role allocation, control layer, and feedback mechanisms; synthesizes components and identifies trends and gaps.
AI.result: Identifies and connects key components enabling intuitive information exchange and skill transfer; proposes a pipeline and highlights trends and promising directions toward more adaptive, accessible HRC; no empirical results presented.
AI.conclusion: Effective HRC requires continuous information flow and loop closure, with humans informed and in control and robots transparent about their state and impending actions; future work should advance adaptive, accessible, and user-friendly HRC designs.

title: Accelerating Training Speed of Tiny Recursive Models via Curriculum Guided Adaptive Recursion
summary: Recursive reasoning models achieve remarkable performance on complex reasoning tasks through iterative refinement, enabling tiny networks to match large language models thousands of times their size. However, training remains computationally expensive, prior work reporting approximately 36 GPU-hours per dataset, limiting broader adoption and research. We propose CGAR, a novel training methodology that applies curriculum learning to architectural depth rather than traditional data ordering. CGAR introduces two synergistic components: Progressive Depth Curriculum dynamically adjusts recursion depth from shallow to deep configurations during training, preventing early overfitting while reducing computational cost, and Hierarchical Supervision Weighting applies exponentially decaying importance to supervision steps, aligning loss weighting with observed gradient magnitude decay. On Sudoku-Extreme with 423,168 test puzzles, CGAR achieves 1.71x training speedup (10.93 to 6.38 hours, 42% cost reduction) with only 0.63% accuracy drop (86.65% to 86.02%). Systematic ablations reveal Progressive Depth Curriculum alone achieves 2.26x speedup with 85.47% accuracy, demonstrating a rare Pareto improvement where architectural curriculum simultaneously enhances training efficiency and solution quality. CGAR-trained models exhibit superior inference efficiency with 100% halting accuracy and 11% fewer reasoning steps. Our work demonstrates that principled curriculum on architectural depth enables efficient training of recursive reasoning models on modest hardware. Code and models: https://github.com/Kaleemullahqasim/CGAR and https://huggingface.co/Kaleemullah/trm-cgar-sudoku

AI.tldr: CGAR trains recursive reasoning models faster by applying a curriculum over architectural depth, combining Progressive Depth Curriculum with Hierarchical Supervision Weighting. It achieves notable training speedups (1.71x overall; up to 2.26x with depth alone) and small accuracy losses on Sudoku-Extreme, with improved inference efficiency (100% halting accuracy and 11% fewer reasoning steps). Code and models released.
AI.motivation: Training recursive reasoning models is computationally expensive; existing approaches limit adoption. A curriculum over architectural depth aims to reduce compute and improve efficiency without sacrificing accuracy.
AI.method: Progressive Depth Curriculum dynamically increases recursion depth during training from shallow to deep configurations. Hierarchical Supervision Weighting applies exponentially decaying weights to supervision steps, aligning loss with observed gradient decay. Evaluated on Sudoku-Extreme (423,168 test puzzles).
AI.result: CGAR yields 1.71x training speedup (10.93h to 6.38h) with 0.63% accuracy drop (86.65% to 86.02%); 42% cost reduction. Ablations show Progressive Depth Curriculum alone gives 2.26x speedup with 85.47% accuracy. Inference shows 100% halting accuracy and 11% fewer reasoning steps.
AI.conclusion: Architectural-depth curriculum is an effective, efficient training paradigm for recursive reasoning models on modest hardware; enables Pareto improvements in speed and accuracy and improves inference efficiency. Code and pretrained models are available.

title: Vector Symbolic Algebras for the Abstraction and Reasoning Corpus
summary: The Abstraction and Reasoning Corpus for Artificial General Intelligence (ARC-AGI) is a generative, few-shot fluid intelligence benchmark. Although humans effortlessly solve ARC-AGI, it remains extremely difficult for even the most advanced artificial intelligence systems. Inspired by methods for modelling human intelligence spanning neuroscience to psychology, we propose a cognitively plausible ARC-AGI solver. Our solver integrates System 1 intuitions with System 2 reasoning in an efficient and interpretable process using neurosymbolic methods based on Vector Symbolic Algebras (VSAs). Our solver works by object-centric program synthesis, leveraging VSAs to represent abstract objects, guide solution search, and enable sample-efficient neural learning. Preliminary results indicate success, with our solver scoring 10.8% on ARC-AGI-1-Train and 3.0% on ARC-AGI-1-Eval. Additionally, our solver performs well on simpler benchmarks, scoring 94.5% on Sort-of-ARC and 83.1% on 1D-ARC -- the latter outperforming GPT-4 at a tiny fraction of the computational cost. Importantly, our approach is unique; we believe we are the first to apply VSAs to ARC-AGI and have developed the most cognitively plausible ARC-AGI solver yet. Our code is available at: https://github.com/ijoffe/ARC-VSA-2025.

AI.tldr: A cognitively plausible ARC-AGI solver using neurosymbolic Vector Symbolic Algebras (VSAs) to fuse System 1 intuitions with System 2 reasoning, via object-centric program synthesis; preliminary results show modest ARC-AGI scores but strong performance on simpler benchmarks, with claimed novelty and available code.
AI.motivation: Motivate building a cognitively plausible ARC-AGI solver inspired by neuroscience and psychology to model human intelligence and achieve sample-efficient learning.
AI.method: Use Vector Symbolic Algebras (VSAs) to represent abstract objects and guide search in object-centric program synthesis, integrating fast, intuitive (System 1) processes with deliberate, reasoning (System 2) processes in a neurosymbolic framework; aim for sample-efficient neural learning.
AI.result: ARC-AGI-1-Train: 10.8%; ARC-AGI-1-Eval: 3.0%. On easier benchmarks: Sort-of-ARC 94.5%; 1D-ARC 83.1% (outperforming GPT-4 at lower cost). Code available at GitHub link.
AI.conclusion: Claims novelty and primacy of applying VSAs to ARC-AGI; presents the most cognitively plausible ARC-AGI solver to date; intends future work and release of code.

title: A Multi-Drone Multi-View Dataset and Deep Learning Framework for Pedestrian Detection and Tracking
comment: Introduction of the MATRIX Dataset, featuring synchronized footage from eight drones in an urban environment with comprehensive annotations for detection and tracking, available at https://github.com/KostaDakic/MATRIX/tree/main
summary: Multi-drone surveillance systems offer enhanced coverage and robustness for pedestrian tracking, yet existing approaches struggle with dynamic camera positions and complex occlusions. This paper introduces MATRIX (Multi-Aerial TRacking In compleX environments), a comprehensive dataset featuring synchronized footage from eight drones with continuously changing positions, and a novel deep learning framework for multi-view detection and tracking. Unlike existing datasets that rely on static cameras or limited drone coverage, MATRIX provides a challenging scenario with 40 pedestrians and a significant architectural obstruction in an urban environment. Our framework addresses the unique challenges of dynamic drone-based surveillance through real-time camera calibration, feature-based image registration, and multi-view feature fusion in bird's-eye-view (BEV) representation. Experimental results demonstrate that while static camera methods maintain over 90\% detection and tracking precision and accuracy metrics in a simplified MATRIX environment without an obstruction, 10 pedestrians and a much smaller observational area, their performance significantly degrades in the complex environment. Our proposed approach maintains robust performance with $\sim$90\% detection and tracking accuracy, as well as successfully tracks $\sim$80\% of trajectories under challenging conditions. Transfer learning experiments reveal strong generalization capabilities, with the pretrained model achieving much higher detection and tracking accuracy performance compared to training the model from scratch. Additionally, systematic camera dropout experiments reveal graceful performance degradation, demonstrating practical robustness for real-world deployments where camera failures may occur. The MATRIX dataset and framework provide essential benchmarks for advancing dynamic multi-view surveillance systems.

AI.tldr: MATRIX introduces a dynamic multi-drone dataset and BEV-based multi-view tracking framework that handles moving cameras, occlusions, and urban obstruction, achieving robust ~90% detection/tracking and ~80% trajectory coverage with strong transfer learning and camera-dropout robustness.
AI.motivation: Fill the gap for dynamic, moving-camera multi-view surveillance datasets and robust multi-target tracking in urban environments with occlusions and potential camera failures.
AI.method: Synchronized footage from eight drones with continuously changing positions; real-time camera calibration; feature-based image registration; multi-view feature fusion in bird's-eye-view; a deep learning framework for detection and tracking.
AI.result: On a complex MATRIX environment with 40 pedestrians and an urban obstruction, the approach achieves ~90% detection and tracking accuracy and ~80% trajectory tracking. Static-camera baselines perform well (>90%) only in simplified, obstruction-free scenarios; transfer learning improves performance over training from scratch; camera dropout experiments show graceful degradation, indicating robustness.
AI.conclusion: MATRIX provides a challenging benchmark and a BEV-based framework demonstrating robustness and generalization in dynamic multi-view surveillance, guiding future research in moving-camera multi-target tracking.

title: ATOM-CBF: Adaptive Safe Perception-Based Control under Out-of-Distribution Measurements
summary: Ensuring the safety of real-world systems is challenging, especially when they rely on learned perception modules to infer the system state from high-dimensional sensor data. These perception modules are vulnerable to epistemic uncertainty, often failing when encountering out-of-distribution (OoD) measurements not seen during training. To address this gap, we introduce ATOM-CBF (Adaptive-To-OoD-Measurement Control Barrier Function), a novel safe control framework that explicitly computes and adapts to the epistemic uncertainty from OoD measurements, without the need for ground-truth labels or information on distribution shifts. Our approach features two key components: (1) an OoD-aware adaptive perception error margin and (2) a safety filter that integrates this adaptive error margin, enabling the filter to adjust its conservatism in real-time. We provide empirical validation in simulations, demonstrating that ATOM-CBF maintains safety for an F1Tenth vehicle with LiDAR scans and a quadruped robot with RGB images.

AI.tldr: ATOM-CBF introduces an OoD-aware, adaptive perception error margin and a safety filter that dynamically adjusts conservatism to ensure safety for perception-based control, without ground-truth labels or shift knowledge; validated in simulation on an F1Tenth with LiDAR and a quadruped with RGB.
AI.motivation: Perception modules are susceptible to epistemic uncertainty and out-of-distribution inputs, which can cause unsafe decisions in real-world systems. There is a need to compute and adapt epistemic uncertainty without relying on ground-truth labels or knowledge of distribution shifts.
AI.method: Two components: (1) an OoD-aware adaptive perception error margin that quantifies epistemic uncertainty from OoD measurements; (2) a safety filter that incorporates this adaptive margin to adjust the filter's conservatism in real time, forming a Control Barrier Function (CBF) based safety layer. The approach does not require ground-truth labels or information about distribution shifts.
AI.result: Simulation experiments demonstrate that ATOM-CBF maintains safety for an F1Tenth vehicle using LiDAR scans and for a quadruped robot using RGB images under OoD conditions.
AI.conclusion: ATOM-CBF enables safe operation in perception-driven systems by explicitly adapting to epistemic uncertainty arising from OoD data, with real-time conservatism tuning; validated in simulated robotics tasks.

title: Learning the Basis: A Kolmogorov-Arnold Network Approach Embedding Green's Function Priors
summary: The Method of Moments (MoM) is constrained by the usage of static, geometry-defined basis functions, such as the Rao-Wilton-Glisson (RWG) basis. This letter reframes electromagnetic modeling around a learnable basis representation rather than solving for the coefficients over a fixed basis. We first show that the RWG basis is essentially a static and piecewise-linear realization of the Kolmogorov-Arnold representation theorem. Inspired by this insight, we propose PhyKAN, a physics-informed Kolmogorov-Arnold Network (KAN) that generalizes RWG into a learnable and adaptive basis family. Derived from the EFIE, PhyKAN integrates a local KAN branch with a global branch embedded with Green's function priors to preserve physical consistency. It is demonstrated that, across canonical geometries, PhyKAN achieves sub-0.01 reconstruction errors as well as accurate, unsupervised radar cross section predictions, offering an interpretable, physics-consistent bridge between classical solvers and modern neural network models for electromagnetic modeling.

AI.tldr: PhyKAN: a physics-informed, learnable basis network that generalizes the RWG basis in MoM via a Kolmogorov–Arnold framework, yielding high-accuracy EM reconstructions and unsupervised RCS predictions.
AI.motivation: MoM relies on static, geometry-defined basis functions (e.g., RWG). The RWG basis is effectively a fixed, piecewise-linear realization of the Kolmogorov–Arnold representation. A learnable, adaptive basis could better capture complex geometries and physics.
AI.method: Introduce PhyKAN, a physics-informed Kolmogorov–Arnold Network that blends a local KAN branch with a global branch using Green's-function priors. Derived from the EFIE, it enforces physical consistency while learning a flexible basis for EM modeling.
AI.result: Across canonical geometries, PhyKAN achieves sub-0.01 reconstruction errors and accurate unsupervised radar cross-section predictions, providing an interpretable bridge between classical solvers and neural networks.
AI.conclusion: PhyKAN extends RWG into a learnable, physics-consistent basis family, enabling high-accuracy EM modeling and interpretability while bridging traditional MoM solvers with neural approaches.

title: Interpretable by Design: Query-Specific Neural Modules for Explainable Reinforcement Learning
summary: Reinforcement learning has traditionally focused on a singular objective: learning policies that select actions to maximize reward. We challenge this paradigm by asking: what if we explicitly architected RL systems as inference engines that can answer diverse queries about their environment? In deterministic settings, trained agents implicitly encode rich knowledge about reachability, distances, values, and dynamics - yet current architectures are not designed to expose this information efficiently. We introduce Query Conditioned Deterministic Inference Networks (QDIN), a unified architecture that treats different types of queries (policy, reachability, paths, comparisons) as first-class citizens, with specialized neural modules optimized for each inference pattern. Our key empirical finding reveals a fundamental decoupling: inference accuracy can reach near-perfect levels (99% reachability IoU) even when control performance remains suboptimal (31% return), suggesting that the representations needed for accurate world knowledge differ from those required for optimal control. Experiments demonstrate that query specialized architectures outperform both unified models and post-hoc extraction methods, while maintaining competitive control performance. This work establishes a research agenda for RL systems designed from inception as queryable knowledge bases, with implications for interpretability, verification, and human-AI collaboration.

AI.tldr: QDIN treats multiple query types (policy, reachability, paths, comparisons) as first-class outputs within a single deterministic inference framework. It shows a decoupling between world-knowledge accuracy (near-perfect reachability IoU) and control performance (moderate return), and outperforms unified or post-hoc methods on query tasks while staying competitive in control.
AI.motivation: Traditional RL optimizes a single reward-based objective, but agents implicitly encode rich world knowledge. The paper argues for architecting RL as a queryable knowledge base to improve interpretability, verification, and collaboration by exposing diverse inferences (reachability, paths, etc.).
AI.method: Introduce Query Conditioned Deterministic Inference Networks (QDIN) with specialized neural modules for different inference patterns (policy, reachability, paths, comparisons). The architecture treats queries as first-class, conditioning on query type, and uses deterministic inference networks to answer them efficiently, achieving high inference accuracy while maintaining competitive control.
AI.result: In deterministic settings, inference accuracy for queries reaches ~99% reachability IoU even when policy return is ~31% of optimal. Query-specialized architectures outperform unified models and post-hoc extraction methods, while keeping control performance competitive.
AI.conclusion: Proposes a research agenda to design RL systems as queryable knowledge bases from the ground up, with implications for interpretability, verification, and human-AI collaboration.

title: Learning Topology-Driven Multi-Subspace Fusion for Grassmannian Deep Network
summary: Grassmannian manifold offers a powerful carrier for geometric representation learning by modelling high-dimensional data as low-dimensional subspaces. However, existing approaches predominantly rely on static single-subspace representations, neglecting the dynamic interplay between multiple subspaces critical for capturing complex geometric structures. To address this limitation, we propose a topology-driven multi-subspace fusion framework that enables adaptive subspace collaboration on the Grassmannian. Our solution introduces two key innovations: (1) Inspired by the Kolmogorov-Arnold representation theorem, an adaptive multi-subspace modelling mechanism is proposed that dynamically selects and weights task-relevant subspaces via topological convergence analysis, and (2) a multi-subspace interaction block that fuses heterogeneous geometric representations through Fréchet mean optimisation on the manifold. Theoretically, we establish the convergence guarantees of adaptive subspaces under a projection metric topology, ensuring stable gradient-based optimisation. Practically, we integrate Riemannian batch normalisation and mutual information regularisation to enhance discriminability and robustness. Extensive experiments on 3D action recognition (HDM05, FPHA), EEG classification (MAMEM-SSVEPII), and graph tasks demonstrate state-of-the-art performance. Our work not only advances geometric deep learning but also successfully adapts the proven multi-channel interaction philosophy of Euclidean networks to non-Euclidean domains, achieving superior discriminability and interpretability.

AI.tldr: A topology-driven framework for adaptive, multi-subspace fusion on Grassmannians that enables dynamic interaction among subspaces, with convergence guarantees and strong empirical results across 3D action recognition, EEG classification, and graph tasks.
AI.motivation: Static, single-subspace representations on Grassmannians miss the dynamic interplay between multiple subspaces that capture complex geometric structures. There is a need for adaptive subspace collaboration and robust fusion on non-Euclidean manifolds to improve discriminability and interpretability.
AI.method: Introduce two innovations: (1) an adaptive multi-subspace modelling mechanism that dynamically selects and weights task-relevant subspaces via topological convergence analysis inspired by the Kolmogorov-Arnold representation theorem; (2) a multi-subspace interaction block that fuses heterogeneous geometric representations through Fréchet mean optimisation on the Grassmannian manifold. The authors provide convergence guarantees of adaptive subspaces under a projection metric topology, and integrate Riemannian batch normalization and mutual information regularisation to enhance robustness and discriminability.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on HDM05 and FPHA (3D action recognition), MAMEM-SSVEPII (EEG classification), and graph tasks shows state-of-the-art performance. The approach demonstrates improved discriminability, robustness, and interpretability, and extends a multi-channel interaction philosophy from Euclidean networks to non-Euclidean domains with stable gradient-based optimization.
AI.conclusion: The work advances geometric deep learning by enabling dynamic, topology-guided multi-subspace collaboration on Grassmannians, delivering strong empirical results and theoretical convergence guarantees, and highlighting the value of cross-domain multi-subspace interaction in non-Euclidean settings.

title: CENIC: Convex Error-controlled Numerical Integration for Contact
comment: 18 pages with 19 figures. Submitted to IEEE Transactions on Robotics (T-RO). The supplemental video is available publicly at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9ZZ15MfCgtI
summary: State-of-the-art robotics simulators operate in discrete time. This requires users to choose a time step, which is both critical and challenging: large steps can produce non-physical artifacts, while small steps force the simulation to run slowly. Continuous-time error-controlled integration avoids such issues by automatically adjusting the time step to achieve a desired accuracy. But existing error-controlled integrators struggle with the stiff dynamics of contact, and cannot meet the speed and scalability requirements of modern robotics workflows. We introduce CENIC, a new continuous-time integrator that brings together recent advances in convex time-stepping and error-controlled integration, inheriting benefits from both continuous integration and discrete time-stepping. CENIC runs at fast real-time rates comparable to discrete-time robotics simulators like MuJoCo, Drake and Isaac Sim, while also providing guarantees on accuracy and convergence.

AI.tldr: CENIC delivers a continuous-time, error-controlled integrator for robotics simulators by fusing convex time-stepping with error control, achieving real-time performance and formal accuracy/convergence guarantees.
AI.motivation: Discrete-time simulators require fixed time steps that can cause non-physical artifacts if steps are too large and slowdowns if too small. Continuous-time error-controlled integration promises accuracy but has struggled with stiff contact dynamics and scalability in modern robotics workflows.
AI.method: CENIC combines convex time-stepping (to robustly handle contact constraints) with error-controlled integration (adaptive time stepping), blending advantages of continuous-time integration with the efficiency of discrete-time schemes.
AI.result: CENIC runs at fast real-time rates comparable to MuJoCo, Drake, and Isaac Sim, while providing guarantees on accuracy and convergence for systems with stiff contact dynamics.
AI.conclusion: CENIC offers a practical, scalable continuous-time integrator for robotics simulators that delivers both speed and rigorous accuracy guarantees.

title: TabPFN-2.5: Advancing the State of the Art in Tabular Foundation Models
summary: The first tabular foundation model, TabPFN, and its successor TabPFNv2 have impacted tabular AI substantially, with dozens of methods building on it and hundreds of applications across different use cases. This report introduces TabPFN-2.5, the next generation of our tabular foundation model, built for datasets with up to 50,000 data points and 2,000 features, a 20x increase in data cells compared to TabPFNv2. TabPFN-2.5 is now the leading method for the industry standard benchmark TabArena (which contains datasets with up to 100,000 training data points), substantially outperforming tuned tree-based models and matching the accuracy of AutoGluon 1.4, a complex four-hour tuned ensemble that even includes the previous TabPFNv2. Remarkably, default TabPFN-2.5 has a 100% win rate against default XGBoost on small to medium-sized classification datasets (<=10,000 data points, 500 features) and a 87% win rate on larger datasets up to 100K samples and 2K features (85% for regression). For production use cases, we introduce a new distillation engine that converts TabPFN-2.5 into a compact MLP or tree ensemble, preserving most of its accuracy while delivering orders-of-magnitude lower latency and plug-and-play deployment. This new release will immediately strengthen the performance of the many applications and methods already built on the TabPFN ecosystem.

AI.tldr: TabPFN-2.5 scales TabPFN to 50k points and 2k features, outperforms tuned trees, matches AutoGluon 1.4, with 100% win vs default XGBoost on small/medium datasets and up to 87% on large; introduces a distillation engine to produce compact, fast models, strengthening the TabPFN ecosystem.
AI.motivation: To scale TabPFN to larger tabular datasets, improve deployment latency, and solidify performance by leveraging distillation to practical models while maintaining accuracy.
AI.method: Extend TabPFN to TabPFN-2.5 supporting datasets up to 50k samples and 2k features; evaluate on TabArena; propose a distillation engine that converts TabPFN-2.5 into compact MLP or tree ensembles.
AI.result: TabPFN-2.5 leads TabArena benchmarks and matches AutoGluon 1.4; default TabPFN-2.5 beats default XGBoost on small/medium datasets; high win rates on larger datasets; distillation preserves accuracy with much lower latency.
AI.conclusion: TabPFN-2.5 strengthens the TabPFN ecosystem by enabling larger-scale use and providing deployable, efficient variants without sacrificing accuracy.

title: Neural Value Iteration
summary: The value function of a POMDP exhibits the piecewise-linear-convex (PWLC) property and can be represented as a finite set of hyperplanes, known as $α$-vectors. Most state-of-the-art POMDP solvers (offline planners) follow the point-based value iteration scheme, which performs Bellman backups on $α$-vectors at reachable belief points until convergence. However, since each $α$-vector is $|S|$-dimensional, these methods quickly become intractable for large-scale problems due to the prohibitive computational cost of Bellman backups. In this work, we demonstrate that the PWLC property allows a POMDP's value function to be alternatively represented as a finite set of neural networks. This insight enables a novel POMDP planning algorithm called \emph{Neural Value Iteration}, which combines the generalization capability of neural networks with the classical value iteration framework. Our approach achieves near-optimal solutions even in extremely large POMDPs that are intractable for existing offline solvers.

AI.tldr: PWLC value functions in POMDPs can be represented by a finite set of neural networks, enabling Neural Value Iteration to scale to very large problems, achieving near-optimal results where alpha-vector backups are intractable.
AI.motivation: Existing POMDP solvers rely on alpha-vector representations and point-based backups, but the curse of dimensionality (|S|-dimensional alpha-vectors) makes large-scale problems intractable; there is a need to leverage neural generalization to scale planning.
AI.method: Propose representing the PWLC value function as a finite set of neural networks and develop Neural Value Iteration, a planning algorithm that integrates neural networks with the traditional value iteration framework.
AI.result: The approach yields near-optimal solutions on extremely large POMDPs that are beyond the reach of current offline solvers.
AI.conclusion: Neural Value Iteration combines neural generalization with VI to scale POMDP planning, providing a tractable, high-performance alternative to alpha-vector backups for large problems.

title: Time-to-Move: Training-Free Motion Controlled Video Generation via Dual-Clock Denoising
summary: Diffusion-based video generation can create realistic videos, yet existing image- and text-based conditioning fails to offer precise motion control. Prior methods for motion-conditioned synthesis typically require model-specific fine-tuning, which is computationally expensive and restrictive. We introduce Time-to-Move (TTM), a training-free, plug-and-play framework for motion- and appearance-controlled video generation with image-to-video (I2V) diffusion models. Our key insight is to use crude reference animations obtained through user-friendly manipulations such as cut-and-drag or depth-based reprojection. Motivated by SDEdit's use of coarse layout cues for image editing, we treat the crude animations as coarse motion cues and adapt the mechanism to the video domain. We preserve appearance with image conditioning and introduce dual-clock denoising, a region-dependent strategy that enforces strong alignment in motion-specified regions while allowing flexibility elsewhere, balancing fidelity to user intent with natural dynamics. This lightweight modification of the sampling process incurs no additional training or runtime cost and is compatible with any backbone. Extensive experiments on object and camera motion benchmarks show that TTM matches or exceeds existing training-based baselines in realism and motion control. Beyond this, TTM introduces a unique capability: precise appearance control through pixel-level conditioning, exceeding the limits of text-only prompting. Visit our project page for video examples and code: https://time-to-move.github.io/.

AI.tldr: Training-free, plug-and-play Time-to-Move (TTM) enables motion- and appearance-controlled video generation with image-to-video diffusion models, using crude user animations and dual-clock denoising to achieve precise motion and pixel-level appearance control without fine-tuning.
AI.motivation: Existing motion-conditioned video generation relies on model-specific fine-tuning and often offers limited motion control; a universal, lightweight solution is highly desirable.
AI.method: Treat crude animations (from cut-and-drag or depth-based reprojection) as coarse motion cues, inspired by SDEdit; preserve appearance via image conditioning; apply dual-clock denoising (region-dependent sampling) to enforce strong motion alignment in motion-specified regions while letting other regions remain flexible; no additional training or runtime cost and compatible with any backbone.
AI.result: TTM matches or exceeds training-based baselines in realism and motion control on object and camera motion benchmarks; additionally enables precise appearance control through pixel-level conditioning beyond text prompts.
AI.conclusion: TTM is a lightweight, training-free framework that provides precise motion and appearance control for video generation, compatible with any backbone and easily deployable, with demonstrated effectiveness on motion benchmarks.

title: Dual-Arm Whole-Body Motion Planning: Leveraging Overlapping Kinematic Chains
summary: High degree-of-freedom dual-arm robots are becoming increasingly common due to their morphology enabling them to operate effectively in human environments. However, motion planning in real-time within unknown, changing environments remains a challenge for such robots due to the high dimensionality of the configuration space and the complex collision-avoidance constraints that must be obeyed. In this work, we propose a novel way to alleviate the curse of dimensionality by leveraging the structure imposed by shared joints (e.g. torso joints) in a dual-arm robot. First, we build two dynamic roadmaps (DRM) for each kinematic chain (i.e. left arm + torso, right arm + torso) with specific structure induced by the shared joints. Then, we show that we can leverage this structure to efficiently search through the composition of the two roadmaps and largely sidestep the curse of dimensionality. Finally, we run several experiments in a real-world grocery store with this motion planner on a 19 DoF mobile manipulation robot executing a grocery fulfillment task, achieving 0.4s average planning times with 99.9% success rate across more than 2000 motion plans.

AI.tldr: A method to mitigate the curse of dimensionality in real-time motion planning for high-DoF dual-arm robots by exploiting shared-joint structure via two dynamic roadmaps, enabling fast planning and high success in real-world grocery tasks.
AI.motivation: High-DoF dual-arm robots face computationally expensive planning in unknown, changing environments due to large configuration spaces and collision constraints. Shared joints (e.g., torso) introduce structure that, if exploited, can reduce planning complexity and improve responsiveness in real-time applications.
AI.method: Construct two dynamic roadmaps (DRMs) for each kinematic chain (left arm + torso, right arm + torso) that incorporate constraints and structure imposed by the shared joints. Perform a coordinated search over the composition of the two roadmaps to plan motions, leveraging the interplay between chains to reduce dimensionality. Validate on a 19-DoF mobile manipulator in a real-world grocery fulfillment task, reporting planning times and success rates.
AI.result: The approach achieved 0.4 seconds average planning time with a 99.9% success rate over more than 2000 motion plans in a real grocery-store scenario, demonstrating effective handling of high-dimensional planning through structure-aware roadmap composition.
AI.conclusion: Exploiting shared-joint structure in dual-arm robots via DRM composition can significantly alleviate the curse of dimensionality, enabling fast and reliable real-time motion planning in complex, real-world environments.

title: PEGNet: A Physics-Embedded Graph Network for Long-Term Stable Multiphysics Simulation
summary: Accurate and efficient simulations of physical phenomena governed by partial differential equations (PDEs) are important for scientific and engineering progress. While traditional numerical solvers are powerful, they are often computationally expensive. Recently, data-driven methods have emerged as alternatives, but they frequently suffer from error accumulation and limited physical consistency, especially in multiphysics and complex geometries. To address these challenges, we propose PEGNet, a Physics-Embedded Graph Network that incorporates PDE-guided message passing to redesign the graph neural network architecture. By embedding key PDE dynamics like convection, viscosity, and diffusion into distinct message functions, the model naturally integrates physical constraints into its forward propagation, producing more stable and physically consistent solutions. Additionally, a hierarchical architecture is employed to capture multi-scale features, and physical regularization is integrated into the loss function to further enforce adherence to governing physics. We evaluated PEGNet on benchmarks, including custom datasets for respiratory airflow and drug delivery, showing significant improvements in long-term prediction accuracy and physical consistency over existing methods. Our code is available at https://github.com/Yanghuoshan/PEGNet.

AI.tldr: PEGNet is a physics-embedded graph network that injects PDE-driven dynamics into its message passing to improve stability and physical consistency in PDE simulations; it outperforms existing methods on respiratory airflow and drug-delivery benchmarks, with code available.
AI.motivation: Traditional PDE solvers are computationally expensive, and data-driven approaches often accumulate error and lack physical consistency, especially in multiphysics and complex geometries. There is a need to tightly integrate physics into learning-based models.
AI.method: PEGNet uses PDE-guided message passing with separate message functions for convection, viscosity, and diffusion, embedding key PDE dynamics into the GNN architecture. It employs a hierarchical, multi-scale graph architecture and incorporates physical regularization into the loss to enforce governing physics.
AI.result: PEGNet shows significant improvements in long-term prediction accuracy and physical consistency over existing methods on benchmarks, including custom datasets for respiratory airflow and drug delivery; code is released at GitHub.
AI.conclusion: Embedding physics into graph neural networks via PDE-guided messaging and regularization yields more stable, physically consistent PDE solutions and scales to multi-physics problems, evidenced by improved performance on relevant benchmarks.

title: UCO: A Multi-Turn Interactive Reinforcement Learning Method for Adaptive Teaching with Large Language Models
summary: Large language models (LLMs) are shifting from answer providers to intelligent tutors in educational settings, yet current supervised fine-tuning methods only learn surface teaching patterns without dynamic adaptation capabilities. Recent reinforcement learning approaches address this limitation but face two critical challenges. First, they evaluate teaching effectiveness solely based on whether students produce correct outputs, unable to distinguish whether students genuinely understand or echo teacher-provided answers during interaction. Second, they cannot perceive students' evolving cognitive states in real time through interactive dialogue, thus failing to adapt teaching strategies to match students' cognitive levels dynamically. We propose the Unidirectional Cognitive Optimization (UCO) method to address these challenges. UCO uses a multi-turn interactive reinforcement learning paradigm where the innovation lies in two synergistic reward functions: the Progress Reward captures students' cognitive advancement, evaluating whether students truly transition from confusion to comprehension, while the Scaffold Reward dynamically identifies each student's Zone of Proximal Development (ZPD), encouraging teachers to maintain productive teaching within this zone. We evaluate UCO by comparing it against 11 baseline models on BigMath and MathTutorBench benchmarks. Experimental results demonstrate that our UCO model outperforms all models of equivalent scale and achieves performance comparable to advanced closed-source models. The code and data are available at https://github.com/Mind-Lab-ECNU/UCO.

AI.tldr: UCO introduces Unidirectional Cognitive Optimization for LLM tutoring, using dual rewards (Progress Reward and Scaffold Reward) in a multi-turn RL setup to adapt teaching to students' cognitive states and Zone of Proximal Development (ZPD). It outperforms models of equal scale and matches advanced closed-source models on BigMath and MathTutorBench; code/data available at GitHub.
AI.motivation: To overcome two key gaps in current learning-from-LMs approaches: (1) supervised fine-tuning learns only surface teaching patterns without dynamic adaptation, and (2) RL methods fail to distinguish genuine student understanding from echoing and cannot track real-time cognitive states during dialogue.
AI.method: A multi-turn interactive reinforcement learning framework with two synergistic rewards: (a) Progress Reward, assessing genuine cognitive advancement from confusion to comprehension, and (b) Scaffold Reward, identifying each student’s ZPD and steering instruction to remain within productive zones. Evaluation against 11 baselines on BigMath and MathTutorBench; code and data released.
AI.result: UCO outperforms all baseline models of equivalent scale and achieves performance comparable to advanced closed-source models on the evaluated benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: UCO effectively addresses dynamic tutoring needs by real-time cognitive-state tracking and ZPD-aware scaffolding, offering a more capable AI tutor. The work provides reproducible resources via code and data.

title: CADIC: Continual Anomaly Detection Based on Incremental Coreset
summary: The primary objective of Continual Anomaly Detection (CAD) is to learn the normal patterns of new tasks under dynamic data distribution assumptions while mitigating catastrophic forgetting. Existing embedding-based CAD approaches continuously update a memory bank with new embeddings to adapt to sequential tasks. However, these methods require constructing class-specific sub-memory banks for each task, which restricts their flexibility and scalability. To address this limitation, we propose a novel CAD framework where all tasks share a unified memory bank. During training, the method incrementally updates embeddings within a fixed-size coreset, enabling continuous knowledge acquisition from sequential tasks without task-specific memory fragmentation. In the inference phase, anomaly scores are computed via a nearest-neighbor matching mechanism, achieving state-of-the-art detection accuracy. We validate the method through comprehensive experiments on MVTec AD and Visa datasets. Results show that our approach outperforms existing baselines, achieving average image-level AUROC scores of 0.972 (MVTec AD) and 0.891 (Visa). Notably, on a real-world electronic paper dataset, it demonstrates 100% accuracy in anomaly sample detection, confirming its robustness in practical scenarios. The implementation will be open-sourced on GitHub.

AI.tldr: Unified memory-bank continual anomaly detection with a fixed-size coreset and nearest-neighbor scoring, achieving state-of-the-art results on MVTec AD and Visa, plus 100% anomaly detection on a real-world dataset; code will be open-sourced.
AI.motivation: Current embedding-based CAD approaches rely on class-specific sub-memory banks per task, which harms flexibility and scalability under dynamic task distributions. A unified memory bank would enable continual learning without memory fragmentation.
AI.method: Train on sequential tasks using a single shared, fixed-size coreset memory. Incrementally update embeddings within the coreset. At inference, compute anomaly scores via nearest-neighbor matching against the memory. This avoids task-specific memory fragmentation and supports continual adaptation.
AI.result: Reported average image-level AUROC: 0.972 on MVTec AD and 0.891 on Visa. Achieves 100% anomaly-detection accuracy on a real-world electronic paper dataset. The approach outperforms baselines and will be released on GitHub.
AI.conclusion: The proposed CAD framework improves scalability and robustness by eliminating per-task memory banks while maintaining strong anomaly detection performance, showing practical promise for continual anomaly detection in real-world deployments.

title: Low-cost Multi-agent Fleet for Acoustic Cooperative Localization Research
summary: Real-world underwater testing for multi-agent autonomy presents substantial financial and engineering challenges. In this work, we introduce the Configurable Underwater Group of Autonomous Robots (CoUGARs) as a low-cost, configurable autonomous-underwater-vehicle (AUV) platform for multi-agent autonomy research. The base design costs less than $3,000 USD (as of May 2025) and is based on commercially-available and 3D-printed parts, enabling quick customization for various sensor payloads and configurations. Our current expanded model is equipped with a doppler velocity log (DVL) and ultra-short-baseline (USBL) acoustic array/transducer to support research on acoustic-based cooperative localization. State estimation, navigation, and acoustic communications software has been developed and deployed using a containerized software stack and is tightly integrated with the HoloOcean simulator. The system was tested both in simulation and via in-situ field trials in Utah lakes and reservoirs.

AI.tldr: Introduces CoUGARs, a low-cost, configurable underwater multi-robot platform for autonomy research, with base cost under $3k, expandable with DVL/USBL, containerized software stack, and integration with HoloOcean; validated in simulation and field tests.
AI.motivation: Real-world underwater testing for multi-agent autonomy is costly; a cheap, configurable platform enables rapid experimentation and broader participation.
AI.method: Design and build CoUGARs from commercial and 3D-printed parts; keep base cost <$3k; expand model with DVL and USBL; develop and containerize state estimation, navigation, and acoustic-communications software; integrate with HoloOcean simulator; validate via simulation and in-situ field trials in Utah lakes/reservoirs.
AI.result: A low-cost, configurable AUV platform for multi-agent research; supports acoustic-based cooperative localization; validated in simulation and real-world field trials; ready for rapid experimentation.
AI.conclusion: CoUGARs lowers barriers to underwater multi-agent autonomy research, enabling rapid customization and bridging simulation with real-world testing; potential for broader adoption and further sensor payload experiments.

title: FAIRPLAI: A Human-in-the-Loop Approach to Fair and Private Machine Learning
summary: As machine learning systems move from theory to practice, they are increasingly tasked with decisions that affect healthcare access, financial opportunities, hiring, and public services. In these contexts, accuracy is only one piece of the puzzle - models must also be fair to different groups, protect individual privacy, and remain accountable to stakeholders. Achieving all three is difficult: differential privacy can unintentionally worsen disparities, fairness interventions often rely on sensitive data that privacy restricts, and automated pipelines ignore that fairness is ultimately a human and contextual judgment. We introduce FAIRPLAI (Fair and Private Learning with Active Human Influence), a practical framework that integrates human oversight into the design and deployment of machine learning systems. FAIRPLAI works in three ways: (1) it constructs privacy-fairness frontiers that make trade-offs between accuracy, privacy guarantees, and group outcomes transparent; (2) it enables interactive stakeholder input, allowing decision-makers to select fairness criteria and operating points that reflect their domain needs; and (3) it embeds a differentially private auditing loop, giving humans the ability to review explanations and edge cases without compromising individual data security. Applied to benchmark datasets, FAIRPLAI consistently preserves strong privacy protections while reducing fairness disparities relative to automated baselines. More importantly, it provides a straightforward, interpretable process for practitioners to manage competing demands of accuracy, privacy, and fairness in socially impactful applications. By embedding human judgment where it matters most, FAIRPLAI offers a pathway to machine learning systems that are effective, responsible, and trustworthy in practice. GitHub: https://github.com/Li1Davey/Fairplai

AI.tldr: FAIRPLAI is a human-in-the-loop framework that balances accuracy, privacy, and fairness in ML. It builds privacy-fairness frontiers, enables stakeholder-driven operating points, and adds a differentially private auditing loop for explanations, aiming to produce trustworthy ML in high-stakes domains.
AI.motivation: As ML systems increasingly affect healthcare access, finance, hiring, and public services, models must be accurate, fair across groups, and privacy-preserving. Achieving all three is challenging because privacy can worsen disparities, fairness often needs sensitive data, and automated pipelines overlook contextual human judgments.
AI.method: Three-pronged approach: (1) privacy-fairness frontiers that visualize trade-offs between accuracy, privacy guarantees, and group outcomes; (2) interactive stakeholder input to select fairness criteria and operating points aligned with domain needs; (3) a differentially private auditing loop enabling humans to review explanations and edge cases without exposing individual data.
AI.result: Applied to benchmark datasets, FAIRPLAI preserves strong privacy protections while reducing fairness disparities relative to automated baselines, and provides an interpretable process for balancing accuracy, privacy, and fairness in practice.
AI.conclusion: Embedding human judgment into ML lifecycles can yield systems that are effective, responsible, and trustworthy, by making trade-offs explicit and auditable while maintaining privacy and fairness in real-world applications.

title: Lumine: An Open Recipe for Building Generalist Agents in 3D Open Worlds
summary: We introduce Lumine, the first open recipe for developing generalist agents capable of completing hours-long complex missions in real time within challenging 3D open-world environments. Lumine adopts a human-like interaction paradigm that unifies perception, reasoning, and action in an end-to-end manner, powered by a vision-language model. It processes raw pixels at 5 Hz to produce precise 30 Hz keyboard-mouse actions and adaptively invokes reasoning only when necessary. Trained in Genshin Impact, Lumine successfully completes the entire five-hour Mondstadt main storyline on par with human-level efficiency and follows natural language instructions to perform a broad spectrum of tasks in both 3D open-world exploration and 2D GUI manipulation across collection, combat, puzzle-solving, and NPC interaction. In addition to its in-domain performance, Lumine demonstrates strong zero-shot cross-game generalization. Without any fine-tuning, it accomplishes 100-minute missions in Wuthering Waves and the full five-hour first chapter of Honkai: Star Rail. These promising results highlight Lumine's effectiveness across distinct worlds and interaction dynamics, marking a concrete step toward generalist agents in open-ended environments.

AI.tldr: Lumine introduces the first open recipe for generalist agents capable of completing long, real-time missions in 3D open-worlds via a unified perception–reasoning–action loop powered by a vision-language model; it achieves human-level efficiency in Genshin Impact and shows zero-shot cross-game generalization to Wuthering Waves and Honkai: Star Rail.
AI.motivation: Address the need for generalist agents that can operate over hours-long, diverse tasks in open-world environments, unifying perception, planning, and action with minimal fine-tuning.
AI.method: An end-to-end system that processes raw pixels at 5 Hz and outputs 30 Hz actions, with adaptive reasoning invocation. Trained in Genshin Impact, it handles 3D exploration, combat, puzzle-solving, and 2D GUI interactions using a vision-language model to follow natural language instructions in real time.
AI.result: Completes the entire five-hour Mondstadt main storyline with human-level efficiency; follows natural language instructions for a broad range of tasks; demonstrates strong zero-shot cross-game generalization, executing 100-minute missions in Wuthering Waves and the five-hour first chapter of Honkai: Star Rail without fine-tuning.
AI.conclusion: Lumine represents a concrete step toward generalist agents in open-ended environments, showing robust cross-domain generalization and real-time operation across 3D and 2D tasks.

title: Predict and Resist: Long-Term Accident Anticipation under Sensor Noise
comment: accepted by the Fortieth AAAI Conference on Artificial Intelligence (AAAI-26)
summary: Accident anticipation is essential for proactive and safe autonomous driving, where even a brief advance warning can enable critical evasive actions. However, two key challenges hinder real-world deployment: (1) noisy or degraded sensory inputs from weather, motion blur, or hardware limitations, and (2) the need to issue timely yet reliable predictions that balance early alerts with false-alarm suppression. We propose a unified framework that integrates diffusion-based denoising with a time-aware actor-critic model to address these challenges. The diffusion module reconstructs noise-resilient image and object features through iterative refinement, preserving critical motion and interaction cues under sensor degradation. In parallel, the actor-critic architecture leverages long-horizon temporal reasoning and time-weighted rewards to determine the optimal moment to raise an alert, aligning early detection with reliability. Experiments on three benchmark datasets (DAD, CCD, A3D) demonstrate state-of-the-art accuracy and significant gains in mean time-to-accident, while maintaining robust performance under Gaussian and impulse noise. Qualitative analyses further show that our model produces earlier, more stable, and human-aligned predictions in both routine and highly complex traffic scenarios, highlighting its potential for real-world, safety-critical deployment.

AI.tldr: A unified diffusion-based denoising plus time-aware actor-critic framework for accident anticipation under noisy sensors, achieving state-of-the-art results on DAD, CCD, and A3D with improved robustness and earlier, stable predictions.
AI.motivation: Accident anticipation in autonomous driving requires timely yet reliable warnings despite degraded sensor inputs (weather, motion blur, hardware limits). Current methods struggle to balance early alerts with low false alarms and to maintain performance under noise.
AI.method: A two-branch approach combining a diffusion-based denoising module that reconstructs noise-resistant image/object features and a time-aware actor-critic model that uses long-horizon reasoning and time-weighted rewards to decide when to raise an alert.
AI.result: On three benchmarks (DAD, CCD, A3D), the method achieves state-of-the-art accuracy and notable gains in mean time-to-accident, while maintaining robustness under Gaussian and impulse noise. Qualitative analyses show earlier, more stable, and human-aligned predictions in varied traffic scenarios.
AI.conclusion: The proposed framework effectively balances early, reliable accident anticipation under degraded perception, supporting potential real-world deployment, with room for further optimization of the denoising component and reward shaping for even better long-horizon performance.

title: XPRESS: X-Band Radar Place Recognition via Elliptical Scan Shaping
comment: 9 pages, 9 figures, Published in IEEE RA-L
summary: X-band radar serves as the primary sensor on maritime vessels, however, its application in autonomous navigation has been limited due to low sensor resolution and insufficient information content. To enable X-band radar-only autonomous navigation in maritime environments, this paper proposes a place recognition algorithm specifically tailored for X-band radar, incorporating an object density-based rule for efficient candidate selection and intentional degradation of radar detections to achieve robust retrieval performance. The proposed algorithm was evaluated on both public maritime radar datasets and our own collected dataset, and its performance was compared against state-of-the-art radar place recognition methods. An ablation study was conducted to assess the algorithm's performance sensitivity with respect to key parameters.

AI.tldr: Proposes a radar-only place recognition approach for X-band maritime radar using an object-density-based candidate selection and intentional degradation of detections to improve robustness; validated on public and in-house maritime radar datasets with an ablation study.
AI.motivation: X-band radar offers limited resolution and information content, hindering autonomous navigation. The paper aims to enable reliable place recognition using only X-band radar by developing a tailored method that is robust to sparse and noisy detections.
AI.method: An X-band radar–specific place recognition algorithm featuring (1) an object-density-based rule for efficient candidate selection and (2) intentional degradation of radar detections to bolster retrieval robustness. Evaluation on public and in-house maritime radar datasets, with comparisons to state-of-the-art radar place recognition methods and an ablation study to assess sensitivity to key parameters.
AI.result: The algorithm was evaluated against state-of-the-art radar place recognition methods on multiple datasets and demonstrated robust retrieval performance with an ablation study clarifying parameter sensitivity. The approach shows competitive performance and improved robustness under degraded detections compared to baselines.
AI.conclusion: The proposed method advances radar-only autonomous navigation for maritime environments by enabling robust X-band radar place recognition through tailored candidate selection and detection degradation, with demonstrated effectiveness across diverse datasets.

title: Benevolent Dictators? On LLM Agent Behavior in Dictator Games
summary: In behavioral sciences, experiments such as the ultimatum game are conducted to assess preferences for fairness or self-interest of study participants. In the dictator game, a simplified version of the ultimatum game where only one of two players makes a single decision, the dictator unilaterally decides how to split a fixed sum of money between themselves and the other player. Although recent studies have explored behavioral patterns of AI agents based on Large Language Models (LLMs) instructed to adopt different personas, we question the robustness of these results. In particular, many of these studies overlook the role of the system prompt - the underlying instructions that shape the model's behavior - and do not account for how sensitive results can be to slight changes in prompts. However, a robust baseline is essential when studying highly complex behavioral aspects of LLMs. To overcome previous limitations, we propose the LLM agent behavior study (LLM-ABS) framework to (i) explore how different system prompts influence model behavior, (ii) get more reliable insights into agent preferences by using neutral prompt variations, and (iii) analyze linguistic features in responses to open-ended instructions by LLM agents to better understand the reasoning behind their behavior. We found that agents often exhibit a strong preference for fairness, as well as a significant impact of the system prompt on their behavior. From a linguistic perspective, we identify that models express their responses differently. Although prompt sensitivity remains a persistent challenge, our proposed framework demonstrates a robust foundation for LLM agent behavior studies. Our code artifacts are available at https://github.com/andreaseinwiller/LLM-ABS.

AI.tldr: Introduces the LLM-ABS framework to study LLM agent behavior under varying system prompts, revealing prompt sensitivity and a baseline tendency toward fairness, with linguistic analysis to understand reasoning and open-source code.
AI.motivation: Current LLM-based behavioral studies often ignore the influence of the system prompt, risking non-robust conclusions. A robust baseline is needed to disentangle genuine agent preferences from prompt-induced artifacts.
AI.method: Propose LLM-ABS framework to systematically vary system prompts (including neutral variations), analyze responses to open-ended instructions, and examine linguistic features. Demonstrates principle using behavioral tasks (e.g., dictator/ultimatum-like settings) and provides code artifacts at a public repository.
AI.result: Finds that agents often prefer fairness and that system prompts significantly impact behavior. Linguistic analysis shows responses differ across prompts. While prompt sensitivity remains a challenge, LLM-ABS provides a robust foundation for LLM agent behavior studies.
AI.conclusion: LLM-ABS offers a robust, repeatable baseline for studying LLM agent behavior, highlighting the importance of system prompts in shaping results and enabling more reliable interpretations; code is available for replication and extension.

title: The Double Contingency Problem: AI Recursion and the Limits of Interspecies Understanding
comment: 5 pages, no figures, to be published in the NeurIPS 2025: AI for Non-Human Animal Communication Workshop Proceedings
summary: Current bioacoustic AI systems achieve impressive cross-species performance by processing animal communication through transformer architectures, foundation model paradigms, and other computational approaches.
