However, these approaches overlook a fundamental question: what happens when one form of recursive cognition--AI systems with their attention mechanisms, iterative processing, and feedback loops--encounters the recursive communicative processes of other species? Drawing on philosopher Yuk Hui's work on recursivity and contingency, I argue that AI systems are not neutral pattern detectors but recursive cognitive agents whose own information processing may systematically obscure or distort other species' communicative structures. This creates a double contingency problem: each species' communication emerges through contingent ecological and evolutionary conditions, while AI systems process these signals through their own contingent architectural and training conditions. I propose that addressing this challenge requires reconceptualizing bioacoustic AI from universal pattern recognition toward diplomatic encounter between different forms of recursive cognition, with implications for model design, evaluation frameworks, and research methodologies.

AI.tldr: The abstract argues for reframing bioacoustic AI as a diplomatic encounter between recursive cognitive systems (AI and animal communication), rather than universal pattern recognition, drawing on Yuk Hui’s ideas of recursivity and contingency to address double contingency in cross-species signaling.
AI.motivation: To address a fundamental gap: AI systems, with their own recursive processing, may distort or misinterpret other species’ communication. The paper questions the assumption that cross-species bioacoustic analysis is neutral pattern recognition, highlighting the double contingency between AI architectures/training and ecological/evolutionary conditions shaping animal signals.
AI.method: Philosophical/theoretical analysis drawing on Yuk Hui’s concepts of recursivity and contingency; conceptual synthesis across AI and bioacoustics; proposes a new framing for design and evaluation.
AI.result: A theoretical framework that treats AI as recursive cognitive agents and animal communication as likewise recursive, leading to a double contingency problem. It yields a proposed reframing of bioacoustic AI from universal pattern recognition to diplomatic encounters between different forms of recursive cognition, with implications for model design, evaluation, and methodologies.
AI.conclusion: To advance bioacoustic AI, researchers should adopt a diplomatic, cross-cognitive approach that acknowledges contingent conditions on both sides, developing design principles, evaluation metrics, and research methods that foster genuine cross-species communicative understanding rather than mere pattern matching.

title: RS-Net: Context-Aware Relation Scoring for Dynamic Scene Graph Generation
summary: Dynamic Scene Graph Generation (DSGG) models how object relations evolve over time in videos. However, existing methods are trained only on annotated object pairs and lack guidance for non-related pairs, making it difficult to identify meaningful relations during inference. In this paper, we propose Relation Scoring Network (RS-Net), a modular framework that scores the contextual importance of object pairs using both spatial interactions and long-range temporal context. RS-Net consists of a spatial context encoder with learnable context tokens and a temporal encoder that aggregates video-level information. The resulting relation scores are integrated into a unified triplet scoring mechanism to enhance relation prediction. RS-Net can be easily integrated into existing DSGG models without architectural changes. Experiments on the Action Genome dataset show that RS-Net consistently improves both Recall and Precision across diverse baselines, with notable gains in mean Recall, highlighting its ability to address the long-tailed distribution of relations. Despite the increased number of parameters, RS-Net maintains competitive efficiency, achieving superior performance over state-of-the-art methods.

AI.tldr: RS-Net is a modular relation-scoring module for DSGG that uses spatial context tokens and a temporal encoder to score object-pair relevance, improving relation prediction without changing existing models.
AI.motivation: Existing DSGG models are trained only on annotated object pairs and ignore non-related pairs; the long-tail distribution of relations makes it hard to identify meaningful relations. There is a need to leverage spatial and temporal context to guide relation scoring.
AI.method: Introduce a spatial context encoder with learnable context tokens and a temporal encoder that aggregates video-level information; compute relation scores and integrate them into a unified triplet scoring mechanism; RS-Net is designed as a plug-in without architectural changes to existing DSGG models.
AI.result: On Action Genome, RS-Net yields consistent improvements in Recall and Precision across diverse baselines, with notable gains in mean Recall, demonstrating better handling of long-tail relations; despite more parameters, it remains competitively efficient and outperforms state-of-the-art methods.
AI.conclusion: RS-Net provides a flexible, effective enhancement for DSGG by incorporating spatial and temporal context to improve relation scoring, while maintaining compatibility with existing models and improving robustness to data imbalance.

title: MirrorLimb: Implementing hand pose acquisition and robot teleoperation based on RealMirror
summary: In this work, we present a PICO-based robot remote operating framework that enables low-cost, real-time acquisition of hand motion and pose data, outperforming mainstream visual tracking and motion capture solutions in terms of cost-effectiveness. The framework is natively compatible with the RealMirror ecosystem, offering ready-to-use functionality for stable and precise robotic trajectory recording within the Isaac simulation environment, thereby facilitating the construction of Vision-Language-Action (VLA) datasets. Additionally, the system supports real-time teleoperation of a variety of end-effector-equipped robots, including dexterous hands and robotic grippers. This work aims to lower the technical barriers in the study of upper-limb robotic manipulation, thereby accelerating advancements in VLA-related research.

AI.tldr: A low-cost, real-time PICO-based framework for hand motion capture and teleoperation, integrated with RealMirror and Isaac, enabling VLA dataset construction and affordable end-effector robotics.
AI.motivation: To reduce cost and technical barriers in capturing precise hand motion for upper-limb robotics and Vision-Language-Action datasets; current tracking/motion capture solutions are often expensive or inaccessible; need real-time remote operation to build robust VLA datasets.
AI.method: Develop a PICO-based remote operating framework native to RealMirror, integrated with the Isaac simulation environment, enabling real-time acquisition of hand motion/pose data; supports teleoperation of a range of end-effector robots (dexterous hands and grippers); designed to facilitate stable, precise robotic trajectory recording for VLA data construction.
AI.result: Outperforms mainstream visual tracking and motion capture in cost-effectiveness; provides ready-to-use functionality for stable and precise trajectory recording within Isaac; enables real-time teleoperation across varied end-effectors; closely aligned with VLA data collection needs.
AI.conclusion: The framework lowers technical barriers in studying upper-limb robotic manipulation and accelerates progress in Vision-Language-Action related research.

title: Macroscopic Emission Modeling of Urban Traffic Using Probe Vehicle Data: A Machine Learning Approach
comment: 3 pages, 5 figures, IEEE Big Data 2024 conference
summary: Urban congestions cause inefficient movement of vehicles and exacerbate greenhouse gas emissions and urban air pollution. Macroscopic emission fundamental diagram (eMFD)captures an orderly relationship among emission and aggregated traffic variables at the network level, allowing for real-time monitoring of region-wide emissions and optimal allocation of travel demand to existing networks, reducing urban congestion and associated emissions. However, empirically derived eMFD models are sparse due to historical data limitation. Leveraging a large-scale and granular traffic and emission data derived from probe vehicles, this study is the first to apply machine learning methods to predict the network wide emission rate to traffic relationship in U.S. urban areas at a large scale. The analysis framework and insights developed in this work generate data-driven eMFDs and a deeper understanding of their location dependence on network, infrastructure, land use, and vehicle characteristics, enabling transportation authorities to measure carbon emissions from urban transport of given travel demand and optimize location specific traffic management and planning decisions to mitigate network-wide emissions.

AI.tldr: First large-scale ML-based prediction of the network-wide emission rate–traffic relationship (eMFD) in U.S. urban areas using probe-vehicle data to derive data-driven eMFDs, enabling real-time emissions monitoring and location-specific traffic management.
AI.motivation: Empirical eMFD models are sparse due to historical data limitations; there is a need for data-driven, location-dependent representations of how emissions relate to aggregate traffic variables to support region-wide monitoring and planning.
AI.method: Leverages large-scale, granular traffic and emission data from probe vehicles and applies machine learning to predict the network-wide emission rate–traffic relationship, resulting in data-driven eMFDs and insights on spatial dependence.
AI.result: Produces data-driven eMFDs and analyzes how location factors (network, infrastructure, land use, vehicle characteristics) influence emissions, enabling measurement of emissions from urban travel demand and optimization of location-specific traffic management.
AI.conclusion: A data-rich ML framework for eMFDs supports real-time, region-wide emission assessment and informed planning to mitigate network-wide emissions through targeted traffic management and land-use decisions.

title: A Research on Business Process Optimisation Model Integrating AI and Big Data Analytics
summary: With the deepening of digital transformation, business process optimisation has become the key to improve the competitiveness of enterprises. This study constructs a business process optimisation model integrating artificial intelligence and big data to achieve intelligent management of the whole life cycle of processes. The model adopts a three-layer architecture incorporating data processing, AI algorithms, and business logic to enable real-time process monitoring and optimization. Through distributed computing and deep learning techniques, the system can handle complex business scenarios while maintaining high performance and reliability. Experimental validation across multiple enterprise scenarios shows that the model shortens process processing time by 42%, improves resource utilisation by 28%, and reduces operating costs by 35%. The system maintained 99.9% availability under high concurrent loads. The research results have important theoretical and practical value for promoting the digital transformation of enterprises, and provide new ideas for improving the operational efficiency of enterprises.

AI.tldr: A three-layer AI/big-data driven BPM model enabling real-time monitoring and optimization, achieving substantial efficiency gains and high availability across enterprise scenarios.
AI.motivation: Digital transformation pressure and the need for intelligent, reliable process management to improve competitiveness.
AI.method: Three-layer architecture (data processing, AI algorithms, business logic) with distributed computing and deep learning for real-time monitoring and optimization; validated across multiple enterprise scenarios.
AI.result: Shortens process processing time by 42%, improves resource utilization by 28%, reduces operating costs by 35%; system maintains 99.9% availability under high concurrent loads.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates both theoretical and practical value for enterprise digital transformation and offers new ideas for improving operational efficiency.

title: Privacy Beyond Pixels: Latent Anonymization for Privacy-Preserving Video Understanding
summary: We introduce a novel formulation of visual privacy preservation for video foundation models that operates entirely in the latent space. While spatio-temporal features learned by foundation models have deepened general understanding of video content, sharing or storing these extracted visual features for downstream tasks inadvertently reveals sensitive personal information like skin color, gender, or clothing. Current privacy preservation methods focus on input-pixel-level anonymization, which requires retraining the entire utility video model and results in task-specific anonymization, making them unsuitable for recent video foundational models. To address these challenges, we introduce a lightweight Anonymizing Adapter Module (AAM) that removes private information from video features while retaining general task utility. AAM can be applied in a plug-and-play fashion to frozen video encoders, minimizing the computational burden of finetuning and re-extracting features. Our framework employs three newly designed training objectives: (1) a clip-level self-supervised privacy objective to reduce mutual information between static clips, (2) a co-training objective to retain utility across seen tasks, and (3) a latent consistency loss for generalization on unseen tasks. Our extensive evaluations demonstrate a significant 35% reduction in privacy leakage while maintaining near-baseline utility performance across various downstream tasks: Action Recognition (Kinetics400, UCF101, HMDB51), Temporal Action Detection (THUMOS14), and Anomaly Detection (UCF-Crime). We also provide an analysis on anonymization for sensitive temporal attribute recognition. Additionally, we propose new protocols for assessing gender bias in action recognition models, showing that our method effectively mitigates such biases and promotes more equitable video understanding.

AI.tldr: A lightweight latent-space privacy adapter (AAM) for video foundation models reduces private information leakage from visual features while preserving task utility, using plug-and-play training objectives.
AI.motivation: Sharing or storing features from video foundation models risks revealing sensitive attributes (skin color, gender, clothing). Pixel-level privacy methods require retraining and are task-specific, unsuitable for foundation models. A latent-space solution offers low overhead and broad applicability.
AI.method: Introduce Anonymizing Adapter Module (AAM) that plugs into frozen video encoders to sanitize features. Train with three objectives: (1) clip-level self-supervised privacy objective to minimize mutual information between static clips, (2) co-training objective to preserve utility across seen tasks, (3) latent consistency loss to generalize to unseen tasks.
AI.result: Achieves ~35% reduction in privacy leakage while maintaining near-baseline utility across Action Recognition (Kinetics400, UCF101, HMDB51), Temporal Action Detection (THUMOS14), and Anomaly Detection (UCF-Crime). Includes analysis on anonymization for sensitive temporal attributes and introduces gender-bias assessment protocols; method mitigates biases.
AI.conclusion: Latent-space anonymization via AAM provides effective privacy protection with minimal utility loss, is plug-and-play with frozen encoders, and supports fairness improvements across tasks and unseen domains.

title: A Shared Control Framework for Mobile Robots with Planning-Level Intention Prediction
summary: In mobile robot shared control, effectively understanding human motion intention is critical for seamless human-robot collaboration. This paper presents a novel shared control framework featuring planning-level intention prediction. A path replanning algorithm is designed to adjust the robot's desired trajectory according to inferred human intentions. To represent future motion intentions, we introduce the concept of an intention domain, which serves as a constraint for path replanning. The intention-domain prediction and path replanning problems are jointly formulated as a Markov Decision Process and solved through deep reinforcement learning. In addition, a Voronoi-based human trajectory generation algorithm is developed, allowing the model to be trained entirely in simulation without human participation or demonstration data. Extensive simulations and real-world user studies demonstrate that the proposed method significantly reduces operator workload and enhances safety, without compromising task efficiency compared with existing assistive teleoperation approaches.

AI.tldr: A planning-level shared-control framework for mobile robots that predicts human intent, replans trajectory under an 'intention domain' constraint, and trains via deep RL with Voronoi-based simulated human trajectories; shows reduced workload and enhanced safety without sacrificing efficiency.
AI.motivation: Enable seamless human-robot collaboration in teleoperation by proactively aligning robot motion with human intent, reducing operator workload and improving safety.
AI.method: Jointly formulate intention-domain prediction and path replanning as an MDP; use deep reinforcement learning to solve; introduce intention domain as a constraint; develop Voronoi-based human trajectory generation for simulation-based training.
AI.result: Extensive simulations and real-world user studies show significant reduction in operator workload and enhanced safety, with no compromise on task efficiency, outperforming existing assistive teleoperation approaches.
AI.conclusion: The approach demonstrates that planning-level intention prediction integrated with constraint-based replanning and sim-to-real training can substantially improve performance in mobile robot shared control; future work could extend to other domains and refine the intention domain concept.

title: Gromov-Wasserstein Graph Coarsening
summary: We study the problem of graph coarsening within the Gromov-Wasserstein geometry. Specifically, we propose two algorithms that leverage a novel representation of the distortion induced by merging pairs of nodes. The first method, termed Greedy Pair Coarsening (GPC), iteratively merges pairs of nodes that locally minimize a measure of distortion until the desired size is achieved. The second method, termed $k$-means Greedy Pair Coarsening (KGPC), leverages clustering based on pairwise distortion metrics to directly merge clusters of nodes. We provide conditions guaranteeing optimal coarsening for our methods and validate their performance on six large-scale datasets and a downstream clustering task. Results show that the proposed methods outperform existing approaches on a wide range of parameters and scenarios.

AI.tldr: Proposes two GW-based graph coarsening algorithms (GPC and KGPC) that use a distortion-aware merging strategy; provides conditions for optimal coarsening; validated on six large-scale datasets and a clustering task; shows empirical improvements over existing methods.
AI.motivation: Coarsening graphs under the Gromov-Wasserstein geometry is essential for scalable GW computations. Existing methods lack a distortion-aware merging framework; this work introduces a principled distortion representation to guide node merging and clustering during coarsening.
AI.method: Introduce a novel representation of the distortion caused by merging node pairs. GPC greedily merges pairs that locally minimize distortion until the desired size is reached. KGPC uses clustering based on pairwise distortion metrics to merge clusters directly. The authors also provide conditions under which optimal coarsening is guaranteed.
AI.result: Empirical validation on six large-scale datasets and a downstream clustering task shows that GPC and KGPC outperform existing coarsening approaches across a wide range of parameters and scenarios.
AI.conclusion: The proposed distortion-aware coarsening methods offer theoretically grounded guarantees and strong empirical performance for graph coarsening in the Gromov-Wasserstein framework, enabling scalable analysis of large graphs.

title: AlphaCast: A Human Wisdom-LLM Intelligence Co-Reasoning Framework for Interactive Time Series Forecasting
summary: Time series forecasting plays a critical role in high-stakes domains such as energy, healthcare, and climate. Although recent advances have improved accuracy, most approaches still treat forecasting as a static one-time mapping task, lacking the interaction, reasoning, and adaptability of human experts. This gap limits their usefulness in complex real-world environments. To address this, we propose AlphaCast, a human wisdom-large language model (LLM) intelligence co-reasoning framework that redefines forecasting as an interactive process. The key idea is to enable step-by-step collaboration between human wisdom and LLM intelligence to jointly prepare, generate, and verify forecasts. The framework consists of two stages: (1) automated prediction preparation, where AlphaCast builds a multi-source cognitive foundation comprising a feature set that captures key statistics and time patterns, a domain knowledge base distilled from corpora and historical series, a contextual repository that stores rich information for each time window, and a case base that retrieves optimal strategies via pattern clustering and matching; and (2) generative reasoning and reflective optimization, where AlphaCast integrates statistical temporal features, prior knowledge, contextual information, and forecasting strategies, triggering a meta-reasoning loop for continuous self-correction and strategy refinement. Extensive experiments on short- and long-term datasets show that AlphaCast consistently outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in predictive accuracy. Code is available at this repository: https://github.com/SkyeGT/AlphaCast_Official .

AI.tldr: AlphaCast reframes forecasting as interactive human-LLM co-reasoning, using a two-stage framework (prediction preparation and generative reasoning with meta-reasoning) to improve accuracy, showing strong results on short- and long-term datasets; code available.
AI.motivation: Address limitations of static one-shot forecasting and lack of interaction/adaptability by incorporating human wisdom and continual, multi-source reasoning.
AI.method: Two-stage framework: stage 1 automated prediction preparation builds a multi-source cognitive foundation (features, domain knowledge base from corpora and history, contextual repository, case base); stage 2 generative reasoning integrates features, prior knowledge, context, and strategies within a meta-reasoning loop for self-correction and strategy refinement.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show AlphaCast consistently outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in predictive accuracy across short- and long-term datasets.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates promise of interactive human-LLM co-reasoning for forecasting; potential for practical impact in high-stakes domains; code released.

title: Rethinking generative image pretraining: How far are we from scaling up next-pixel prediction?
summary: This paper investigates the scaling properties of autoregressive next-pixel prediction, a simple, end-to-end yet under-explored framework for unified vision models. Starting with images at resolutions of 32x32, we train a family of Transformers using IsoFlops profiles across compute budgets up to 7e19 FLOPs and evaluate three distinct target metrics: next-pixel prediction objective, ImageNet classification accuracy, and generation quality measured by Fr'echet Distance. First, optimal scaling strategy is critically task-dependent. At a fixed 32x32 resolution alone, the optimal scaling properties for image classification and image generation diverge, where generation optimal setup requires the data size grow three to five times faster than for the classification optimal setup. Second, as image resolution increases, the optimal scaling strategy indicates that the model size must grow much faster than data size. Surprisingly, by projecting our findings, we discover that the primary bottleneck is compute rather than the amount of training data. As compute continues to grow four to five times annually, we forecast the feasibility of pixel-by-pixel modeling of images within the next five years.

AI.tldr: Scaling laws for autoregressive pixel models are highly task-dependent: at 32x32, generation benefits more from data scaling than classification, and as resolution grows, model size must scale faster than data. Compute is the bottleneck, implying pixel-by-pixel vision modeling could be feasible within ~5 years given current compute growth.
AI.motivation: To understand how scaling data, model size, and compute interact for pixel-by-pixel autoregressive vision models, across tasks (next-pixel objective, ImageNet classification, and generation quality) to guide unified vision modeling.
AI.method: Train a family of Transformers using IsoFlops compute profiles across budgets up to 7e19 FLOPs on 32x32 images and evaluate three objectives: next-pixel prediction, ImageNet accuracy, and Fréchet Distance for generation quality.
AI.result: Key findings: (1) Optimal scaling is task-dependent; at fixed 32x32 resolution, the data scaling required for generation is 3–5x faster than for classification. (2) As resolution increases, optimal scaling shifts toward much faster growth of model size relative to data size. (3) The primary bottleneck is compute, not data; given typical compute growth of 4–5x per year, pixel-by-pixel image modeling could become feasible within five years.
AI.conclusion: Pixel-by-pixel autoregressive vision models appear increasingly feasible as compute grows, but scaling strategies must be tailored to the target task (generation vs classification). Compute bottlenecks, not data, will largely drive practical scaling and feasibility.

title: Expand Your SCOPE: Semantic Cognition over Potential-Based Exploration for Embodied Visual Navigation
summary: Embodied visual navigation remains a challenging task, as agents must explore unknown environments with limited knowledge. Existing zero-shot studies have shown that incorporating memory mechanisms to support goal-directed behavior can improve long-horizon planning performance. However, they overlook visual frontier boundaries, which fundamentally dictate future trajectories and observations, and fall short of inferring the relationship between partial visual observations and navigation goals. In this paper, we propose Semantic Cognition Over Potential-based Exploration (SCOPE), a zero-shot framework that explicitly leverages frontier information to drive potential-based exploration, enabling more informed and goal-relevant decisions. SCOPE estimates exploration potential with a Vision-Language Model and organizes it into a spatio-temporal potential graph, capturing boundary dynamics to support long-horizon planning. In addition, SCOPE incorporates a self-reconsideration mechanism that revisits and refines prior decisions, enhancing reliability and reducing overconfident errors. Experimental results on two diverse embodied navigation tasks show that SCOPE outperforms state-of-the-art baselines by 4.6\% in accuracy. Further analysis demonstrates that its core components lead to improved calibration, stronger generalization, and higher decision quality.

AI.tldr: SCOPE introduces frontier-aware, potential-based exploration for zero-shot embodied navigation using a Vision-Language Model, with a self-reconsideration module; it outperforms baselines and improves calibration/generalization.
AI.motivation: Existing zero-shot navigation methods rely on memory but ignore visual frontier boundaries and the relationship between partial observations and goals, limiting long-horizon planning in unknown environments.
AI.method: SCOPE estimates exploration potential via a Vision-Language Model, builds a spatio-temporal potential graph to capture frontier dynamics, and incorporates a self-reconsideration mechanism to revisit/refine prior decisions.
AI.result: On two diverse embodied navigation tasks, SCOPE outperforms state-of-the-art baselines by 4.6% in accuracy; ablations show improved calibration, stronger generalization, and higher decision quality.
AI.conclusion: By explicitly leveraging frontier information and adding self-reconsideration, SCOPE enables more informed, reliable, and goal-relevant zero-shot navigation in unknown environments.

title: Hey Pentti, We Did (More of) It!: A Vector-Symbolic Lisp With Residue Arithmetic
comment: 11 pages, 1 figure, conference paper at IJCNN 2025 Rome
summary: Using Frequency-domain Holographic Reduced Representations (FHRRs), we extend a Vector-Symbolic Architecture (VSA) encoding of Lisp 1.5 with primitives for arithmetic operations using Residue Hyperdimensional Computing (RHC). Encoding a Turing-complete syntax over a high-dimensional vector space increases the expressivity of neural network states, enabling network states to contain arbitrarily structured representations that are inherently interpretable. We discuss the potential applications of the VSA encoding in machine learning tasks, as well as the importance of encoding structured representations and designing neural networks whose behavior is sensitive to the structure of their representations in virtue of attaining more general intelligent agents than exist at present.

AI.tldr: Proposes a high-dimensional VSA framework (FHRR-based) that encodes Lisp 1.5 with arithmetic primitives via Residue Hyperdimensional Computing, enabling Turing-complete, structured representations inside neural states to improve interpretability and generality.
AI.motivation: To enhance neural networks with symbolic, structured representations, enabling more interpretable states and stepping toward more general intelligent agents by integrating Turing-complete syntax within a high-dimensional vector space.
AI.method: Extend a Vector-Symbolic Architecture (VSA) using Frequency-domain Holographic Reduced Representations (FHRRs) to encode Lisp 1.5 with arithmetic primitives via Residue Hyperdimensional Computing (RHC), achieving a Turing-complete syntax over high-dimensional vectors.
AI.result: Neural states can embed arbitrarily structured, interpretable representations; the framework increases expressivity and supports structured computation within neural networks.
AI.conclusion: Encoding structured symbolic representations in high-dimensional neural states may yield more capable, structure-sensitive agents, with broad potential applications in machine learning tasks and the design of general intelligent systems.

title: Heterogeneous Graph Neural Networks for Assumption-Based Argumentation
comment: Accepted to AAAI2026. Version with Appendix
summary: Assumption-Based Argumentation (ABA) is a powerful structured argumentation formalism, but exact computation of extensions under stable semantics is intractable for large frameworks. We present the first Graph Neural Network (GNN) approach to approximate credulous acceptance in ABA. To leverage GNNs, we model ABA frameworks via a dependency graph representation encoding assumptions, claims and rules as nodes, with heterogeneous edge labels distinguishing support, derive and attack relations. We propose two GNN architectures - ABAGCN and ABAGAT - that stack residual heterogeneous convolution or attention layers, respectively, to learn node embeddings. Our models are trained on the ICCMA 2023 benchmark, augmented with synthetic ABAFs, with hyperparameters optimised via Bayesian search. Empirically, both ABAGCN and ABAGAT outperform a state-of-the-art GNN baseline that we adapt from the abstract argumentation literature, achieving a node-level F1 score of up to 0.71 on the ICCMA instances. Finally, we develop a sound polynomial time extension-reconstruction algorithm driven by our predictor: it reconstructs stable extensions with F1 above 0.85 on small ABAFs and maintains an F1 of about 0.58 on large frameworks. Our work opens new avenues for scalable approximate reasoning in structured argumentation.

AI.tldr: First GNN-based approach to approximate credulous acceptance in assumption-based argumentation (ABA) using a heterogeneous dependency-graph representation; introduces two architectures (ABAGCN and ABAGAT); demonstrates strong node-level performance (F1 up to 0.71) on ICCMA with a sound polynomial-time extension-reconstruction algorithm (F1 > 0.85 on small ABAFs, ~0.58 on large); shows potential for scalable approximate reasoning in ABA.
AI.motivation: Exact computation of extensions under stable semantics is intractable for large ABA frameworks. A data-driven, scalable approximation is needed. Graph Neural Networks offer a natural way to learn from structured argumentation graphs, and a dependency-graph encoding can capture assumptions, claims, rules, as well as support, derive, and attack relations.
AI.method: Represent ABA frameworks as a dependency graph with nodes for assumptions, claims, and rules and heterogeneous edges for support, derivation, and attack relations. Develop ABAGCN (residual heterogeneous convolution) and ABAGAT (residual heterogeneous attention) to learn node embeddings. Train on ICCMA 2023 benchmark augmented with synthetic ABAFs; hyperparameters tuned via Bayesian search. Develop a polynomial-time extension-reconstruction algorithm guided by the predictor to reconstruct stable extensions.
AI.result: ABAGCN and ABAGAT outperform a state-of-the-art GNN baseline adapted from abstract argumentation literature, achieving node-level F1 up to 0.71 on ICCMA instances. The extension-reconstruction algorithm achieves F1 > 0.85 on small ABAFs and ~0.58 on large frameworks, indicating scalable approximate reasoning in ABA.
AI.conclusion: This work demonstrates the viability of GNN-based approximations for ABA reasoning, enabling scalable, accurate credulous acceptance in larger frameworks and opening avenues for practical structured argumentation analytics.

title: Harnessing Diffusion-Generated Synthetic Images for Fair Image Classification
summary: Image classification systems often inherit biases from uneven group representation in training data. For example, in face datasets for hair color classification, blond hair may be disproportionately associated with females, reinforcing stereotypes. A recent approach leverages the Stable Diffusion model to generate balanced training data, but these models often struggle to preserve the original data distribution. In this work, we explore multiple diffusion-finetuning techniques, e.g., LoRA and DreamBooth, to generate images that more accurately represent each training group by learning directly from their samples. Additionally, in order to prevent a single DreamBooth model from being overwhelmed by excessive intra-group variations, we explore a technique of clustering images within each group and train a DreamBooth model per cluster. These models are then used to generate group-balanced data for pretraining, followed by fine-tuning on real data. Experiments on multiple benchmarks demonstrate that the studied finetuning approaches outperform vanilla Stable Diffusion on average and achieve results comparable to SOTA debiasing techniques like Group-DRO, while surpassing them as the dataset bias severity increases.

AI.tldr: Diffusion-model finetuning with per-group, per-cluster DreamBooth-like models (and LoRA) to generate balanced training data, improving debiasing in image classification while preserving data distribution; matches or exceeds state-of-the-art baselines, especially as bias severity rises.
AI.motivation: Bias in image classification arises from uneven group representation in training data. Traditional data balancing may distort the original distribution; this work aims to balance groups while preserving real-world distribution by learning from group-specific samples and preventing collapse from intra-group variation.
AI.method: Apply diffusion-finetuning techniques (e.g., LoRA, DreamBooth) to learn from samples of each group. Within each group, cluster images and train a separate DreamBooth model per cluster. Use these models to generate group-balanced data for pretraining, then fine-tune on real data.
AI.result: On multiple benchmarks, the proposed finetuning approaches outperform vanilla Stable Diffusion and achieve results comparable to state-of-the-art debiasing methods like Group-DRO; the advantage over Group-DRO increases as dataset bias severity grows.
AI.conclusion: Per-group, per-cluster diffusion-finetuning can generate balanced data that preserves the original distribution and improves debiasing performance, offering a scalable approach that remains competitive with or surpasses existing debiasing techniques under higher bias.

title: Think, Remember, Navigate: Zero-Shot Object-Goal Navigation with VLM-Powered Reasoning
summary: While Vision-Language Models (VLMs) are set to transform robotic navigation, existing methods often underutilize their reasoning capabilities. To unlock the full potential of VLMs in robotics, we shift their role from passive observers to active strategists in the navigation process. Our framework outsources high-level planning to a VLM, which leverages its contextual understanding to guide a frontier-based exploration agent. This intelligent guidance is achieved through a trio of techniques: structured chain-of-thought prompting that elicits logical, step-by-step reasoning; dynamic inclusion of the agent's recent action history to prevent getting stuck in loops; and a novel capability that enables the VLM to interpret top-down obstacle maps alongside first-person views, thereby enhancing spatial awareness. When tested on challenging benchmarks like HM3D, Gibson, and MP3D, this method produces exceptionally direct and logical trajectories, marking a substantial improvement in navigation efficiency over existing approaches and charting a path toward more capable embodied agents.

AI.tldr: A framework where a Vision-Language Model acts as the high-level planner guiding a frontier-based exploration agent through structured reasoning, action-history, and joint top-down maps with first-person views, achieving more direct, efficient trajectories on HM3D, Gibson, and MP3D.
AI.motivation: Current VLMs are underutilized in robotics navigation; unlocking their reasoning capabilities can make embodied agents more efficient, robust, and capable by using high-level strategic planning.
AI.method: Three components: (1) structured chain-of-thought prompting to elicit step-by-step reasoning, (2) dynamic inclusion of the agent's recent action history to avoid looping and dead-ends, (3) a novel capability for the VLM to interpret top-down obstacle maps alongside first-person views, enabling improved spatial awareness; integration with a frontier-based exploration agent.
AI.result: The approach yields more direct and logically coherent trajectories and substantially improves navigation efficiency compared with existing approaches on challenging benchmarks such as HM3D, Gibson, and MP3D.
AI.conclusion: Vision-Language Models can be repurposed as active strategists in embodied navigation, enabling more efficient and capable agents by combining structured reasoning, memory-aware planning, and cross-view spatial understanding.

title: A Generalized Bias-Variance Decomposition for Bregman Divergences
comment: Extended version of notes previously posted here: http://davidpfau.com/assets/generalized_bvd_proof.pdf
summary: The bias-variance decomposition is a central result in statistics and machine learning, but is typically presented only for the squared error. We present a generalization of the bias-variance decomposition where the prediction error is a Bregman divergence, which is relevant to maximum likelihood estimation with exponential families. While the result is already known, there was not previously a clear, standalone derivation, so we provide one for pedagogical purposes. A version of this note previously appeared on the author's personal website without context. Here we provide additional discussion and references to the relevant prior literature.

AI.tldr: Generalizes bias-variance to Bregman divergences with a pedagogical derivation.
AI.motivation: Extend a central decomposition beyond squared error to divergences arising in MLE/exponential families; provide a standalone derivation and literature context.
AI.method: Derives a bias-variance-like decomposition for the expected Bregman divergence between the true response and the predictor, clarifying terms and showing how standard squared-error decomposition is a special case; includes discussion of prior work and a pedagogical note.
AI.result: A general decomposition theorem for Bregman divergences; decomposition into components akin to bias and variance plus a diversification term; clarifies the relationship to MLE/exp-family losses; yields a clear, standalone derivation.
AI.conclusion: Provides a clear, pedagogical derivation of the generalized bias-variance decomposition for Bregman divergences, situates it in existing literature, and offers references.

title: AI Founding Fathers: A Case Study of GIS Search in Multi-Agent Pipelines
comment: 9 pages, 3 figures. Code and data available at https://github.com/alvco/Founding_Fathers_AI
summary: Although Large Language Models (LLMs) show exceptional fluency, efforts persist to extract stronger reasoning capabilities from them. Drawing on search-based interpretations of LLM computation, this paper advances a systematic framework for understanding LLM reasoning and optimization. Namely, that enhancing reasoning is best achieved by structuring a multi-agent pipeline to ensure a traversal of the search space in a gradual, incremental, and sequential (GIS) manner. Stated succinctly, high-quality reasoning is a controlled, incremental search. To test this framework, we investigate the efficacy of recursive refinement (RR)--an iterative process of self-criticism, adversarial stress-testing, and integrating critical feedback--as a practical method for implementing GIS search. We designed an experiment comparing a simple, linear pipeline against a complex, explicitly structured pipeline leveraging a recursive refinement layer. The multi-agent models were constructed to reflect the historical personas of three US Founding Fathers (Hamilton, Jefferson, and Madison) using RAG-powered corpora and were prompted to generate responses to three contemporary political issues. Model performance was evaluated using a two-tiered approach: a quantitative score from an LLM arbiter agent and qualitative human judgment. Our results revealed that the complex model consistently outperformed the simple model across all nine test cases with an average arbiter-outputted score of 88.3 versus 71.7. The complex model's arguments were superior in analytical depth, structural nuance, and strategic framing. We conclude that recursive refinement is a robust architectural feature for enhancing LLM reasoning via GIS search.

AI.tldr: Recursive refinement with a GIS-style multi-agent pipeline improves LLM reasoning; a complex, structured pipeline using historical personas outperforms a simple linear pipeline.
AI.motivation: To systematically understand and enhance LLM reasoning by shaping computation as a controlled, incremental search (GIS) through iterative self-critique and feedback.
AI.method: Compare a simple linear pipeline against a complex GIS-structured pipeline with a recursive refinement layer, embodied by multi-agent RAG using three historical personas (Hamilton, Jefferson, Madison); evaluate on three contemporary issues across nine test cases using a two-tier evaluation (LLM arbiter score and human judgments).
AI.result: The complex model consistently outperformed the simple model across all nine test cases, with an average arbiter score of 88.3 versus 71.7; resulting in superior analytical depth, structural nuance, and strategic framing.
AI.conclusion: Recursive refinement is a robust architectural feature for enhancing LLM reasoning via a GIS-based search framework.

title: WiCV at CVPR 2025: The Women in Computer Vision Workshop
summary: The Women in Computer Vision Workshop (WiCV@CVPR 2025) was held in conjunction with the IEEE/CVF Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition (CVPR 2025) in Nashville, Tennessee, United States. This report presents an overview of the workshop program, participation statistics, mentorship outcomes, and historical trends from previous WiCV editions. The goal is to document the impact and evolution of WiCV as a reference for future editions and for other initiatives aimed at advancing diversity, equity, and inclusion within the AI and computer vision communities. WiCV@CVPR 2025 marked the 16th edition of this long-standing event dedicated to increasing the visibility, inclusion, and professional growth of women and underrepresented minorities in the computer vision community. This year's workshop featured 14 accepted papers in the CVPR Workshop Proceedings out of 32 full-paper submissions. Five of these were selected for oral presentations, while all 14 were also presented as posters, along with 36 extended abstract posters accepted from 62 short-paper submissions, which are not included in the proceedings. The mentoring program matched 80 mentees with 37 mentors from both academia and industry. The 2025 edition attracted over 100 onsite participants, fostering rich technical and networking interactions across all career stages. Supported by 10 sponsors and approximately $44,000 USD in travel grants and diversity awards, WiCV continued its mission to empower emerging researchers and amplify diverse voices in computer vision.

AI.tldr: WiCV@CVPR 2025 in Nashville marks the 16th edition, showcasing strong engagement and ongoing DEI impact in computer vision: 14 accepted papers in CVPR Workshop Proceedings from 32 submissions (5 oral), 14 poster presentations; 36 extended-abstract posters from 62 short-paper submissions (not in proceedings); 80 mentee–mentor pairs; 100+ onsite participants; 10 sponsors; ~$44k in travel grants and diversity awards.
AI.motivation: Document the impact, evolution, and ongoing relevance of WiCV as a reference for future editions and for broader DEI initiatives in AI and computer vision communities.
AI.method: Descriptive report aggregating workshop program details, participation statistics, mentorship outcomes, and historical trends across WiCV editions, using counts of submissions, acceptances, presentations, mentorship pairings, attendance, and funding.
AI.result: Reported outcomes include: 14 CVPR Workshop Proceedings papers (32 submissions; 14 accepted; 5 oral); 14 poster presentations; 36 extended-abstract posters (from 62 short-paper submissions, not in proceedings); 80 mentees paired with 37 mentors; 100+ onsite participants; 10 sponsors; ~$44k in travel grants and diversity awards.
AI.conclusion: WiCV 2025 reinforces its mission to empower emerging researchers and amplify diverse voices, providing a reference point for future editions and DEI initiatives in computer vision and AI.

title: UniMM-V2X: MoE-Enhanced Multi-Level Fusion for End-to-End Cooperative Autonomous Driving
summary: Autonomous driving holds transformative potential but remains fundamentally constrained by the limited perception and isolated decision-making with standalone intelligence. While recent multi-agent approaches introduce cooperation, they often focus merely on perception-level tasks, overlooking the alignment with downstream planning and control, or fall short in leveraging the full capacity of the recent emerging end-to-end autonomous driving. In this paper, we present UniMM-V2X, a novel end-to-end multi-agent framework that enables hierarchical cooperation across perception, prediction, and planning. At the core of our framework is a multi-level fusion strategy that unifies perception and prediction cooperation, allowing agents to share queries and reason cooperatively for consistent and safe decision-making. To adapt to diverse downstream tasks and further enhance the quality of multi-level fusion, we incorporate a Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) architecture to dynamically enhance the BEV representations. We further extend MoE into the decoder to better capture diverse motion patterns. Extensive experiments on the DAIR-V2X dataset demonstrate our approach achieves state-of-the-art (SOTA) performance with a 39.7% improvement in perception accuracy, a 7.2% reduction in prediction error, and a 33.2% improvement in planning performance compared with UniV2X, showcasing the strength of our MoE-enhanced multi-level cooperative paradigm.

AI.tldr: UniMM-V2X enables end-to-end multi-agent cooperation across perception, prediction, and planning with hierarchical fusion and MoE-enhanced BEV representations, achieving SOTA on DAIR-V2X.
AI.motivation: Autonomous driving is hindered by limited perception and isolated decision-making; existing multi-agent work often focuses on perception or lacks alignment with downstream planning; there is a need for end-to-end, multi-level cooperation that leverages Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) to adapt representations for diverse tasks.
AI.method: Proposes UniMM-V2X, an end-to-end multi-agent framework with multi-level fusion that unifies perception and prediction cooperation via shared queries and cooperative reasoning for consistent planning; employs a Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) architecture to dynamically enhance BEV representations and extends MoE into the decoder to model diverse motion patterns; evaluated on the DAIR-V2X dataset.
AI.result: Achieves state-of-the-art performance: 39.7% improvement in perception accuracy, 7.2% reduction in prediction error, and 33.2% improvement in planning performance compared with UniV2X.
AI.conclusion: An MoE-enhanced, end-to-end multi-agent framework with hierarchical cooperation across perception, prediction, and planning yields substantial performance gains and better alignment with downstream control tasks.

title: BayesQ: Uncertainty-Guided Bayesian Quantization
summary: We present BayesQ, an uncertainty-guided post-training quantization framework that is the first to optimize quantization under the posterior expected loss. BayesQ fits a lightweight Gaussian posterior over weights (diagonal Laplace by default; optional K-FAC/low-rank), whitens by the posterior covariance, designs codebooks to minimize posterior-expected distortion, and allocates mixed precision via a greedy knapsack that maximizes marginal expected-loss reduction per bit under a global budget. For scalar quantizers, posterior-expected MSE yields closed-form tables; task-aware proxies are handled by short Monte Carlo on a small calibration set. An optional calibration-only distillation aligns the quantized model with the posterior predictive teacher. At matched average bits/weight of 3.0/3.5/4.0, BayesQ improves over strong PTQ baselines on ResNet-50 (ImageNet) and BERT-base (GLUE) e.g., vs. GPTQ by $+1.5/+0.7/+0.3$ top-1 percentage points on RN50 and $+1.1/+0.4/+0.2$ GLUE points on BERT, while requiring one-time preprocessing comparable to a GPTQ pass. BayesQ reframes low-bit quantization as uncertainty-aware risk minimization in a practical, post-training pipeline.

AI.tldr: BayesQ is a Bayesian, uncertainty-guided post-training quantization method that optimizes quantization under a posterior expected loss, using a lightweight Gaussian weight posterior, posterior whitening, optimized codebooks, and mixed-precision allocation via a greedy knapsack; it achieves state-of-the-art gains at low bitrates on ResNet-50 and BERT-base with preprocessing comparable to GPTQ.
AI.motivation: To reduce accuracy loss in post-training quantization by explicitly modeling weight uncertainty and optimizing a posterior-expected loss under bit-budget constraints, enabling effective mixed-precision quantization with efficient calibration.
AI.method: Fit a diagonal-Laplace (default) Gaussian posterior over weights (K-FAC/low-rank as options); whiten by posterior covariance; design codebooks to minimize posterior-expected distortion; allocate mixed precision by greedy knapsack maximizing marginal expected loss reduction per bit under a global budget; for scalar quantizers, derive closed-form posterior-expected MSE tables; use short Monte Carlo on a small calibration set for task-aware proxies; optional calibration-only distillation aligns quantized model with posterior predictive teacher.
AI.result: At matched average bits/weight of 3.0/3.5/4.0, BayesQ outperforms strong PTQ baselines (e.g., GPTQ) on ResNet-50 (ImageNet) and BERT-base (GLUE) with gains of +1.5/+0.7/+0.3 top-1 points on RN50 and +1.1/+0.4/+0.2 GLUE points, with one-time preprocessing comparable to a GPTQ pass.
AI.conclusion: BayesQ reframes low-bit quantization as uncertainty-aware risk minimization within a practical post-training pipeline.

title: Solving a Million-Step LLM Task with Zero Errors
comment: Main paper: 14 pages, 29 pages with references and appendix
summary: LLMs have achieved remarkable breakthroughs in reasoning, insights, and tool use, but chaining these abilities into extended processes at the scale of those routinely executed by humans, organizations, and societies has remained out of reach. The models have a persistent error rate that prevents scale-up: for instance, recent experiments in the Towers of Hanoi benchmark domain showed that the process inevitably becomes derailed after at most a few hundred steps. Thus, although LLM research is often still benchmarked on tasks with relatively few dependent logical steps, there is increasing attention on the ability (or inability) of LLMs to perform long range tasks. This paper describes MAKER, the first system that successfully solves a task with over one million LLM steps with zero errors, and, in principle, scales far beyond this level. The approach relies on an extreme decomposition of a task into subtasks, each of which can be tackled by focused microagents. The high level of modularity resulting from the decomposition allows error correction to be applied at each step through an efficient multi-agent voting scheme. This combination of extreme decomposition and error correction makes scaling possible. Thus, the results suggest that instead of relying on continual improvement of current LLMs, massively decomposed agentic processes (MDAPs) may provide a way to efficiently solve problems at the level of organizations and societies.

AI.tldr: MAKER demonstrates zero-error scaling for extremely long LLM-driven tasks (over one million steps) by aggressively decomposing problems into microagents and using multic-agent voting to correct errors at each step, enabling scalable reasoning beyond current LLM limits.
AI.motivation: Current LLMs suffer from persistent errors that prevent long-horizon, scalable reasoning. Evidence (e.g., Towers of Hanoi experiments) shows derailment after hundreds of steps. There is a need for architectures that enable organization- or society-scale problem solving without awaiting incremental improvements in LLMs.
AI.method: Extremely decompose a task into subtasks. Employ focused microagents to tackle each subtask. Implement an efficient multi-agent voting scheme to apply error correction at every step, enabling high modularity and robust long-horizon execution (Massively Decomposed Agentic Processes, MDAPs).
AI.result: The system solves tasks with over one million LLM steps with zero errors, demonstrating unprecedented scale and suggesting the approach can extend far beyond current capabilities.
AI.conclusion: Massively decomposed agentic processes (MDAPs) offer a viable path to scaling LLM-based reasoning to organizational and societal levels, via extreme task decomposition and per-step error correction, rather than solely relying on improving base LLMs.

title: Adaptive graph Kolmogorov-Arnold network for 3D human pose estimation
summary: Graph convolutional network (GCN)-based methods have shown strong performance in 3D human pose estimation by leveraging the natural graph structure of the human skeleton. However, their local receptive field limits their ability to capture long-range dependencies essential for handling occlusions and depth ambiguities. They also exhibit spectral bias, which prioritizes low-frequency components while struggling to model high-frequency details. In this paper, we introduce PoseKAN, an adaptive graph Kolmogorov-Arnold Network (KAN), framework that extends KANs to graph-based learning for 2D-to-3D pose lifting from a single image. Unlike GCNs that use fixed activation functions, KANs employ learnable functions on graph edges, allowing data-driven, adaptive feature transformations. This enhances the model's adaptability and expressiveness, making it more expressive in learning complex pose variations. Our model employs multi-hop feature aggregation, ensuring the body joints can leverage information from both local and distant neighbors, leading to improved spatial awareness. It also incorporates residual PoseKAN blocks for deeper feature refinement, and a global response normalization for improved feature selectivity and contrast. Extensive experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate the competitive performance of our model against state-of-the-art methods.

AI.tldr: PoseKAN extends Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks to graph-based 2D-to-3D pose lifting by using learnable edge functions and multi-hop aggregation, addressing GCN limitations and achieving competitive results on benchmarks.
AI.motivation: GCN-based 3D pose estimation is hindered by small local receptive fields and spectral bias toward low-frequency components, which restricts modeling long-range dependencies under occlusions and depth ambiguities.
AI.method: Adapt Kolmogorov-Arnold Network (KAN) to graphs (PoseKAN) with learnable edge functions for adaptive feature transformation, multi-hop feature aggregation, residual PoseKAN blocks, and global response normalization for robust 2D-to-3D pose lifting from a single image.
AI.result: Experiments on benchmark datasets show competitive performance against state-of-the-art methods, indicating improved expressiveness and spatial awareness.
AI.conclusion: Adaptive graph KAN enhances expressiveness and spatial awareness for 2D-to-3D pose lifting, mitigating limitations of traditional GCNs and enabling better modeling of complex pose variations.

title: A Quantum Tunneling and Bio-Phototactic Driven Enhanced Dwarf Mongoose Optimizer for UAV Trajectory Planning and Engineering Problem
summary: With the widespread adoption of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV), effective path planning has become increasingly important. Although traditional search methods have been extensively applied, metaheuristic algorithms have gained popularity due to their efficiency and problem-specific heuristics. However, challenges such as premature convergence and lack of solution diversity still hinder their performance in complex scenarios. To address these issues, this paper proposes an Enhanced Multi-Strategy Dwarf Mongoose Optimization (EDMO) algorithm, tailored for three-dimensional UAV trajectory planning in dynamic and obstacle-rich environments. EDMO integrates three novel strategies: (1) a Dynamic Quantum Tunneling Optimization Strategy (DQTOS) to enable particles to probabilistically escape local optima; (2) a Bio-phototactic Dynamic Focusing Search Strategy (BDFSS) inspired by microbial phototaxis for adaptive local refinement; and (3) an Orthogonal Lens Opposition-Based Learning (OLOBL) strategy to enhance global exploration through structured dimensional recombination. EDMO is benchmarked on 39 standard test functions from CEC2017 and CEC2020, outperforming 14 advanced algorithms in convergence speed, robustness, and optimization accuracy. Furthermore, real-world validations on UAV three-dimensional path planning and three engineering design tasks confirm its practical applicability and effectiveness in field robotics missions requiring intelligent, adaptive, and time-efficient planning.

AI.tldr: A novel Enhanced Multi-Strategy Dwarf Mongoose Optimization (EDMO) for 3D UAV trajectory planning that combines DQTOS, BDFSS, and OLOBL; it outperforms peers on CEC benchmarks and proves effective in real UAV path planning and engineering design tasks.
AI.motivation: To overcome premature convergence and limited solution diversity in traditional metaheuristics and to enable robust, time-efficient 3D UAV trajectory planning in dynamic, obstacle-rich environments.
AI.method: EDMO integrates three strategies: (1) Dynamic Quantum Tunneling Optimization Strategy (DQTOS) to probabilistically escape local optima; (2) Bio-phototactic Dynamic Focusing Search Strategy (BDFSS), inspired by microbial phototaxis, for adaptive local refinement; and (3) Orthogonal Lens Opposition-Based Learning (OLOBL) to enhance global exploration via structured dimensional recombination. It is evaluated on 39 CEC2017/2020 benchmarks and validated on real UAV 3D path planning and three engineering design tasks.
AI.result: Outperformed 14 advanced algorithms in convergence speed, robustness, and optimization accuracy on benchmark tests; demonstrated practical applicability in field UAV trajectory planning and other design tasks.
AI.conclusion: EDMO is an effective, adaptive, time-efficient metaheuristic for complex, dynamic optimization, with strong potential for broader field robotics and engineering optimization applications.

title: Physics-Informed Machine Learning for Characterizing System Stability
summary: In the design and operation of complex dynamical systems, it is essential to ensure that all state trajectories of the dynamical system converge to a desired equilibrium within a guaranteed stability region. Yet, for many practical systems -- especially in aerospace -- this region cannot be determined a priori and is often challenging to compute. One of the most common methods for computing the stability region is to identify a Lyapunov function. A Lyapunov function is a positive function whose time derivative along system trajectories is non-positive, which provides a sufficient condition for stability and characterizes an estimated stability region. However, existing methods of characterizing a stability region via a Lyapunov function often rely on explicit knowledge of the system governing equations. In this work, we present a new physics-informed machine learning method of characterizing an estimated stability region by inferring a Lyapunov function from system trajectory data that treats the dynamical system as a black box and does not require explicit knowledge of the system governing equations. In our presented Lyapunov function Inference method (LyapInf), we propose a quadratic form for the unknown Lyapunov function and fit the unknown quadratic operator to system trajectory data by minimizing the average residual of the Zubov equation, a first-order partial differential equation whose solution yields a Lyapunov function. The inferred quadratic Lyapunov function can then characterize an ellipsoidal estimate of the stability region. Numerical results on benchmark examples demonstrate that our physics-informed stability analysis method successfully characterizes a near-maximal ellipsoid of the system stability region associated with the inferred Lyapunov function without requiring knowledge of the system governing equations.

AI.tldr: A data-driven, physics-informed method (LyapInf) infers a quadratic Lyapunov function from trajectory data to estimate an ellipsoidal stability region via minimizing the Zubov PDE residual, without requiring known system equations.
AI.motivation: Determining the stability region of complex dynamical systems is hard because the stability region is often unknown a priori and the governing equations may be unavailable. A data-driven approach to infer a Lyapunov function from trajectories addresses this gap.
AI.method: Assume a quadratic Lyapunov function; fit its operator by minimizing the average Zubov PDE residual using trajectory data (black-box system). The method yields an ellipsoidal estimate of the stability region from the inferred Lyapunov function.
AI.result: Numerical experiments on benchmark problems show that LyapInf recovers a near-maximal ellipsoid of the stability region without needing system equations.
AI.conclusion: The physics-informed Lyapunov-function inference provides a practical tool to estimate stability regions for complex systems from data alone, broadening applicability when models are unknown.

title: Argus: Resilience-Oriented Safety Assurance Framework for End-to-End ADSs
comment: The paper has been accepted by the 40th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Automated Software Engineering, ASE 2025
summary:
End-to-end autonomous driving systems (ADSs), with their strong capabilities in environmental perception and generalizable driving decisions, are attracting growing attention from both academia and industry. However, once deployed on public roads, ADSs are inevitably exposed to diverse driving hazards that may compromise safety and degrade system performance. This raises a strong demand for resilience of ADSs, particularly the capability to continuously monitor driving hazards and adaptively respond to potential safety violations, which is crucial for maintaining robust driving behaviors in complex driving scenarios.
  To bridge this gap, we propose a runtime resilience-oriented framework, Argus, to mitigate the driving hazards, thus preventing potential safety violations and improving the driving performance of an ADS. Argus continuously monitors the trajectories generated by the ADS for potential hazards and, whenever the EGO vehicle is deemed unsafe, seamlessly takes control through a hazard mitigator. We integrate Argus with three state-of-the-art end-to-end ADSs, i.e., TCP, UniAD and VAD. Our evaluation has demonstrated that Argus effectively and efficiently enhances the resilience of ADSs, improving the driving score of the ADS by up to 150.30% on average, and preventing up to 64.38% of the violations, with little additional time overhead.

AI.tldr: A runtime resilience framework, Argus, monitors trajectories from end-to-end autonomous driving systems (ADSs) to detect hazards and intervene via a hazard mitigator, improving safety performance with minimal overhead. Validated by integrating with TCP, UniAD, and VAD, achieving up to 150.30% driving-score improvement and preventing up to 64.38% of safety violations.
AI.motivation: ADSs deployed on public roads face diverse, real-world driving hazards that can compromise safety; there is a need for continuous hazard monitoring and adaptive responses to maintain robust driving performance.
AI.method: Argus continuously analyzes ADS-generated trajectories to identify unsafe situations; when the ego vehicle is deemed unsafe, a hazard mitigator takes control to restore safety. It is integrated with three end-to-end ADSs: TCP, UniAD, and VAD.
AI.result: The approach yields substantial resilience gains, with average driving-score improvements up to 150.30% and up to 64.38% of violations prevented, while adding little time overhead.
AI.conclusion: Argus provides an effective, efficient means to enhance ADS resilience and can be embedded with existing end-to-end ADSs to sustain robust driving across diverse scenarios.

title: SIFT-Graph: Benchmarking Multimodal Defense Against Image Adversarial Attacks With Robust Feature Graph
comment: Accepted by ICCV2025 Workshop, short paper
summary: Adversarial attacks expose a fundamental vulnerability in modern deep vision models by exploiting their dependence on dense, pixel-level representations that are highly sensitive to imperceptible perturbations. Traditional defense strategies typically operate within this fragile pixel domain, lacking mechanisms to incorporate inherently robust visual features. In this work, we introduce SIFT-Graph, a multimodal defense framework that enhances the robustness of traditional vision models by aggregating structurally meaningful features extracted from raw images using both handcrafted and learned modalities. Specifically, we integrate Scale-Invariant Feature Transform keypoints with a Graph Attention Network to capture scale and rotation invariant local structures that are resilient to perturbations. These robust feature embeddings are then fused with traditional vision model, such as Vision Transformer and Convolutional Neural Network, to form a unified, structure-aware and perturbation defensive model. Preliminary results demonstrate that our method effectively improves the visual model robustness against gradient-based white box adversarial attacks, while incurring only a marginal drop in clean accuracy.

AI.tldr: SIFT-Graph: a multimodal defense that fuses SIFT keypoints with a Graph Attention Network to produce robust, structure-aware features and improves robustness of Vision Transformers/CNNs against gradient-based white-box attacks with minimal loss in clean accuracy.
AI.motivation: Pixel-domain defenses are fragile; modern deep vision models rely on dense pixel-level representations that are highly sensitive to imperceptible perturbations. Incorporating inherently robust, structural features could bolster resilience to adversarial perturbations.
AI.method: Extract SIFT keypoints/descriptors from raw images, construct a graph of local structures, apply a Graph Attention Network (GAT) to obtain robust feature embeddings, and fuse these embeddings with traditional vision models (e.g., Vision Transformer or CNN) to form a unified, structure-aware classifier. Train under adversarial scenarios to promote robustness.
AI.result: Preliminary results show improved robustness against gradient-based white-box adversarial attacks, with only a marginal drop in clean accuracy.
AI.conclusion: Integrating handcrafted, structure-aware features with learned representations and traditional vision models is a promising direction for defense against adversarial attacks, achieving robustness with minimal accuracy loss.

title: SMF-VO: Direct Ego-Motion Estimation via Sparse Motion Fields
summary: Traditional Visual Odometry (VO) and Visual Inertial Odometry (VIO) methods rely on a 'pose-centric' paradigm, which computes absolute camera poses from the local map thus requires large-scale landmark maintenance and continuous map optimization. This approach is computationally expensive, limiting their real-time performance on resource-constrained devices. To overcome these limitations, we introduce Sparse Motion Field Visual Odometry (SMF-VO), a lightweight, 'motion-centric' framework. Our approach directly estimates instantaneous linear and angular velocity from sparse optical flow, bypassing the need for explicit pose estimation or expensive landmark tracking. We also employed a generalized 3D ray-based motion field formulation that works accurately with various camera models, including wide-field-of-view lenses. SMF-VO demonstrates superior efficiency and competitive accuracy on benchmark datasets, achieving over 100 FPS on a Raspberry Pi 5 using only a CPU. Our work establishes a scalable and efficient alternative to conventional methods, making it highly suitable for mobile robotics and wearable devices.

AI.tldr: A lightweight, motion-centric visual odometry (SMF-VO) that estimates instantaneous velocity from sparse optical flow, avoiding pose estimation and landmark tracking, with a generalized 3D ray-based motion field that handles wide FOVs and runs efficiently on CPU-only hardware (~100 FPS on Raspberry Pi 5).
AI.motivation: Conventional VO/VIO are pose-centric and rely on large-scale landmark maintenance and map optimization, leading to heavy computation that limits real-time performance on resource-constrained devices. A fast, light-weight alternative is needed for mobile robotics and wearables.
AI.method: Introduce SMF-VO, a motion-centric framework that directly estimates instantaneous linear and angular velocity from sparse optical flow, bypassing explicit pose estimation and landmark tracking. Use a generalized 3D ray-based motion field formulation to work with various camera models, including wide FOV lenses.
AI.result: Demonstrates superior efficiency with competitive accuracy on benchmark datasets; achieves over 100 FPS on a Raspberry Pi 5 using only a CPU.
AI.conclusion: SMF-VO provides a scalable, efficient alternative to pose-centric VO/VIO, enabling real-time operation on limited hardware and broad applicability to mobile robotics and wearables.

title: TIGER-MARL: Enhancing Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning with Temporal Information through Graph-based Embeddings and Representations
summary: In this paper, we propose capturing and utilizing \textit{Temporal Information through Graph-based Embeddings and Representations} or \textbf{TIGER} to enhance multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL). We explicitly model how inter-agent coordination structures evolve over time. While most MARL approaches rely on static or per-step relational graphs, they overlook the temporal evolution of interactions that naturally arise as agents adapt, move, or reorganize cooperation strategies. Capturing such evolving dependencies is key to achieving robust and adaptive coordination. To this end, TIGER constructs dynamic temporal graphs of MARL agents, connecting their current and historical interactions. It then employs a temporal attention-based encoder to aggregate information across these structural and temporal neighborhoods, yielding time-aware agent embeddings that guide cooperative policy learning. Through extensive experiments on two coordination-intensive benchmarks, we show that TIGER consistently outperforms diverse value-decomposition and graph-based MARL baselines in task performance and sample efficiency. Furthermore, we conduct comprehensive ablation studies to isolate the impact of key design parameters in TIGER, revealing how structural and temporal factors can jointly shape effective policy learning in MARL. All codes can be found here: https://github.com/Nikunj-Gupta/tiger-marl.

AI.tldr: Temporal graph dynamics for MARL via TIGER improves coordination and sample efficiency through a temporal graph encoder.
AI.motivation: Agents' interactions evolve as they move and adapt; static graphs miss temporal dependencies that are key to robust coordination.
AI.method: Construct dynamic temporal graphs linking current and historical interactions; apply a temporal attention-based encoder to produce time-aware agent embeddings; integrate into cooperative policy learning; compare with value-decomposition and graph-based MARL baselines; perform ablations.
AI.result: TIGER consistently outperforms baselines on two coordination-heavy benchmarks in task performance and sample efficiency; ablations highlight the joint impact of structural and temporal factors; code released.
AI.conclusion: Highlight the importance of modeling temporal evolution of interactions for MARL; TIGER provides a framework for robust, adaptive coordination via time-aware embeddings; potential for broader MARL applications.

title: Advancing Autonomous Emergency Response Systems: A Generative AI Perspective
summary: Autonomous Vehicles (AVs) are poised to revolutionize emergency services by enabling faster, safer, and more efficient responses. This transformation is driven by advances in Artificial Intelligence (AI), particularly Reinforcement Learning (RL), which allows AVs to navigate complex environments and make critical decisions in real time. However, conventional RL paradigms often suffer from poor sample efficiency and lack adaptability in dynamic emergency scenarios. This paper reviews next-generation AV optimization strategies to address these limitations. We analyze the shift from conventional RL to Diffusion Model (DM)-augmented RL, which enhances policy robustness through synthetic data generation, albeit with increased computational cost. Additionally, we explore the emerging paradigm of Large Language Model (LLM)-assisted In-Context Learning (ICL), which offers a lightweight and interpretable alternative by enabling rapid, on-the-fly adaptation without retraining. By reviewing the state of the art in AV intelligence, DM-augmented RL, and LLM-assisted ICL, this paper provides a critical framework for understanding the next generation of autonomous emergency response systems from a Generative AI perspective.

AI.tldr: Survey of next-gen autonomous emergency response AI, comparing diffusion-model augmented reinforcement learning and LLM-assisted in-context learning to improve robustness and speed of adaptation, while noting trade-offs in compute and data requirements.
AI.motivation: Address inefficiencies and limited adaptability of conventional RL in dynamic emergency scenarios, aiming to enhance speed, safety, and efficiency of AV-based emergency responses.
AI.method: Literature review of AV optimization methods, focusing on transitions from conventional RL to diffusion-model augmented RL and LLM-assisted ICL; analysis of benefits, drawbacks, and trade-offs from a Generative AI perspective.
AI.result: Identifies that DM-augmented RL can boost policy robustness via synthetic data but increases computational costs; LLM-assisted ICL offers rapid, on-the-fly adaptation without retraining, but may have other limitations; provides a framework to compare approaches.
AI.conclusion: Provides a critical framework for understanding next-generation autonomous emergency response systems from a Generative AI perspective, highlighting trade-offs and guiding future research in AV intelligence, DM-augmented RL, and LLM-assisted ICL.

title: DT-NVS: Diffusion Transformers for Novel View Synthesis
summary: Generating novel views of a natural scene, e.g., every-day scenes both indoors and outdoors, from a single view is an under-explored problem, even though it is an organic extension to the object-centric novel view synthesis. Existing diffusion-based approaches focus rather on small camera movements in real scenes or only consider unnatural object-centric scenes, limiting their potential applications in real-world settings. In this paper we move away from these constrained regimes and propose a 3D diffusion model trained with image-only losses on a large-scale dataset of real-world, multi-category, unaligned, and casually acquired videos of everyday scenes. We propose DT-NVS, a 3D-aware diffusion model for generalized novel view synthesis that exploits a transformer-based architecture backbone. We make significant contributions to transformer and self-attention architectures to translate images to 3d representations, and novel camera conditioning strategies to allow training on real-world unaligned datasets. In addition, we introduce a novel training paradigm swapping the role of reference frame between the conditioning image and the sampled noisy input. We evaluate our approach on the 3D task of generalized novel view synthesis from a single input image and show improvements over state-of-the-art 3D aware diffusion models and deterministic approaches, while generating diverse outputs.
