A Dual-View Alignment Loss aligns low-frequency signals with the periodic branch and high-frequency signals with the residual branch. Experiments on four real-world datasets show state-of-the-art accuracy, robustness to disturbances, and better computational efficiency.
AI.motivation: Accurate traffic forecasting is challenged by (i) complex spatial dependencies across road segments and sensors, and (ii) coexistence of multi-scale periodic patterns (daily/weekly) with irregular, event-driven fluctuations (accidents, weather, construction). A model that separates these components can better capture regularities while handling anomalies.
AI.method: Propose HyperD which decouples data into: (1) Periodic component via Hybrid Periodic Representation Module with learnable periodic embeddings and spatial-temporal attention to extract fine-grained daily/weekly patterns; (2) Residual component via Frequency-Aware Residual Representation Module using complex-valued MLP in the frequency domain to model non-periodic, high-frequency fluctuations. A Dual-View Alignment Loss enforces semantic separation by aligning low-frequency information with the periodic branch and high-frequency information with the residual branch.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on four real-world traffic datasets demonstrate state-of-the-art prediction accuracy, superior robustness under disturbances, and improved computational efficiency compared to existing methods.
AI.conclusion: HyperD advances traffic forecasting by decoupling periodic and residual signals and enforcing their semantic separation, achieving high accuracy, robustness, and efficiency.

title: LLM-Guided Probabilistic Fusion for Label-Efficient Document Layout Analysis
summary: Document layout understanding remains data-intensive despite advances in semi-supervised learning. We present a framework that enhances semi-supervised detection by fusing visual predictions with structural priors from text-pretrained LLMs via principled probabilistic weighting. Given unlabeled documents, an OCR-LLM pipeline infers hierarchical regions which are combined with teacher detector outputs through inverse-variance fusion to generate refined pseudo-labels.Our method demonstrates consistent gains across model scales. With a lightweight SwiftFormer backbone (26M params), we achieve 88.2$\pm$0.3 AP using only 5\% labels on PubLayNet. When applied to document-pretrained LayoutLMv3 (133M params), our fusion framework reaches 89.7$\pm$0.4 AP, surpassing both LayoutLMv3 with standard semi-supervised learning (89.1$\pm$0.4 AP, p=0.02) and matching UDOP~\cite{udop} (89.8 AP) which requires 100M+ pages of multimodal pretraining. This demonstrates that LLM structural priors are complementary to both lightweight and pretrained architectures. Key findings include: (1) learned instance-adaptive gating improves over fixed weights by +0.9 AP with data-dependent PAC bounds correctly predicting convergence; (2) open-source LLMs enable privacy-preserving deployment with minimal loss (Llama-3-70B: 87.1 AP lightweight, 89.4 AP with LayoutLMv3); (3) LLMs provide targeted semantic disambiguation (18.7\% of cases, +3.8 AP gain) beyond simple text heuristics.Total system cost includes \$12 for GPT-4o-mini API or 17 GPU-hours for local Llama-3-70B per 50K pages, amortized across training runs.

AI.tldr: A semi-supervised framework for document layout understanding that fuses visual detector outputs with LLM-derived structural priors via inverse-variance weighting to generate high-quality pseudo-labels, achieving strong AP on PubLayNet and LayoutLMv3 with limited labels, and enabling privacy-preserving deployment using open-source LLMs.
AI.motivation: Document layout understanding is data-intensive; leveraging structural priors from text-pretrained LLMs and probabilistic fusion can reduce labeled data requirements and improve pseudo-label quality.
AI.method: 1) Build an OCR-LLM pipeline to infer hierarchical regions from unlabeled documents. 2) Fuse these regions with teacher detector outputs through inverse-variance weighting to produce refined pseudo-labels. 3) Learn instance-adaptive gating with data-dependent PAC bounds to balance priors and visual signals. 4) evaluate across lightweight and pretrained backbones (SwiftFormer 26M, LayoutLMv3 133M) and with open-source LLMs (e.g., Llama-3-70B) for privacy-preserving deployment. 5) report cost indicators (GPT-4o-mini, Llama-3-70B).
AI.result: On PubLayNet, 26M SwiftFormer with 5% labeled data achieves 88.2±0.3 AP. With LayoutLMv3 (133M) fusion reaches 89.7±0.4 AP, surpassing standard semi-supervised LayoutLMv3 (89.1±0.4 AP, p=0.02) and matching UDOP (89.8 AP). Open-source LLMs enable privacy-preserving deployment (Llama-3-70B: 87.1 AP lightweight, 89.4 AP with LayoutLMv3). LLMs contribute semantic disambiguation in 18.7% of cases (+3.8 AP). Total system cost ~$12 for GPT-4o-mini API or 17 GPU-hours for local Llama-3-70B per 50K pages.
AI.conclusion: LLM-based structural priors are complementary to both lightweight and pretrained document models. Instance-adaptive gating yields data-dependent gains; open-source LLMs support privacy-preserving deployment with minimal loss; LLMs provide targeted semantic disambiguation beyond simple text heuristics.

title: UMIGen: A Unified Framework for Egocentric Point Cloud Generation and Cross-Embodiment Robotic Imitation Learning
summary: Data-driven robotic learning faces an obvious dilemma: robust policies demand large-scale, high-quality demonstration data, yet collecting such data remains a major challenge owing to high operational costs, dependence on specialized hardware, and the limited spatial generalization capability of current methods. The Universal Manipulation Interface (UMI) relaxes the strict hardware requirements for data collection, but it is restricted to capturing only RGB images of a scene and omits the 3D geometric information on which many tasks rely. Inspired by DemoGen, we propose UMIGen, a unified framework that consists of two key components: (1) Cloud-UMI, a handheld data collection device that requires no visual SLAM and simultaneously records point cloud observation-action pairs; and (2) a visibility-aware optimization mechanism that extends the DemoGen pipeline to egocentric 3D observations by generating only points within the camera's field of view. These two components enable efficient data generation that aligns with real egocentric observations and can be directly transferred across different robot embodiments without any post-processing. Experiments in both simulated and real-world settings demonstrate that UMIGen supports strong cross-embodiment generalization and accelerates data collection in diverse manipulation tasks.

AI.tldr: UMIGen combines a handheld Cloud-UMI data collection device with a visibility-aware optimization to generate ego-centric 3D observations from 2.5D data, enabling cross-embodiment transfer and faster data collection for manipulation policies.
AI.motivation: Data-driven robotic learning needs large, high-quality demonstration data. Existing interfaces either limit data to RGB or require costly setups with 3D sensing and SLAM. UMIGen proposes an ergonomic, multi-embodiment data collection solution that preserves 3D geometry while aligning with real egocentric observations.
AI.method: Two-part approach: (1) Cloud-UMI — a handheld device that records point cloud observations and actions without requiring visual SLAM; (2) visibility-aware optimization — extends the DemoGen idea to generate only points within the camera frustum, producing ego-centric 3D observations that transfer across robot embodiments without post-processing.
AI.result: Demonstrates strong cross-embodiment generalization and accelerated data collection in both simulated and real-world manipulation tasks.
AI.conclusion: UMIGen provides an efficient, transferable framework for generating 3D demonstration data that aligns with egocentric perception, enabling robust, embodiment-agnostic learning for robotic manipulation.

title: Covariance Scattering Transforms
summary: Machine learning and data processing techniques relying on covariance information are widespread as they identify meaningful patterns in unsupervised and unlabeled settings. As a prominent example, Principal Component Analysis (PCA) projects data points onto the eigenvectors of their covariance matrix, capturing the directions of maximum variance. This mapping, however, falls short in two directions: it fails to capture information in low-variance directions, relevant when, e.g., the data contains high-variance noise; and it provides unstable results in low-sample regimes, especially when covariance eigenvalues are close. CoVariance Neural Networks (VNNs), i.e., graph neural networks using the covariance matrix as a graph, show improved stability to estimation errors and learn more expressive functions in the covariance spectrum than PCA, but require training and operate in a labeled setup. To get the benefits of both worlds, we propose Covariance Scattering Transforms (CSTs), deep untrained networks that sequentially apply filters localized in the covariance spectrum to the input data and produce expressive hierarchical representations via nonlinearities. We define the filters as covariance wavelets that capture specific and detailed covariance spectral patterns. We improve CSTs' computational and memory efficiency via a pruning mechanism, and we prove that their error due to finite-sample covariance estimations is less sensitive to close covariance eigenvalues compared to PCA, improving their stability. Our experiments on age prediction from cortical thickness measurements on 4 datasets collecting patients with neurodegenerative diseases show that CSTs produce stable representations in low-data settings, as VNNs but without any training, and lead to comparable or better predictions w.r.t. more complex learning models.

AI.tldr: Untrained Covariance Scattering Transforms (CSTs) use covariance-spectrum–localized filters (covariance wavelets) to build hierarchical representations, yielding stable, competitive predictions without training; pruning improves efficiency; they outperform PCA and match or exceed covariance-based networks in low-data settings.
AI.motivation: PCA misses low-variance directions and is unstable with small sample sizes; covariance neural networks (VNNs) offer stability and richer spectral processing but require labels and training. There is a need for an unsupervised, stable, and expressive method that leverages covariance information.
AI.method: Define covariance wavelets as filters localized in the eigen-spectrum of the data covariance, apply them sequentially in a deep architecture with nonlinearities to produce hierarchical representations; introduce pruning for computational/memory efficiency; show theoretically that finite-sample covariance estimation error is less sensitive to close eigenvalues than PCA, improving stability.
AI.result: Empirically, CSTs produce stable representations in low-data settings (like VNNs) without training and achieve age-prediction from cortical thickness across four neurodegenerative datasets with performance comparable or better than more complex learning models.
AI.conclusion: CSTs offer an unsupervised, untrained, covariance-based representation that captures detailed spectral patterns, provides stability in low-sample regimes, and achieves competitive predictive performance, effectively bridging PCA and VNNs without requiring labeled training.

title: From Model Training to Model Raising -- A call to reform AI model training paradigms from post-hoc alignment to intrinsic, identity-based development
comment: Accepted for publication in Communications of the ACM (CACM), Opinion section
summary: Current AI training methods align models with human values only after their core capabilities have been established, resulting in models that are easily misaligned and lack deep-rooted value systems. We propose a paradigm shift from "model training" to "model raising", in which alignment is woven into a model's development from the start. We identify several key components for this paradigm, all centered around redesigning the training corpus: reframing training data from a first-person perspective, recontextualizing information as lived experience, simulating social interactions, and scaffolding the ordering of training data. We expect that this redesign of the training corpus will lead to an early commitment to values from the first training token onward, such that knowledge, skills, and values are intrinsically much harder to separate. In an ecosystem in which large language model capabilities start overtaking human capabilities in many tasks, this seems to us like a critical need.

AI.tldr: Proposes a 'model raising' paradigm to embed alignment from the outset by redesigning the training corpus around lived experience and social interaction.
AI.motivation: Current AI training aligns models with human values only after core capabilities are established, leaving models prone to misalignment as they scale.
AI.method: Redesign training data to (1) frame content from a first-person perspective, (2) treat information as lived experience, (3) simulate social interactions, and (4) scaffold the ordering of data to instill values from the first token.
AI.result: A conceptual framework arguing that early, intrinsic alignment emerges when knowledge, skills, and values are interwoven from the start, making separation harder.
AI.conclusion: Shifting from 'training' to 'raising'—with corpus redesign and early value commitment—is presented as essential for robust alignment in increasingly capable LLMs.

title: Consistency Change Detection Framework for Unsupervised Remote Sensing Change Detection
comment: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Multimedia and Expo (ICME)
summary: Unsupervised remote sensing change detection aims to monitor and analyze changes from multi-temporal remote sensing images in the same geometric region at different times, without the need for labeled training data. Previous unsupervised methods attempt to achieve style transfer across multi-temporal remote sensing images through reconstruction by a generator network, and then capture the unreconstructable areas as the changed regions. However, it often leads to poor performance due to generator overfitting. In this paper, we propose a novel Consistency Change Detection Framework (CCDF) to address this challenge. Specifically, we introduce a Cycle Consistency (CC) module to reduce the overfitting issues in the generator-based reconstruction. Additionally, we propose a Semantic Consistency (SC) module to enable detail reconstruction. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our method outperforms other state-of-the-art approaches.

AI.tldr: Proposes CCDF, a two-pronged unsupervised change detection framework that reduces generator overfitting via Cycle Consistency and enables detail reconstruction via Semantic Consistency, achieving superior performance on unsupervised remote sensing change detection.
AI.motivation: Unsupervised change detection using reconstruction-based generators often overfits, misinterpreting changes and failing to recover fine details. There is a need for mechanisms that constrain generators and preserve semantic detail across multi-temporal images.
AI.method: Introduce CCDF with two modules: (1) Cycle Consistency (CC) to mitigate generator overfitting by enforcing bidirectional consistency during reconstruction across time steps, and (2) Semantic Consistency (SC) to encourage faithful detail reconstruction by preserving semantic information and enabling finer detail recovery.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show that CCDF outperforms state-of-the-art unsupervised change detection methods, demonstrating improved accuracy and robustness.
AI.conclusion: CCDF effectively addresses generator overfitting while preserving detail through semantic consistency, offering a strong unsupervised framework for remote sensing change detection.

title: CoRL-MPPI: Enhancing MPPI With Learnable Behaviours For Efficient And Provably-Safe Multi-Robot Collision Avoidance
comment: The manuscript includes 9 pages, 4 figures, and 1 table
summary: Decentralized collision avoidance remains a core challenge for scalable multi-robot systems. One of the promising approaches to tackle this problem is Model Predictive Path Integral (MPPI) -- a framework that is naturally suited to handle any robot motion model and provides strong theoretical guarantees. Still, in practice MPPI-based controller may provide suboptimal trajectories as its performance relies heavily on uninformed random sampling. In this work, we introduce CoRL-MPPI, a novel fusion of Cooperative Reinforcement Learning and MPPI to address this limitation. We train an action policy (approximated as deep neural network) in simulation that learns local cooperative collision avoidance behaviors. This learned policy is then embedded into the MPPI framework to guide its sampling distribution, biasing it towards more intelligent and cooperative actions. Notably, CoRL-MPPI preserves all the theoretical guarantees of regular MPPI. We evaluate our approach in dense, dynamic simulation environments against state-of-the-art baselines, including ORCA, BVC, and a multi-agent MPPI implementation. Our results demonstrate that CoRL-MPPI significantly improves navigation efficiency (measured by success rate and makespan) and safety, enabling agile and robust multi-robot navigation.

AI.tldr: CoRL-MPPI fuses Cooperative Reinforcement Learning with MPPI, training a neural policy to bias MPPI's sampling toward cooperative actions. This improves success rate, makespan, and safety in dense multi-robot scenarios while preserving MPPI's theoretical guarantees.
AI.motivation: Decentralized collision avoidance is essential for scalable multi-robot systems. MPPI offers strong guarantees but relies on uninformed random sampling, which can yield suboptimal trajectories; integrating learned cooperative behavior aims to guide sampling without sacrificing MPPI theory.
AI.method: Train a neural policy in simulation that encodes local cooperative collision avoidance. Embed this policy into MPPI to bias its sampling distribution toward cooperative actions, preserving MPPI's guarantees.
AI.result: In dense, dynamic simulations, CoRL-MPPI outperforms baselines (ORCA, BVC, multi-agent MPPI) in navigation efficiency (higher success rate, reduced makespan) and safety.
AI.conclusion: CoRL-MPPI provides a principled approach to decentralized collision avoidance that enhances performance while preserving the theoretical guarantees of MPPI, showing promise for scalable, robust multi-robot navigation.

title: Spectral Predictability as a Fast Reliability Indicator for Time Series Forecasting Model Selection
summary: Practitioners deploying time series forecasting models face a dilemma: exhaustively validating dozens of models is computationally prohibitive, yet choosing the wrong model risks poor performance. We show that spectral predictability~$Ω$ -- a simple signal processing metric -- systematically stratifies model family performance, enabling fast model selection. We conduct controlled experiments in four different domains, then further expand our analysis to 51 models and 28 datasets from the GIFT-Eval benchmark. We find that large time series foundation models (TSFMs) systematically outperform lightweight task-trained baselines when $Ω$ is high, while their advantage vanishes as $Ω$ drops. Computing $Ω$ takes seconds per dataset, enabling practitioners to quickly assess whether their data suits TSFM approaches or whether simpler, cheaper models suffice. We demonstrate that $Ω$ stratifies model performance predictably, offering a practical first-pass filter that reduces validation costs while highlighting the need for models that excel on genuinely difficult (low-$Ω$) problems rather than merely optimizing easy ones.

AI.tldr: Omega, a spectral predictability metric, efficiently guides model selection for time-series forecasting by predicting when large TSFMs outperform lightweight models; compute Omega in seconds per dataset to decide whether TSFMs are worth it.
AI.motivation: Avoid exhaustive validation of many models; reduce computation while maintaining performance; provide a fast screen for data suitability for TSFMs.
AI.method: Controlled experiments across four domains; expanded analysis to 51 models and 28 datasets from GIFT-Eval; compute Omega; compare performance across Omega levels.
AI.result: Omega stratifies performance: high Omega -> TSFMs outperform; low Omega -> no clear advantage; Omega computation is fast; first-pass filter reduces validation costs; highlights focus on difficult (low Omega) problems.
AI.conclusion: Omega is a practical, low-cost predictor for model selection and evaluation cost reduction in time-series forecasting; use as a fast screening tool to allocate resources toward hard problems.

title: Not Everything That Counts Can Be Counted: A Case for Safe Qualitative AI
comment: Accepted at 3rd International Conference on Frontiers of Artificial Intelligence, Ethics, and Multidisciplinary Applications (FAIEMA 2025)
summary: Artificial intelligence (AI) and large language models (LLM) are reshaping science, with most recent advances culminating in fully-automated scientific discovery pipelines. But qualitative research has been left behind. Researchers in qualitative methods are hesitant about AI adoption. Yet when they are willing to use AI at all, they have little choice but to rely on general-purpose tools like ChatGPT to assist with interview interpretation, data annotation, and topic modeling - while simultaneously acknowledging these system's well-known limitations of being biased, opaque, irreproducible, and privacy-compromising. This creates a critical gap: while AI has substantially advanced quantitative methods, the qualitative dimensions essential for meaning-making and comprehensive scientific understanding remain poorly integrated. We argue for developing dedicated qualitative AI systems built from the ground up for interpretive research. Such systems must be transparent, reproducible, and privacy-friendly. We review recent literature to show how existing automated discovery pipelines could be enhanced by robust qualitative capabilities, and identify key opportunities where safe qualitative AI could advance multidisciplinary and mixed-methods research.

AI.tldr: The abstract argues for creating dedicated qualitative AI systems designed for interpretive research to complement qualitative methods, addressing biases, opacity, irreproducibility, and privacy concerns of general-purpose AI, and outlines a research agenda to integrate meaning-making into scientific discovery.
AI.motivation: Qualitative research risks being left behind as AI advances, and researchers rely on generic tools (e.g., ChatGPT) with known limitations. There is a need to preserve interpretive rigor, meaning, and privacy while leveraging AI.
AI.method: Literature review and normative analysis to propose design principles for qualitative AI, outlining how existing automated discovery pipelines could be enhanced with qualitative capabilities and identifying opportunities for safe, cross-disciplinary, mixed-methods research.
AI.result: A roadmap and design criteria for dedicated qualitative AI systems, including transparency, reproducibility, and privacy; evidence that current pipelines could be augmented with qualitative capabilities; identification of opportunities for multidisciplinary and mixed-methods research.
AI.conclusion: Develop qualitative AI systems from the ground up that support interpretive research, ensuring transparency, reproducibility, and privacy, thereby integrating qualitative meaning-making into automated scientific discovery.

title: HitoMi-Cam: A Shape-Agnostic Person Detection Method Using the Spectral Characteristics of Clothing
comment: 37 pages, 21 figures, 9 tables. Published in MDPI Journal of Imaging. Includes 1 supplementary video file (ancillary file)
summary: While convolutional neural network (CNN)-based object detection is widely used, it exhibits a shape dependency that degrades performance for postures not included in the training data. Building upon our previous simulation study published in this journal, this study implements and evaluates the spectral-based approach on physical hardware to address this limitation. Specifically, this paper introduces HitoMi-Cam, a lightweight and shape-agnostic person detection method that uses the spectral reflectance properties of clothing. The author implemented the system on a resource-constrained edge device without a GPU to assess its practical viability. The results indicate that a processing speed of 23.2 frames per second (fps) (253x190 pixels) is achievable, suggesting that the method can be used for real-time applications. In a simulated search and rescue scenario where the performance of CNNs declines, HitoMi-Cam achieved an average precision (AP) of 93.5%, surpassing that of the compared CNN models (best AP of 53.8%). Throughout all evaluation scenarios, the occurrence of false positives remained minimal. This study positions the HitoMi-Cam method not as a replacement for CNN-based detectors but as a complementary tool under specific conditions. The results indicate that spectral-based person detection can be a viable option for real-time operation on edge devices in real-world environments where shapes are unpredictable, such as disaster rescue.

AI.tldr: Spectral-based, shape-agnostic HitoMi-Cam detects people via clothing reflectance on edge devices; achieves 23.2 fps, AP 93.5% in simulated rescue, outperforming CNNs; positions as a complementary tool for real-time, unpredictable-shape environments.
AI.motivation: CNN-based detectors exhibit a shape dependency that degrades performance for postures not seen during training. There is a need for a lightweight, real-time, shape-agnostic detection method that can run on edge devices in real-world scenarios with unpredictable shapes, such as disaster rescue.
AI.method: A spectral reflectance-based person detection approach (HitoMi-Cam) leveraging clothing properties. Implemented on a resource-constrained edge device without a GPU, and evaluated in real-time and in a simulated search-and-rescue scenario.
AI.result: Achieves 23.2 frames per second on 253x190 pixel input; average precision of 93.5% in the simulation, surpassing the best CNNs at 53.8% AP; false positives remain minimal across scenarios.
AI.conclusion: Spectral-based detection is viable for real-time edge operation in environments with unpredictable shapes and can serve as a complementary tool to CNN detectors, particularly in disaster rescue contexts.

title: SPIDER: Scalable Physics-Informed Dexterous Retargeting
summary: Learning dexterous and agile policy for humanoid and dexterous hand control requires large-scale demonstrations, but collecting robot-specific data is prohibitively expensive. In contrast, abundant human motion data is readily available from motion capture, videos, and virtual reality, which could help address the data scarcity problem. However, due to the embodiment gap and missing dynamic information like force and torque, these demonstrations cannot be directly executed on robots. To bridge this gap, we propose Scalable Physics-Informed DExterous Retargeting (SPIDER), a physics-based retargeting framework to transform and augment kinematic-only human demonstrations to dynamically feasible robot trajectories at scale. Our key insight is that human demonstrations should provide global task structure and objective, while large-scale physics-based sampling with curriculum-style virtual contact guidance should refine trajectories to ensure dynamical feasibility and correct contact sequences. SPIDER scales across diverse 9 humanoid/dexterous hand embodiments and 6 datasets, improving success rates by 18% compared to standard sampling, while being 10X faster than reinforcement learning (RL) baselines, and enabling the generation of a 2.4M frames dynamic-feasible robot dataset for policy learning. As a universal physics-based retargeting method, SPIDER can work with diverse quality data and generate diverse and high-quality data to enable efficient policy learning with methods like RL.

AI.tldr: A physics-based, scalable retargeting framework (SPIDER) converts human kinematic demonstrations into dynamically feasible robot trajectories for dexterous hands, enabling large-scale policy learning.
AI.motivation: Robot dexterous control suffers from data scarcity and the embodiment gap between humans and robots; available human motion data lacks dynamic information (forces/torques) making direct transfer infeasible. A scalable bridge is needed to generate robot-feasible data from human demonstrations.
AI.method: SPIDER (Scalable Physics-Informed DExterous Retargeting) uses human demonstrations to provide global task structure, while a curriculum-style physics-based sampling with virtual contact guidance refines trajectories to ensure dynamical feasibility and correct contact sequences across 9 humanoid/dexterous hand embodiments and 6 datasets, enabling large-scale dynamic data generation (2.4M frames).
AI.result: Improves success rates by 18% over standard sampling and is about 10x faster than RL baselines; yields a universal, high-quality dynamic dataset suitable for policy learning.
AI.conclusion: SPIDER offers a universal, physics-based retargeting method that can work with varied data quality to generate diverse, dynamic-feasible robot trajectories, accelerating policy learning with methods like RL.

title: FAST-CAD: A Fairness-Aware Framework for Non-Contact Stroke Diagnosis
summary: Stroke is an acute cerebrovascular disease, and timely diagnosis significantly improves patient survival. However, existing automated diagnosis methods suffer from fairness issues across demographic groups, potentially exacerbating healthcare disparities. In this work we propose FAST-CAD, a theoretically grounded framework that combines domain-adversarial training (DAT) with group distributionally robust optimization (Group-DRO) for fair and accurate non-contact stroke diagnosis. Our approach is built on domain adaptation and minimax fairness theory and provides convergence guarantees and fairness bounds. We curate a multimodal dataset covering 12 demographic subgroups defined by age, gender, and posture. FAST-CAD employs self-supervised encoders with adversarial domain discrimination to learn demographic-invariant representations, while Group-DRO optimizes worst-group risk to ensure robust performance across all subgroups. Extensive experiments show that our method achieves superior diagnostic performance while maintaining fairness across demographic groups, and our theoretical analysis supports the effectiveness of the unified DAT + Group-DRO framework. This work provides both practical advances and theoretical insights for fair medical AI systems.

AI.tldr: FAST-CAD combines domain-adversarial training and group-DRO to enable fair, accurate non-contact stroke diagnosis, with theoretical convergence guarantees and fairness bounds, validated on a multimodal dataset across 12 demographic subgroups.
AI.motivation: Fairness gaps in automated stroke diagnosis across age, gender, and posture; prevent exacerbation of healthcare disparities; require robustness to subgroup distribution shifts.
AI.method: Self-supervised encoders with adversarial domain discrimination to learn demographic-invariant representations; Group-DRO optimizing worst-group risk; theoretical grounding in domain adaptation and minimax fairness; dataset of 12 subgroups.
AI.result: Empirical experiments show superior diagnostic performance while maintaining fairness across subgroups; convergence guarantees and fairness bounds; unified framework with practical and theoretical contributions.
AI.conclusion: Provides a practical and theoretical framework for fair medical AI; advances fair, robust non-contact stroke diagnosis; potential to reduce healthcare disparities.

title: BarrierBench : Evaluating Large Language Models for Safety Verification in Dynamical Systems
summary:
Safety verification of dynamical systems via barrier certificates is essential for ensuring correctness in autonomous applications. Synthesizing these certificates involves discovering mathematical functions with current methods suffering from poor scalability, dependence on carefully designed templates, and exhaustive or incremental function-space searches. They also demand substantial manual expertise--selecting templates, solvers, and hyperparameters, and designing sampling strategies--requiring both theoretical and practical knowledge traditionally shared through linguistic reasoning rather than formalized methods.
  This motivates a key question: can such expert reasoning be captured and operationalized by language models? We address this by introducing an LLM-based agentic framework for barrier certificate synthesis. The framework uses natural language reasoning to propose, refine, and validate candidate certificates, integrating LLM-driven template discovery with SMT-based verification, and supporting barrier-controller co-synthesis to ensure consistency between safety certificates and controllers.
  To evaluate this capability, we introduce BarrierBench, a benchmark of 100 dynamical systems spanning linear, nonlinear, discrete-time, and continuous-time settings. Our experiments assess not only the effectiveness of LLM-guided barrier synthesis but also the utility of retrieval-augmented generation and agentic coordination strategies in improving its reliability and performance. Across these tasks, the framework achieves more than 90% success in generating valid certificates. By releasing BarrierBench and the accompanying toolchain, we aim to establish a community testbed for advancing the integration of language-based reasoning with formal verification in dynamical systems.
  The benchmark is publicly available at https://hycodev.com/dataset/barrierbench

AI.tldr: An LLM-driven agentic framework for barrier certificate synthesis achieving over 90% success on BarrierBench (100 dynamical systems) by combining template discovery, language-driven reasoning, SMT verification, and barrier-controller co-synthesis; benchmark and toolchain released.
AI.motivation: Synthesizing barrier certificates for safety verification is hindered by scalability limits, dependence on hand-designed templates, exhaustive search, and required expert knowledge. The work investigates whether language models can capture and operationalize expert reasoning to automate synthesis.
AI.method: An LLM-based agentic loop proposes, refines, and validates candidate barrier certificates, integrating retrieval-augmented generation for template discovery with SMT-based verification and enabling barrier-controller co-synthesis to ensure consistency between certificates and controllers.
AI.result: Empirically, the framework achieves >90% success in generating valid barrier certificates across 100 dynamical systems; demonstrating benefits of retrieval-augmented generation and agent coordination; BarrierBench and accompanying toolchain are publicly released.
AI.conclusion: This work advances the integration of language-based reasoning with formal verification in dynamical systems, providing BarrierBench as a community testbed to accelerate research and practice in barrier certificate synthesis and related verification tasks.

title: Negative Entity Suppression for Zero-Shot Captioning with Synthetic Images
summary: Text-only training provides an attractive approach to address data scarcity challenges in zero-shot image captioning (ZIC), avoiding the expense of collecting paired image-text annotations. However, although these approaches perform well within training domains, they suffer from poor cross-domain generalization, often producing hallucinated content when encountering novel visual environments. Retrieval-based methods attempt to mitigate this limitation by leveraging external knowledge, but they can paradoxically exacerbate hallucination when retrieved captions contain entities irrelevant to the inputs. We introduce the concept of negative entities--objects that appear in generated caption but are absent from the input--and propose Negative Entity Suppression (NES) to tackle this challenge. NES seamlessly integrates three stages: (1) it employs synthetic images to ensure consistent image-to-text retrieval across both training and inference; (2) it filters negative entities from retrieved content to enhance accuracy; and (3) it applies attention-level suppression using identified negative entities to further minimize the impact of hallucination-prone features. Evaluation across multiple benchmarks demonstrates that NES maintains competitive in-domain performance while improving cross-domain transfer and reducing hallucination rates, achieving new state-of-the-art results in ZIC. Our code is available at https://github.com/nidongpinyinme/NESCap.

AI.tldr: Negative Entity Suppression (NES) for zero-shot image captioning reduces hallucination and improves cross-domain transfer by leveraging synthetic images, negative-entity filtering, and attention suppression, achieving state-of-the-art results while staying competitive in-domain.
AI.motivation: Zero-shot image captioning faces data scarcity and poor cross-domain generalization, with retrieval-based methods risking hallucinations when retrieved captions include irrelevant entities.
AI.method: NES comprises three stages: (1) use synthetic images to align image-to-text retrieval between training and inference; (2) filter out negative entities (entities present in caption but not in input) from retrieved content; (3) apply attention-level suppression guided by identified negative entities to minimize hallucination-prone features.
AI.result: NES preserves in-domain performance, improves cross-domain transfer, reduces hallucination rates, and achieves new state-of-the-art results in ZIC across benchmarks; code available at the provided GitHub URL.
AI.conclusion: By integrating synthetic-image alignment, negative-entity filtering, and attention suppression, NES offers a robust approach to halting hallucinations in ZIC and enhancing cross-domain generalization.

title: WMPO: World Model-based Policy Optimization for Vision-Language-Action Models
summary: Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models have shown strong potential for general-purpose robotic manipulation, but their reliance on expert demonstrations limits their ability to learn from failures and perform self-corrections. Reinforcement learning (RL) addresses these through self-improving interactions with the physical environment, but suffers from high sample complexity on real robots. We introduce World-Model-based Policy Optimization (WMPO), a principled framework for on-policy VLA RL without interacting with the real environment. In contrast to widely used latent world models, WMPO focuses on pixel-based predictions that align the "imagined" trajectories with the VLA features pretrained with web-scale images. Crucially, WMPO enables the policy to perform on-policy GRPO that provides stronger performance than the often-used off-policy methods. Extensive experiments in both simulation and real-robot settings demonstrate that WMPO (i) substantially improves sample efficiency, (ii) achieves stronger overall performance, (iii) exhibits emergent behaviors such as self-correction, and (iv) demonstrates robust generalization and lifelong learning capabilities.

AI.tldr: WMPO is an on-policy, pixel-based world-model RL framework for Vision-Language-Action robotics that aligns imagined trajectories with pretrained VLA features, enabling self-correcting, sample-efficient learning without real-environment interactions.
AI.motivation: VLA models generally rely on expert demonstrations; while RL can learn from failures, real-robot RL suffers from high sample complexity. There is a need for an on-policy approach that learns from failures and corrections without requiring real-world interactions, while leveraging strong VLA features.
AI.method: WMPO introduces a world-model-based policy optimization framework that uses pixel-level predictions instead of latent world models and aligns imagined trajectories with VLA features pretrained on web-scale images. It enables on-policy GRPO (on-policy gradient-based policy optimization) and demonstrates superior performance to off-policy methods. Experiments cover both simulation and real-robot settings.
AI.result: WMPO substantially improves sample efficiency, achieves stronger overall performance, exhibits emergent self-correction, and demonstrates robust generalization and lifelong learning capabilities.
AI.conclusion: WMPO enables effective on-policy VLA RL without real-world interaction, bridging vision-language-action pretraining with on-policy reinforcement learning to achieve robust, lifelong robotic manipulation.

title: Weaver: Kronecker Product Approximations of Spatiotemporal Attention for Traffic Network Forecasting
summary: Spatiotemporal forecasting on transportation networks is a complex task that requires understanding how traffic nodes interact within a dynamic, evolving system dictated by traffic flow dynamics and social behavioral patterns. The importance of transportation networks and ITS for modern mobility and commerce necessitates forecasting models that are not only accurate but also interpretable, efficient, and robust under structural or temporal perturbations. Recent approaches, particularly Transformer-based architectures, have improved predictive performance but often at the cost of high computational overhead and diminished architectural interpretability. In this work, we introduce Weaver, a novel attention-based model that applies Kronecker product approximations (KPA) to decompose the PN X PN spatiotemporal attention of O(P^2N^2) complexity into local P X P temporal and N X N spatial attention maps. This Kronecker attention map enables our Parallel-Kronecker Matrix-Vector product (P2-KMV) for efficient spatiotemporal message passing with O(P^2N + N^2P) complexity. To capture real-world traffic dynamics, we address the importance of negative edges in modeling traffic behavior by introducing Valence Attention using the continuous Tanimoto coefficient (CTC), which provides properties conducive to precise latent graph generation and training stability. To fully utilize the model's learning capacity, we introduce the Traffic Phase Dictionary for self-conditioning. Evaluations on PEMS-BAY and METR-LA show that Weaver achieves competitive performance across model categories while training more efficiently.

AI.tldr: Weaver is an efficient, Kronecker-based attention model for spatiotemporal forecast in transportation networks, achieving competitive accuracy with lower training cost; it introduces Valence Attention via continuous Tanimoto and a Traffic Phase Dictionary for self-conditioning.
AI.motivation: Forecasting on transportation networks requires models that are accurate, interpretable, efficient, and robust to structural/temporal perturbations. Transformer-based approaches offer accuracy but suffer high computation and limited interpretability; there is a need for scalable, stable architectures with good latent graph learning.
AI.method: The model decomposes PN x PN spatiotemporal attention with Kronecker product approximations into local P x P temporal and N x N spatial attention maps. This enables a Parallel-Kronecker Matrix-Vector product (P2-KMV) with complexity O(P^2N + N^2P). It introduces Valence Attention using a continuous Tanimoto coefficient (CTC) to model negative edges and improve latent graph learning stability, and a Traffic Phase Dictionary for self-conditioning.
AI.result: On real-world benchmarks PEMS-BAY and METR-LA, Weaver achieves competitive performance across model categories while training more efficiently.
AI.conclusion: Kronecker-based attention with valence modeling and a self-conditioning phase dictionary yields a scalable, interpretable, and efficient spatiotemporal forecasting framework for transportation networks, offering strong performance with reduced computational overhead and improved training stability.

title: The 2025 Planning Performance of Frontier Large Language Models
summary: The capacity of Large Language Models (LLMs) for reasoning remains an active area of research, with the capabilities of frontier models continually advancing. We provide an updated evaluation of the end-to-end planning performance of three frontier LLMs as of 2025, where models are prompted to generate a plan from PDDL domain and task descriptions. We evaluate DeepSeek R1, Gemini 2.5 Pro, GPT-5 and as reference the planner LAMA on a subset of domains from the most recent Learning Track of the International Planning Competition. Our results show that on standard PDDL domains, the performance of GPT-5 in terms of solved tasks is competitive with LAMA. When the PDDL domains and tasks are obfuscated to test for pure reasoning, the performance of all LLMs degrades, though less severely than previously reported for other models. These results show substantial improvements over prior generations of LLMs, reducing the performance gap to planners on a challenging benchmark.

AI.tldr: Frontier LLMs, especially GPT-5, approach planner performance on standard PDDL tasks close to LAMA, with declines under pure-reasoning obfuscation but still improved over prior LLMs, narrowing the planner-LLM gap.
AI.motivation: Assess current end-to-end planning capabilities of frontier LLMs using PDDL prompts to quantify progress toward AI planning benchmarks and identify robustness to reasoning challenges.
AI.method: Compare three frontier LLMs—DeepSeek R1, Gemini 2.5 Pro, GPT-5—and LAMA as a reference on a subset of IPC Learning Track domains. Each model is prompted to produce a plan from PDDL domain and task descriptions, evaluating solved tasks under standard and obfuscated (pure reasoning) conditions.
AI.result: GPT-5's solved-task rate on standard PDDL domains is competitive with LAMA. When domains/tasks are obfuscated to test pure reasoning, all LLMs' performance declines, but less severely than some prior models. Overall, the work reports substantial improvements over earlier LLM generations, reducing the planner-LLM gap on a challenging benchmark.
AI.conclusion: Frontier LLMs are closing the gap with traditional planners for end-to-end planning on standard tasks, demonstrating robustness improvements; however, pure-reasoning weaknesses remain and future work should address deeper reasoning and generalization.

title: SPEED-Q: Staged Processing with Enhanced Distillation towards Efficient Low-bit On-device VLM Quantization
summary: Deploying Vision-Language Models (VLMs) on edge devices (e.g., smartphones and robots) is crucial for enabling low-latency and privacy-preserving intelligent applications. Given the resource constraints of these devices, quantization offers a promising solution by improving memory efficiency and reducing bandwidth requirements, thereby facilitating the deployment of VLMs. However, existing research has rarely explored aggressive quantization on VLMs, particularly for the models ranging from 1B to 2B parameters, which are more suitable for resource-constrained edge devices. In this paper, we propose SPEED-Q, a novel Staged Processing with Enhanced Distillation framework for VLM low-bit weight-only quantization that systematically addresses the following two critical obstacles: (1) significant discrepancies in quantization sensitivity between vision (ViT) and language (LLM) components in VLMs; (2) training instability arising from the reduced numerical precision inherent in low-bit quantization. In SPEED-Q, a staged sensitivity adaptive mechanism is introduced to effectively harmonize performance across different modalities. We further propose a distillation-enhanced quantization strategy to stabilize the training process and reduce data dependence. Together, SPEED-Q enables accurate, stable, and data-efficient quantization of complex VLMs. SPEED-Q is the first framework tailored for quantizing entire small-scale billion-parameter VLMs to low bits. Extensive experiments across multiple benchmarks demonstrate that SPEED-Q achieves up to 6x higher accuracy than existing quantization methods under 2-bit settings and consistently outperforms prior on-device VLMs under both 2-bit and 4-bit settings. Our code and models are available at https://github.com/antgroup/SPEED-Q.

AI.tldr: SPEED-Q is a framework for low-bit weight-only quantization of 1B–2B vision-language models, using staged processing with enhanced distillation to tackle modality sensitivity gaps and training instability, achieving up to 6x accuracy gains at 2-bit and robust performance at 4-bit.
AI.motivation: Deploying VLMs on edge devices requires aggressive compression to meet latency and memory limits. Existing quantization methods under-explore 1B–2B VLMs, and two key obstacles—unequal quantization sensitivity between vision (ViT) and language (LLM) components, and training instability from low-precision arithmetic—hinder practical edge deployment.
AI.method: Introduce a staged sensitivity adaptive mechanism to balance cross-modality quantization sensitivity, and a distillation-enhanced quantization strategy to stabilize training and reduce data dependence. The approach quantizes entire small-scale billion-parameter VLMs to low-bit weights (2-bit and 4-bit) with a focus on stability and data efficiency.
AI.result: Experiments show SPEED-Q achieves up to 6x higher accuracy than existing quantization methods under 2-bit settings and consistently outperforms prior on-device VLMs under both 2-bit and 4-bit settings.
AI.conclusion: SPEED-Q enables accurate, stable, and data-efficient quantization for complex VLMs, and is the first framework tailored to quantize entire small-scale 1B–2B VLMs to very low-bit weights. Code and models are available at the provided repository.

title: MAP-VLA: Memory-Augmented Prompting for Vision-Language-Action Model in Robotic Manipulation
summary: Pre-trained Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models have achieved remarkable success in improving robustness and generalization for end-to-end robotic manipulation. However, these models struggle with long-horizon tasks due to their lack of memory and reliance solely on immediate sensory inputs. To address this limitation, we propose Memory-Augmented Prompting for Vision-Language-Action model (MAP-VLA), a novel framework that empowers pre-trained VLA models with demonstration-derived memory prompts to augment action generation for long-horizon robotic manipulation tasks. To achieve this, MAP-VLA first constructs a memory library from historical demonstrations, where each memory unit captures information about a specific stage of a task. These memory units are implemented as learnable soft prompts optimized through prompt tuning. Then, during real-time task execution, MAP-VLA retrieves relevant memory through trajectory similarity matching and dynamically integrates it into the VLA model for augmented action generation. Importantly, this prompt tuning and retrieval augmentation approach operates as a plug-and-play module for a frozen VLA model, offering a lightweight and flexible solution to improve task performance. Experimental results show that MAP-VLA delivers up to 7.0% absolute performance gains in the simulation benchmark and 25.0% on real robot evaluations for long-horizon tasks, surpassing the current state-of-the-art methods.

AI.tldr: MAP-VLA introduces memory-augmented prompting for Vision-Language-Action models to handle long-horizon robotic tasks; builds a memory library of learnable prompts from demonstrations, retrieves via trajectory similarity, and plugs into frozen VLA models. It yields up to 7.0% absolute gains in simulation and 25.0% on real robots, outperforming SOTA.
AI.motivation: Identify the memory limitation in pre-trained VLA models that hinders long-horizon manipulation, due to reliance on only current sensory input.
AI.method: Construct a memory library from historical demonstrations with memory units as learnable soft prompts; retrieve relevant memory by trajectory similarity; integrate into the VLA model during execution; plug-and-play with frozen models.
AI.result: Up to 7.0% absolute gains in simulation; 25.0% on real robot evaluations; surpassing state-of-the-art.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates a lightweight, flexible plug-in memory augmentation via prompt tuning and retrieval to boost long-horizon robotic manipulation without retraining frozen VLA models.

title: DeepDR: an integrated deep-learning model web server for drug repositioning
summary: Background: Identifying new indications for approved drugs is a complex and time-consuming process that requires extensive knowledge of pharmacology, clinical data, and advanced computational methods. Recently, deep learning (DL) methods have shown their capability for the accurate prediction of drug repositioning. However, implementing DL-based modeling requires in-depth domain knowledge and proficient programming skills. Results: In this application, we introduce DeepDR, the first integrated platform that combines a variety of established DL-based models for disease- and target-specific drug repositioning tasks. DeepDR leverages invaluable experience to recommend candidate drugs, which covers more than 15 networks and a comprehensive knowledge graph that includes 5.9 million edges across 107 types of relationships connecting drugs, diseases, proteins/genes, pathways, and expression from six existing databases and a large scientific corpus of 24 million PubMed publications. Additionally, the recommended results include detailed descriptions of the recommended drugs and visualize key patterns with interpretability through a knowledge graph. Conclusion: DeepDR is free and open to all users without the requirement of registration. We believe it can provide an easy-to-use, systematic, highly accurate, and computationally automated platform for both experimental and computational scientists.

AI.tldr: DeepDR is an open, integrated platform for DL-based drug repositioning, combining 15+ models and a large knowledge graph (5.9M edges, 107 relation types, across drugs, diseases, proteins/genes, pathways, and expression) sourced from six databases and 24M PubMed publications to recommend candidate drugs with interpretability.
AI.motivation: Drug repositioning is complex and DL methods offer prediction capabilities but require deep domain knowledge and programming skills; a user-friendly, comprehensive platform could democratize and accelerate discovery.
AI.method: DeepDR integrates multiple established DL models for disease- and target-specific repositioning and builds a knowledge graph spanning 5.9 million edges across 107 relationship types, linking drugs, diseases, proteins/genes, pathways, and expression from six databases plus 24 million PubMed publications; results include detailed drug descriptions and visual, interpretable patterns via the KG.
AI.result: The platform DeepDR aggregates more than 15 networks and a large, multi-source knowledge graph to generate candidate drug recommendations with interpretability; it is freely accessible without registration.
AI.conclusion: DeepDR is a free, easy-to-use, systematic, and largely automated platform intended to aid both experimental and computational scientists in drug repositioning.

title: What We Don't C: Representations for scientific discovery beyond VAEs
comment: Accepted to the Machine Learning and the Physical Sciences workshop at NeurIPS 2025
summary: Accessing information in learned representations is critical for scientific discovery in high-dimensional domains. We introduce a novel method based on latent flow matching with classifier-free guidance that disentangles latent subspaces by explicitly separating information included in conditioning from information that remains in the residual representation. Across three experiments -- a synthetic 2D Gaussian toy problem, colored MNIST, and the Galaxy10 astronomy dataset -- we show that our method enables access to meaningful features of high dimensional data. Our results highlight a simple yet powerful mechanism for analyzing, controlling, and repurposing latent representations, providing a pathway toward using generative models for scientific exploration of what we don't capture, consider, or catalog.

AI.tldr: A latent flow matching approach with classifier-free guidance disentangles conditioning information from residual latent representation, enabling access to meaningful high-dimensional features. Demonstrated on a synthetic 2D Gaussian toy problem, colored MNIST, and Galaxy10 astronomy data, highlighting a mechanism to analyze, control, and repurpose latent representations for scientific exploration of what is not captured.
AI.motivation: To enable access to interpretable and controllable information in learned representations, facilitating scientific discovery in high-dimensional domains by separating conditioning information from the residual latent space.
AI.method: Latent flow matching with classifier-free guidance that explicitly partitions latent subspaces into information included in conditioning versus information remaining in the residual representation, demonstrated across three experiments.
AI.result: The method enables access to meaningful features of high-dimensional data and supports analysis, control, and repurposing of latent representations across diverse tasks.
AI.conclusion: Provides a simple yet powerful mechanism for analyzing and repurposing latent representations and points toward using generative models for scientific exploration of what is not captured or cataloged.

title: Machines Serve Human: A Novel Variable Human-machine Collaborative Compression Framework
summary: Human-machine collaborative compression has been receiving increasing research efforts for reducing image/video data, serving as the basis for both human perception and machine intelligence. Existing collaborative methods are dominantly built upon the de facto human-vision compression pipeline, witnessing deficiency on complexity and bit-rates when aggregating the machine-vision compression. Indeed, machine vision solely focuses on the core regions within the image/video, requiring much less information compared with the compressed information for human vision. In this paper, we thus set out the first successful attempt by a novel collaborative compression method based on the machine-vision-oriented compression, instead of human-vision pipeline. In other words, machine vision serves as the basis for human vision within collaborative compression. A plug-and-play variable bit-rate strategy is also developed for machine vision tasks. Then, we propose to progressively aggregate the semantics from the machine-vision compression, whilst seamlessly tailing the diffusion prior to restore high-fidelity details for human vision, thus named as diffusion-prior based feature compression for human and machine visions (Diff-FCHM). Experimental results verify the consistently superior performances of our Diff-FCHM, on both machine-vision and human-vision compression with remarkable margins. Our code will be released upon acceptance.

AI.tldr: A diffusion-prior based feature compression framework (Diff-FCHM) uses machine-vision–oriented compression as the basis and a plug-and-play variable bitrate, progressively aggregating semantics and refining with a diffusion prior to achieve high-fidelity results for both machine and human vision, outperforming traditional human-vision–driven pipelines.
AI.motivation: Existing collaborative compression largely follow human-vision pipelines, which are complex and inefficient when extended to machine-vision tasks. Machine vision concentrates on core regions and requires less information, suggesting a shift to a machine-vision–based basis could improve bitrate efficiency and fidelity for both human and machine perception.
AI.method: Propose Diff-FCHM: a machine-vision–oriented compression basis with a plug-and-play variable bitrate strategy. Semantics are progressively aggregated from the machine-vision compression, while a diffusion prior refines and restores high-fidelity details for human vision. This constitutes diffusion-prior based feature compression for both human and machine visions.
AI.result: Experimental results show consistently superior performance for both machine-vision and human-vision compression with remarkable margins compared to baselines.
AI.conclusion: This work represents the first successful attempt to base collaborative compression on a machine-vision pipeline. The diffusion prior enables high-fidelity restoration, and the approach supports variable bitrate and both vision modalities. Code will be released after acceptance.

title: SpatialActor: Exploring Disentangled Spatial Representations for Robust Robotic Manipulation
summary: Robotic manipulation requires precise spatial understanding to interact with objects in the real world. Point-based methods suffer from sparse sampling, leading to the loss of fine-grained semantics. Image-based methods typically feed RGB and depth into 2D backbones pre-trained on 3D auxiliary tasks, but their entangled semantics and geometry are sensitive to inherent depth noise in real-world that disrupts semantic understanding. Moreover, these methods focus on high-level geometry while overlooking low-level spatial cues essential for precise interaction. We propose SpatialActor, a disentangled framework for robust robotic manipulation that explicitly decouples semantics and geometry. The Semantic-guided Geometric Module adaptively fuses two complementary geometry from noisy depth and semantic-guided expert priors. Also, a Spatial Transformer leverages low-level spatial cues for accurate 2D-3D mapping and enables interaction among spatial features. We evaluate SpatialActor on multiple simulation and real-world scenarios across 50+ tasks. It achieves state-of-the-art performance with 87.4% on RLBench and improves by 13.9% to 19.4% under varying noisy conditions, showing strong robustness. Moreover, it significantly enhances few-shot generalization to new tasks and maintains robustness under various spatial perturbations. Project Page: https://shihao1895.github.io/SpatialActor

AI.tldr: SpatialActor disentangles semantics and geometry for robust robotic manipulation, combining a semantic-guided geometric module with a spatial transformer to fuse noisy depth priors and low-level cues, achieving state-of-the-art performance and strong robustness/generalization.
AI.motivation: Current approaches either sample sparsely at points or rely on image-based 2D backbones that entangle semantics and geometry and are sensitive to depth noise, leading to degraded semantic understanding and interaction precision. A disentangled framework is proposed to address these gaps.
AI.method: Propose SpatialActor with a Semantic-guided Geometric Module that adaptively fuses geometry from noisy depth with semantic priors, and a Spatial Transformer that leverages low-level spatial cues for accurate 2D-3D mapping and interaction among spatial features.
AI.result: Evaluated on 50+ tasks across simulation and real world, achieving state-of-the-art RLBench score (87.4%). Robustness gains under noisy conditions range from 13.9% to 19.4% across varying noise. Also improves few-shot generalization and maintains robustness under spatial perturbations.
AI.conclusion: Disentangling semantics and geometry with semantic priors and low-level spatial cues yields robust, generalizable robotic manipulation. SpatialActor offers strong empirical gains and a viable path toward reliable real-world deployment.

title: Diffusion Policies with Value-Conditional Optimization for Offline Reinforcement Learning
summary: In offline reinforcement learning, value overestimation caused by out-of-distribution (OOD) actions significantly limits policy performance. Recently, diffusion models have been leveraged for their strong distribution-matching capabilities, enforcing conservatism through behavior policy constraints. However, existing methods often apply indiscriminate regularization to redundant actions in low-quality datasets, resulting in excessive conservatism and an imbalance between the expressiveness and efficiency of diffusion modeling. To address these issues, we propose DIffusion policies with Value-conditional Optimization (DIVO), a novel approach that leverages diffusion models to generate high-quality, broadly covered in-distribution state-action samples while facilitating efficient policy improvement. Specifically, DIVO introduces a binary-weighted mechanism that utilizes the advantage values of actions in the offline dataset to guide diffusion model training. This enables a more precise alignment with the dataset's distribution while selectively expanding the boundaries of high-advantage actions. During policy improvement, DIVO dynamically filters high-return-potential actions from the diffusion model, effectively guiding the learned policy toward better performance. This approach achieves a critical balance between conservatism and explorability in offline RL. We evaluate DIVO on the D4RL benchmark and compare it against state-of-the-art baselines. Empirical results demonstrate that DIVO achieves superior performance, delivering significant improvements in average returns across locomotion tasks and outperforming existing methods in the challenging AntMaze domain, where sparse rewards pose a major difficulty.

AI.tldr: DIVO uses diffusion models with a value-guided binary weighting strategy to selectively regularize OOD actions in offline RL, enabling targeted exploration of high-advantage actions and improving policy performance, especially in sparse-reward tasks like AntMaze.
AI.motivation: Offline RL suffers from value overestimation due to out-of-distribution (OOD) actions. Diffusion models offer strong distribution alignment and can enforce conservatism, but existing methods apply broad regularization, causing excessive conservatism and reducing expressiveness. There's a need for selective, action-value-informed regularization to balance conservatism and exploration.
AI.method: DIVO introduces a binary-weighted mechanism that uses action advantages from the offline dataset to train diffusion models, aligning sampling with the dataset and selectively expanding high-advantage actions. During policy improvement, it dynamically filters high-return-potential actions from the diffusion model to steer learning toward better performance, achieving a balance between conservatism and explorability.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on the D4RL benchmark shows that DIVO achieves superior performance, with notable gains in average returns across locomotion tasks and strong performance in the AntMaze domain, where sparse rewards are challenging.
AI.conclusion: DIVO demonstrates that a diffusion-based offline RL approach with value-conditional optimization can effectively balance conservatism and explorability, improving policy performance while maintaining dataset-aligned sampling and targeted expansion of high-value actions.

title: CrochetBench: Can Vision-Language Models Move from Describing to Doing in Crochet Domain?
summary: We present CrochetBench, a benchmark for evaluating the ability of multimodal large language models to perform fine-grained, low-level procedural reasoning in the domain of crochet. Unlike prior benchmarks that focus on high-level description or visual question answering, CrochetBench shifts the emphasis from describing to doing: models are required to recognize stitches, select structurally appropriate instructions, and generate compilable crochet procedures. We adopt the CrochetPARADE DSL as our intermediate representation, enabling structural validation and functional evaluation via execution. The benchmark covers tasks including stitch classification, instruction grounding, and both natural language and image-to-DSL translation. Across all tasks, performance sharply declines as the evaluation shifts from surface-level similarity to executable correctness, exposing limitations in long-range symbolic reasoning and 3D-aware procedural synthesis. CrochetBench offers a new lens for assessing procedural competence in multimodal models and highlights the gap between surface-level understanding and executable precision in real-world creative domains. Code is available at https://github.com/Peiyu-Georgia-Li/crochetBench.

AI.tldr: CrochetBench introduces a multimodal benchmark to assess procedural, low-level crochet task performance in LLMs, using CrochetPARADE DSL for validation and execution and spanning stitch classification, grounding, and NL/image-to-DSL translation.
AI.motivation: To evaluate procedural competence of multimodal LLMs in creative, 3D-aware domains and reveal the gap between surface-level understanding and executable, long-range symbolic reasoning.
AI.method: Tasks include stitch classification, instruction grounding, natural language and image-to-DSL translation. The CrochetPARADE DSL serves as the intermediate representation enabling structural checks and executable evaluation.
AI.result: Performance drops sharply when moving from surface similarity to executable correctness, highlighting limitations in long-range symbolic reasoning and 3D-aware procedural synthesis.
AI.conclusion: CrochetBench provides a new lens for assessing procedural competence in multimodal models; it exposes a gap between surface understanding and executable precision; code at GitHub.

title: From Structure to Detail: Hierarchical Distillation for Efficient Diffusion Model
summary: The inference latency of diffusion models remains a critical barrier to their real-time application. While trajectory-based and distribution-based step distillation methods offer solutions, they present a fundamental trade-off. Trajectory-based methods preserve global structure but act as a "lossy compressor", sacrificing high-frequency details. Conversely, distribution-based methods can achieve higher fidelity but often suffer from mode collapse and unstable training. This paper recasts them from independent paradigms into synergistic components within our novel Hierarchical Distillation (HD) framework. We leverage trajectory distillation not as a final generator, but to establish a structural ``sketch", providing a near-optimal initialization for the subsequent distribution-based refinement stage. This strategy yields an ideal initial distribution that enhances the ceiling of overall performance. To further improve quality, we introduce and refine the adversarial training process. We find standard discriminator structures are ineffective at refining an already high-quality generator. To overcome this, we introduce the Adaptive Weighted Discriminator (AWD), tailored for the HD pipeline. By dynamically allocating token weights, AWD focuses on local imperfections, enabling efficient detail refinement. Our approach demonstrates state-of-the-art performance across diverse tasks. On ImageNet $256\times256$, our single-step model achieves an FID of 2.26, rivaling its 250-step teacher. It also achieves promising results on the high-resolution text-to-image MJHQ benchmark, proving its generalizability. Our method establishes a robust new paradigm for high-fidelity, single-step diffusion models.

AI.tldr: A hierarchical distillation framework that merges trajectory sketching with distribution refinement, plus an adaptive discriminator, enabling high-fidelity single-step diffusion with state-of-the-art results.
AI.motivation: Diffusion models suffer from high inference latency; existing step-distillation methods trade off either global structure (losing high-frequency details) or fidelity (mode collapse, unstable training).
AI.method: Use Hierarchical Distillation (HD): first apply trajectory distillation to generate a structural sketch; initialize the subsequent distribution-based refinement with a near-optimal distribution; refine via adversarial training using Adaptive Weighted Discriminator (AWD) that dynamically weights tokens to focus on local imperfections.
AI.result: Achieves 2.26 FID on ImageNet 256x256 with a single-step model rivaling a 250-step teacher; shows promising results on high-resolution MJHQ benchmark; demonstrates robustness and generalizability across diverse tasks.
AI.conclusion: HD establishes a robust new paradigm for high-fidelity, single-step diffusion models, achieving state-of-the-art performance and strong generalization.

title: IFG: Internet-Scale Guidance for Functional Grasping Generation
summary: Large Vision Models trained on internet-scale data have demonstrated strong capabilities in segmenting and semantically understanding object parts, even in cluttered, crowded scenes. However, while these models can direct a robot toward the general region of an object, they lack the geometric understanding required to precisely control dexterous robotic hands for 3D grasping. To overcome this, our key insight is to leverage simulation with a force-closure grasping generation pipeline that understands local geometries of the hand and object in the scene. Because this pipeline is slow and requires ground-truth observations, the resulting data is distilled into a diffusion model that operates in real-time on camera point clouds. By combining the global semantic understanding of internet-scale models with the geometric precision of a simulation-based locally-aware force-closure, \our achieves high-performance semantic grasping without any manually collected training data. For visualizations of this please visit our website at https://ifgrasping.github.io/

AI.tldr: A method that fuses internet-scale vision model semantics with a diffusion-based, simulation-generated, real-time grasping model to achieve semantic grasping without manually labeled data.
AI.motivation: Bridge the gap between high-level semantic understanding and low-level geometric control for 3D grasping; reduce dependence on manually labeled data by distilling simulation data into a real-time model.
AI.method: Use a force-closure grasping pipeline in simulation to capture local geometry relationships; distill this into a diffusion model that operates on camera point clouds; combine with the semantic cues from large vision models.
AI.result: Demonstrates high-performance semantic grasping in cluttered scenes without manually collected training data, with real-time inference on point clouds.
AI.conclusion: Merges global semantic understanding with local geometric precision to enable robust autonomous semantic grasping; eliminates need for manually labeled data.

title: TransactionGPT
summary: We present TransactionGPT (TGPT), a foundation model for consumer transaction data within one of world's largest payment networks. TGPT is designed to understand and generate transaction trajectories while simultaneously supporting a variety of downstream prediction and classification tasks. We introduce a novel 3D-Transformer architecture specifically tailored for capturing the complex dynamics in payment transaction data. This architecture incorporates design innovations that enhance modality fusion and computational efficiency, while seamlessly enabling joint optimization with downstream objectives. Trained on billion-scale real-world transactions, TGPT significantly improves downstream classification performance against a competitive production model and exhibits advantages over baselines in generating future transactions. We conduct extensive empirical evaluations utilizing a diverse collection of company transaction datasets spanning multiple downstream tasks, thereby enabling a thorough assessment of TGPT's effectiveness and efficiency in comparison to established methodologies. Furthermore, we examine the incorporation of LLM-derived embeddings within TGPT and benchmark its performance against fine-tuned LLMs, demonstrating that TGPT achieves superior predictive accuracy as well as faster training and inference. We anticipate that the architectural innovations and practical guidelines from this work will advance foundation models for transaction-like data and catalyze future research in this emerging field.

AI.tldr: TGPT is a 3D-Transformer foundation model for consumer transaction data that can both predict/classify and generate transaction trajectories; trained on billion-scale data; improves downstream tasks and generation; integrates LLM-derived embeddings; validated across diverse datasets.
AI.motivation: Capture complex dynamics in payment transactions, enable joint optimization with downstream tasks, and improve prediction/generation efficiency across large-scale data networks.
AI.method: Introduce a novel 3D-Transformer architecture optimized for modality fusion and efficiency; enable joint optimization with downstream objectives; train on billion-scale real-world transactions; evaluate on multiple datasets; assess LLM-derived embeddings vs fine-tuned LLMs.
AI.result: TGPT improves downstream classification performance over a competitive production model; outperforms baselines in generating future transactions; LLM-derived embeddings with TGPT yield superior predictive accuracy and faster training/inference.
AI.conclusion: Architectural innovations and practical guidelines from TGPT can advance foundation models for transaction-like data and spur future research in this emerging field.

title: Consensus Sampling for Safer Generative AI
summary: Many approaches to AI safety rely on inspecting model outputs or activations, yet certain risks are inherently undetectable by inspection alone. We propose a complementary, architecture-agnostic approach that enhances safety through the aggregation of multiple generative models, with the aggregated model inheriting its safety from the safest subset of a given size among them. Specifically, we present a consensus sampling algorithm that, given $k$ models and a prompt, achieves risk competitive with the average risk of the safest $s$ of the $k$ models, where $s$ is a chosen parameter, while abstaining when there is insufficient agreement between them. The approach leverages the models' ability to compute output probabilities, and we bound the probability of abstention when sufficiently many models are safe and exhibit adequate agreement. The algorithm is inspired by the provable copyright protection algorithm of Vyas et al. (2023). It requires some overlap among safe models, offers no protection when all models are unsafe, and may accumulate risk over repeated use. Nonetheless, our results provide a new, model-agnostic approach for AI safety by amplifying safety guarantees from an unknown subset of models within a collection to that of a single reliable model.

AI.tldr: Proposes a consensus sampling ensemble that aggregates k generative models to inherit safety from the safest s models, with abstention on lack of agreement; a model-agnostic safety amplification with risk comparable to the safest subset.
