AI.motivation: Many AI safety concerns are not detectable by inspecting outputs or activations. An architecture-agnostic method that leverages agreement across multiple models can provide safety guarantees even when individual models are unsafe.
AI.method: Consensus sampling: given k models and a prompt, select outputs based on their probabilities to achieve an aggregate with safety comparable to the average risk of the safest s models. Abstain if models disagree beyond a threshold. Bound abstention probability when enough safe models agree. Inspired by Vyas et al. (2023).
AI.result: The aggregated consensus achieves risk competitive with the average risk of the safest s models among the k, with a provable abstention bound under sufficient overlap among safe models.
AI.conclusion: Offers a new, model-agnostic safety amplification approach that transfers safety guarantees from an unknown subset of safe models to a single reliable model, while noting limitations: requires overlap among safe models, does not protect when all are unsafe, and may accumulate risk over repeated use.

title: Boosting Adversarial Transferability via Ensemble Non-Attention
summary: Ensemble attacks integrate the outputs of surrogate models with diverse architectures, which can be combined with various gradient-based attacks to improve adversarial transferability. However, previous work shows unsatisfactory attack performance when transferring across heterogeneous model architectures. The main reason is that the gradient update directions of heterogeneous surrogate models differ widely, making it hard to reduce the gradient variance of ensemble models while making the best of individual model. To tackle this challenge, we design a novel ensemble attack, NAMEA, which for the first time integrates the gradients from the non-attention areas of ensemble models into the iterative gradient optimization process. Our design is inspired by the observation that the attention areas of heterogeneous models vary sharply, thus the non-attention areas of ViTs are likely to be the focus of CNNs and vice versa. Therefore, we merge the gradients respectively from the attention and non-attention areas of ensemble models so as to fuse the transfer information of CNNs and ViTs. Specifically, we pioneer a new way of decoupling the gradients of non-attention areas from those of attention areas, while merging gradients by meta-learning. Empirical evaluations on ImageNet dataset indicate that NAMEA outperforms AdaEA and SMER, the state-of-the-art ensemble attacks by an average of 15.0% and 9.6%, respectively. This work is the first attempt to explore the power of ensemble non-attention in boosting cross-architecture transferability, providing new insights into launching ensemble attacks.

AI.tldr: NAMEA is an ensemble adversarial attack that decouples gradients from attention and non-attention regions across CNNs and ViTs, then fuses them via meta-learning to improve cross-architecture transferability, showing substantial gains on ImageNet over AdaEA and SMER.
AI.motivation: Cross-architecture transferability remains poor because heterogeneous surrogate models have divergent gradient directions, and prior ensemble methods cannot effectively exploit complementary regions (attention vs non-attention) across architectures.
AI.method: Compute gradients from both attention and non-attention areas for each model in the ensemble (e.g., ViTs' attention maps and CNNs' corresponding non-attended regions), decouple these components, and merge them using a meta-learning framework to guide iterative adversarial perturbations.
AI.result: On ImageNet, NAMEA outperforms AdaEA and SMER by an average of 15.0% and 9.6%, respectively, indicating improved cross-architecture transferability.
AI.conclusion: First to exploit ensemble non-attention gradients to boost cross-architecture transferability; demonstrates a new direction for ensemble attacks and provides insights into leveraging complementary regions across model architectures.

title: QIBONN: A Quantum-Inspired Bilevel Optimizer for Neural Networks on Tabular Classification
comment: 6 pages, 3 figures, 3 tables. Accepted at IEEE International Conference on Big Data 2025
summary: Hyperparameter optimization (HPO) for neural networks on tabular data is critical to a wide range of applications, yet it remains challenging due to large, non-convex search spaces and the cost of exhaustive tuning. We introduce the Quantum-Inspired Bilevel Optimizer for Neural Networks (QIBONN), a bilevel framework that encodes feature selection, architectural hyperparameters, and regularization in a unified qubit-based representation. By combining deterministic quantum-inspired rotations with stochastic qubit mutations guided by a global attractor, QIBONN balances exploration and exploitation under a fixed evaluation budget. We conduct systematic experiments under single-qubit bit-flip noise (0.1\%--1\%) emulated by an IBM-Q backend. Results on 13 real-world datasets indicate that QIBONN is competitive with established methods, including classical tree-based methods and both classical/quantum-inspired HPO algorithms under the same tuning budget.

AI.tldr: A quantum-inspired bilevel optimizer (QIBONN) for neural networks on tabular data encodes feature selection, architecture, and regularization in a qubit-based representation, using deterministic rotations and stochastic mutations with a global attractor, evaluated under IBM-Q noise and fixed budget, showing competitive performance vs classical and quantum-inspired HPO methods.
AI.motivation: Hyperparameter optimization for neural networks on tabular data is challenging due to large non-convex search spaces and costly tuning; there is a need for efficient, budget-aware HPO methods, including quantum-inspired approaches.
AI.method: A bilevel framework (QIBONN) that encodes hyperparameters (feature selection, architectural choices, regularization) into a qubit-based representation. It combines deterministic quantum-inspired rotations with stochastic qubit mutations guided by a global attractor, to balance exploration and exploitation under a fixed evaluation budget. Noise is emulated as single-qubit bit-flip errors (0.1%-1%) on IBM-Q backend. Experiments assess performance under these conditions.
AI.result: On 13 real-world datasets, QIBONN is competitive with established methods, including classical tree-based methods and both classical- and quantum-inspired HPO algorithms, under the same tuning budget.
AI.conclusion: QIBONN demonstrates competitive performance under realistic noise and budget constraints, supporting quantum-inspired hyperparameter optimization as a viable approach for tabular neural networks; results motivate further exploration of qubit-based representations for HPO and robustness to hardware-like noise.

title: Fundamentals of Physical AI
comment: This paper is already published in Journal of Intelligent System of Systems Lifecycle Management
summary: This work will elaborate the fundamental principles of physical artificial intelligence (Physical AI) from a scientific and systemic perspective. The aim is to create a theoretical foundation that describes the physical embodiment, sensory perception, ability to act, learning processes, and context sensitivity of intelligent systems within a coherent framework. While classical AI approaches rely on symbolic processing and data driven models, Physical AI understands intelligence as an emergent phenomenon of real interaction between body, environment, and experience. The six fundamentals presented here are embodiment, sensory perception, motor action, learning, autonomy, and context sensitivity, and form the conceptual basis for designing and evaluating physically intelligent systems. Theoretically, it is shown that these six principles do not represent loose functional modules but rather act as a closed control loop in which energy, information, control, and context are in constant interaction. This circular interaction enables a system to generate meaning not from databases, but from physical experience, a paradigm shift that understands intelligence as an physical embodied process. Physical AI understands learning not as parameter adjustment, but as a change in the structural coupling between agents and the environment. To illustrate this, the theoretical model is explained using a practical scenario: An adaptive assistant robot supports patients in a rehabilitation clinic. This example illustrates that physical intelligence does not arise from abstract calculation, but from immediate, embodied experience. It shows how the six fundamentals interact in a real system: embodiment as a prerequisite, perception as input, movement as expression, learning as adaptation, autonomy as regulation, and context as orientation.

AI.tldr: A theory of Physical AI where intelligence arises from embodied interaction; six fundamentals form a closed loop; learning is structural coupling; illustrated with an adaptive robot example.
AI.motivation: To shift from symbolic/data-driven AI to embodied, interaction-based intelligence and establish a theoretical foundation for physically intelligent systems.
AI.method: Proposes a theoretical framework with six fundamentals (embodiment, perception, action, learning, autonomy, context) operating as a closed loop integrating energy, information, control, and context; uses a practical rehab-robot scenario to illustrate.
AI.result: A conceptual model is articulated in which the six principles act as a closed control loop, with meaning arising from physical experience; learning is reframing the coupling between agent and environment rather than parameter tuning; demonstrated conceptually via an adaptive assistant robot in rehabilitation.
AI.conclusion: Advances a paradigm shift to treat intelligence as a physically embodied process and offers guidance for designing and evaluating physically intelligent systems.

title: Neural B-frame Video Compression with Bi-directional Reference Harmonization
summary: Neural video compression (NVC) has made significant progress in recent years, while neural B-frame video compression (NBVC) remains underexplored compared to P-frame compression. NBVC can adopt bi-directional reference frames for better compression performance. However, NBVC's hierarchical coding may complicate continuous temporal prediction, especially at some hierarchical levels with a large frame span, which could cause the contribution of the two reference frames to be unbalanced. To optimize reference information utilization, we propose a novel NBVC method, termed Bi-directional Reference Harmonization Video Compression (BRHVC), with the proposed Bi-directional Motion Converge (BMC) and Bi-directional Contextual Fusion (BCF). BMC converges multiple optical flows in motion compression, leading to more accurate motion compensation on a larger scale. Then BCF explicitly models the weights of reference contexts under the guidance of motion compensation accuracy. With more efficient motions and contexts, BRHVC can effectively harmonize bi-directional references. Experimental results indicate that our BRHVC outperforms previous state-of-the-art NVC methods, even surpassing the traditional coding, VTM-RA (under random access configuration), on the HEVC datasets. The source code is released at https://github.com/kwai/NVC.

AI.tldr: BRHVC harmonizes bi-directional references in NBVC using Bi-directional Motion Converge (BMC) and Bi-directional Contextual Fusion (BCF) to improve motion compensation and reference weighting, achieving state-of-the-art results on HEVC datasets and even surpassing VTM-RA in random-access tests; code released.
AI.motivation: Bi-directional reference frames offer compression gains in NBVC but hierarchical coding can lead to unbalanced contribution from references and poor continuous temporal prediction, motivating a method to better utilize reference information.
AI.method: Introduce BRHVC with two components: (1) Bi-directional Motion Converge (BMC) that aggregates multiple optical flows for more accurate motion compensation over larger time spans; (2) Bi-directional Contextual Fusion (BCF) that learns weights for reference contexts guided by motion compensation accuracy, enabling harmonious use of bidirectional references.
AI.result: BRHVC outperforms prior neural video compression methods and even surpasses traditional coding (VTM-RA) under random-access configuration on HEVC datasets.
AI.conclusion: BRHVC effectively harmonizes bi-directional references in NBVC by jointly improving motion and contextual modeling, achieving superior compression performance and demonstrating the viability of bidirectional reference harmonization; source code is released.

title: Robust Backdoor Removal by Reconstructing Trigger-Activated Changes in Latent Representation
summary: Backdoor attacks pose a critical threat to machine learning models, causing them to behave normally on clean data but misclassify poisoned data into a poisoned class. Existing defenses often attempt to identify and remove backdoor neurons based on Trigger-Activated Changes (TAC) which is the activation differences between clean and poisoned data. These methods suffer from low precision in identifying true backdoor neurons due to inaccurate estimation of TAC values. In this work, we propose a novel backdoor removal method by accurately reconstructing TAC values in the latent representation. Specifically, we formulate the minimal perturbation that forces clean data to be classified into a specific class as a convex quadratic optimization problem, whose optimal solution serves as a surrogate for TAC. We then identify the poisoned class by detecting statistically small $L^2$ norms of perturbations and leverage the perturbation of the poisoned class in fine-tuning to remove backdoors. Experiments on CIFAR-10, GTSRB, and TinyImageNet demonstrated that our approach consistently achieves superior backdoor suppression with high clean accuracy across different attack types, datasets, and architectures, outperforming existing defense methods.

AI.tldr: A convex optimization-based TAC reconstruction method improves backdoor removal by estimating perturbations that push clean samples to a target class, enabling poisoned-class identification and effective fine-tuning; achieves high clean accuracy and outperforms prior defenses on multiple datasets.
AI.motivation: Backdoor attacks degrade model reliability by triggering misclassification; previous TAC-based defenses suffer from imprecise TAC estimates leading to low precision in backdoor neuron identification.
AI.method: Formulate minimal perturbation that forces clean data into a specific class as a convex quadratic program; use the optimal perturbation as a TAC surrogate; identify poisoned class via small L2-norm perturbations; fine-tune using the poisoned-class perturbation to remove backdoors.
AI.result: Empirical results on CIFAR-10, GTSRB, and TinyImageNet show consistent superior backdoor suppression with high clean accuracy across attack types, datasets, and architectures; outperforms existing defenses.
AI.conclusion: Accurate TAC reconstruction in latent space enables precise backdoor removal and robust defense across settings.

title: Robust and Diverse Multi-Agent Learning via Rational Policy Gradient
summary: Adversarial optimization algorithms that explicitly search for flaws in agents' policies have been successfully applied to finding robust and diverse policies in multi-agent settings. However, the success of adversarial optimization has been largely limited to zero-sum settings because its naive application in cooperative settings leads to a critical failure mode: agents are irrationally incentivized to self-sabotage, blocking the completion of tasks and halting further learning. To address this, we introduce Rationality-preserving Policy Optimization (RPO), a formalism for adversarial optimization that avoids self-sabotage by ensuring agents remain rational--that is, their policies are optimal with respect to some possible partner policy. To solve RPO, we develop Rational Policy Gradient (RPG), which trains agents to maximize their own reward in a modified version of the original game in which we use opponent shaping techniques to optimize the adversarial objective. RPG enables us to extend a variety of existing adversarial optimization algorithms that, no longer subject to the limitations of self-sabotage, can find adversarial examples, improve robustness and adaptability, and learn diverse policies. We empirically validate that our approach achieves strong performance in several popular cooperative and general-sum environments. Our project page can be found at https://rational-policy-gradient.github.io.

AI.tldr: RPO/RPG enforce rationality to enable adversarial optimization in cooperative/general-sum settings, avoiding self-sabotage and enabling robust, diverse policies; validated empirically.
AI.motivation: Existing adversarial optimization excels in zero-sum settings but causes self-sabotage in cooperative/general-sum contexts. The work aims to keep agents rational—policies optimal against potential partner policies—to extend adversarial methods beyond zero-sum.
AI.method: Introduce Rationality-preserving Policy Optimization (RPO) as a formalism. Develop Rational Policy Gradient (RPG) which trains agents to maximize their own reward in a modified game using opponent shaping to optimize the adversarial objective. This framework allows attaching adversarial optimization to existing methods without inducing self-sabotage.
AI.result: Empirically demonstrates strong performance in several cooperative and general-sum environments. RPG enables extending adversarial optimization to non-zero-sum settings, fostering robust, adaptable, and diverse policies.
AI.conclusion: RPO/RPG generalize adversarial optimization to broader multi-agent settings by preserving rationality, enabling robust adversaries and diverse policies across cooperative and general-sum tasks.

title: FGM-HD: Boosting Generation Diversity of Fractal Generative Models through Hausdorff Dimension Induction
summary: Improving the diversity of generated results while maintaining high visual quality remains a significant challenge in image generation tasks. Fractal Generative Models (FGMs) are efficient in generating high-quality images, but their inherent self-similarity limits the diversity of output images. To address this issue, we propose a novel approach based on the Hausdorff Dimension (HD), a widely recognized concept in fractal geometry used to quantify structural complexity, which aids in enhancing the diversity of generated outputs. To incorporate HD into FGM, we propose a learnable HD estimation method that predicts HD directly from image embeddings, addressing computational cost concerns. However, simply introducing HD into a hybrid loss is insufficient to enhance diversity in FGMs due to: 1) degradation of image quality, and 2) limited improvement in generation diversity. To this end, during training, we adopt an HD-based loss with a monotonic momentum-driven scheduling strategy to progressively optimize the hyperparameters, obtaining optimal diversity without sacrificing visual quality. Moreover, during inference, we employ HD-guided rejection sampling to select geometrically richer outputs. Extensive experiments on the ImageNet dataset demonstrate that our FGM-HD framework yields a 39\% improvement in output diversity compared to vanilla FGMs, while preserving comparable image quality. To our knowledge, this is the very first work introducing HD into FGM. Our method effectively enhances the diversity of generated outputs while offering a principled theoretical contribution to FGM development.

AI.tldr: Proposes FGM-HD, a Fractal Generative Model augmented with a learnable Hausdorff Dimension to boost output diversity while preserving visual quality. Utilizes HD-based loss with a monotonic momentum-driven schedule and HD-guided rejection sampling; reports 39% diversity gain on ImageNet vs vanilla FGMs.
AI.motivation: Diversity in fractal-style generative models is limited by self-similarity; HD provides a measure of structural complexity to encourage richer outputs without sacrificing quality.
AI.method: Introduce a learnable HD estimator predicting HD from image embeddings; integrate into a hybrid loss with monotonic scheduling; train with evolving hyperparameters; at inference, apply rejection sampling guided by HD to select geometrically richer outputs.
AI.result: On ImageNet, achieves 39% improvement in output diversity relative to vanilla FGMs while maintaining comparable image quality.
AI.conclusion: First work to integrate HD into FGM; provides a principled, theoretically informed route to enhance diversity with minimal quality loss, opening new avenues for fractal-based generative modeling.

title: Improving Conditional VAE with approximation using Normalizing Flows
summary: Variational Autoencoders and Generative Adversarial Networks remained the state-of-the-art (SOTA) generative models until 2022. Now they are superseded by diffusion based models. Efforts to improve traditional models have stagnated as a result. In old-school fashion, we explore image generation with conditional Variational Autoencoders (CVAE) to incorporate desired attributes within the images. VAEs are known to produce blurry images with less diversity, we refer a method that solve this issue by leveraging the variance of the gaussian decoder as a learnable parameter during training. Previous works on CVAEs assumed that the conditional distribution of the latent space given the labels is equal to the prior distribution, which is not the case in reality. We show that estimating it using normalizing flows results in better image generation than existing methods by reducing the FID by 5% and increasing log likelihood by 7.7% than the previous case.

AI.tldr: Conditional VAEs with learnable decoder variance and flow-based posterior p(z|y) improve image generation compared to standard CVAEs, achieving better FID and log-likelihood.
AI.motivation: Address blur and limited diversity of VAEs and realism gaps in CVAEs due to the assumption p(z|y)=p(z); model the conditional latent distribution to improve generation metrics.
AI.method: Extend CVAE with a learnable Gaussian variance in the decoder to reduce blurriness; replace the standard assumption p(z|y)=p(z) with a normalizing-flow-based estimate of p(z|y) to better capture the conditional latent distribution during training.
AI.result: FID improved by about 5% and log-likelihood increased by about 7.7% over the previous approach that assumed p(z|y)=p(z).
AI.conclusion: Modeling the conditional latent distribution with normalizing flows along with a learnable decoder variance yields better generative performance for CVAEs, addressing blurriness and diversity issues.

title: Breadth-First Search vs. Restarting Random Walks for Escaping Uninformed Heuristic Regions
summary: Greedy search methods like Greedy Best-First Search (GBFS) and Enforced Hill-Climbing (EHC) often struggle when faced with Uninformed Heuristic Regions (UHRs) like heuristic local minima or plateaus. In this work, we theoretically and empirically compare two popular methods for escaping UHRs in breadth-first search (BrFS) and restarting random walks (RRWs). We first derive the expected runtime of escaping a UHR using BrFS and RRWs, based on properties of the UHR and the random walk procedure, and then use these results to identify when RRWs will be faster in expectation than BrFS. We then evaluate these methods for escaping UHRs by comparing standard EHC, which uses BrFS to escape UHRs, to variants of EHC called EHC-RRW, which use RRWs for that purpose. EHC-RRW is shown to have strong expected runtime guarantees in cases where EHC has previously been shown to be effective. We also run experiments with these approaches on PDDL planning benchmarks to better understand their relative effectiveness for escaping UHRs.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes escaping uninformed heuristic regions (UHRs) in search, comparing breadth-first escape (BrFS) vs restarting random walks (RRWs); derives their expected escape runtimes, identifies regimes where RRWs are faster, introduces EHC-RRW variants, and validates findings on PDDL benchmarks.
AI.motivation: UHRs like local minima and plateaus hinder greedy search methods. The work provides theoretical and empirical guidance on escape strategies and aims to improve EHC performance in planning.
AI.method: 1) Derive the expected escape time from a UHR for BrFS and RRWs using properties of the UHR and the random walk process. 2) Identify regimes where RRWs have lower expected escape time. 3) Propose EHC-RRW variants that use RRWs to escape UHRs. 4) Empirically evaluate EHC vs EHC-RRW on PDDL planning benchmarks.
AI.result: Analytical results show RRWs can be faster in expectation than BrFS in certain UHR regimes. EHC-RRW provides strong expected runtime guarantees in cases where EHC is effective. Experiments on PDDL benchmarks corroborate the theoretical predictions and illustrate practical performance differences.
AI.conclusion: RRWs offer a robust alternative to BrFS for escaping UHRs in EHC, with EHC-RRW showing promising theoretical guarantees and empirical performance. Further work could refine regime identification and adaptive strategies.

title: AuthSig: Safeguarding Scanned Signatures Against Unauthorized Reuse in Paperless Workflows
summary: With the deepening trend of paperless workflows, signatures as a means of identity authentication are gradually shifting from traditional ink-on-paper to electronic formats.Despite the availability of dynamic pressure-sensitive and PKI-based digital signatures, static scanned signatures remain prevalent in practice due to their convenience. However, these static images, having almost lost their authentication attributes, cannot be reliably verified and are vulnerable to malicious copying and reuse. To address these issues, we propose AuthSig, a novel static electronic signature framework based on generative models and watermark, which binds authentication information to the signature image. Leveraging the human visual system's insensitivity to subtle style variations, AuthSig finely modulates style embeddings during generation to implicitly encode watermark bits-enforcing a One Signature, One Use policy.To overcome the scarcity of handwritten signature data and the limitations of traditional augmentation methods, we introduce a keypoint-driven data augmentation strategy that effectively enhances style diversity to support robust watermark embedding. Experimental results show that AuthSig achieves over 98% extraction accuracy under both digital-domain distortions and signature-specific degradations, and remains effective even in print-scan scenarios.

AI.tldr: AuthSig binds authentication data to static signature images using generative-model-based style modulation and watermarking, enabling One Signature, One Use with strong robustness to distortions including print-scan.
AI.motivation: Static scanned signatures are prevalent but insecure; need reliable verification and binding of authentication data into the signature; address scarcity of handwriting data and support for paperless workflows.
AI.method: Keypoint-driven data augmentation to diversify style; generative model to modulate style embeddings while embedding watermark bits; watermark system enforces One Signature, One Use, binding auth info to the signature image.
AI.result: Extraction accuracy >98% under digital-domain distortions and signature degradations; robust to print-scan scenarios.
AI.conclusion: Proposes a practical static e-signature framework that improves security and verifiability while maintaining convenience, demonstrated to be robust in real-world degradations.

title: HOTFLoc++: End-to-End Hierarchical LiDAR Place Recognition, Re-Ranking, and 6-DoF Metric Localisation in Forests
summary: This article presents HOTFLoc++, an end-to-end framework for LiDAR place recognition, re-ranking, and 6-DoF metric localisation in forests. Leveraging an octree-based transformer, our approach extracts hierarchical local descriptors at multiple granularities to increase robustness to clutter, self-similarity, and viewpoint changes in challenging scenarios, including ground-to-ground and ground-to-aerial in forest and urban environments. We propose a learnable multi-scale geometric verification module to reduce re-ranking failures in the presence of degraded single-scale correspondences. Our coarse-to-fine registration approach achieves comparable or lower localisation errors to baselines, with runtime improvements of two orders of magnitude over RANSAC for dense point clouds. Experimental results on public datasets show the superiority of our approach compared to state-of-the-art methods, achieving an average Recall@1 of 90.7% on CS-Wild-Places: an improvement of 29.6 percentage points over baselines, while maintaining high performance on single-source benchmarks with an average Recall@1 of 91.7% and 96.0% on Wild-Places and MulRan, respectively. Our method achieves under 2 m and 5 degrees error for 97.2% of 6-DoF registration attempts, with our multi-scale re-ranking module reducing localisation errors by ~2$\times$ on average. The code will be available upon acceptance.

AI.tldr: HOTFLoc++ is a end-to-end LiDAR place recognition and 6-DoF localization framework that uses an octree-based transformer to extract multi-scale local descriptors, plus a learnable multi-scale geometric verification module for robust re-ranking. It achieves state-of-the-art recall and fast registration, with substantial speedups over RANSAC.
AI.motivation: To improve robustness of LiDAR-based place recognition in cluttered, self-similar, and viewpoint-varying environments (forests, urban) and to reduce re-ranking failures caused by degraded single-scale matches, while enabling fast, accurate 6-DoF localisation.
AI.method: An octree-based transformer extracts hierarchical local descriptors at multiple scales. A learnable multi-scale geometric verification module is used for re-ranking. Coarse-to-fine registration enables efficient 6-DoF localisation. The approach is end-to-end for place recognition, re-ranking, and localisation.
AI.result: On public datasets, HOTFLoc++ achieves Recall@1 of 90.7% on CS-Wild-Places (29.6 pp above baselines) and 91.7% on Wild-Places, 96.0% on MulRan. It obtains under 2 m and 5° error for 97.2% of 6-DoF registrations; the multi-scale re-ranking reduces localisation errors by ~2x. Runtime is two orders of magnitude faster than RANSAC for dense point clouds.
AI.conclusion: HOTFLoc++ provides robust, scalable, and fast end-to-end LiDAR place recognition and localization in challenging environments, with strong empirical gains and a plan to release code upon acceptance.

title: Bayesian Mixture of Experts For Large Language Models
summary: We present Bayesian Mixture of Experts (Bayesian-MoE), a post-hoc uncertainty estimation framework for fine-tuned large language models (LLMs) based on Mixture-of-Experts architectures. Our method applies a structured Laplace approximation to the second linear layer of each expert, enabling calibrated uncertainty estimation without modifying the original training procedure or introducing new parameters. Unlike prior approaches, which apply Bayesian inference to added adapter modules, Bayesian-MoE directly targets the expert pathways already present in MoE models, leveraging their modular design for tractable block-wise posterior estimation. We use Kronecker-factored low-rank approximations to model curvature and derive scalable estimates of predictive uncertainty and marginal likelihood. Experiments on common-sense reasoning benchmarks with Qwen1.5-MoE and DeepSeek-MoE demonstrate that Bayesian-MoE improves both expected calibration error (ECE) and negative log-likelihood (NLL) over baselines, confirming its effectiveness for reliable downstream decision-making.

AI.tldr: Bayesian-MoE is a post-hoc uncertainty estimation method for fine-tuned MoE-based LLMs that adds no new parameters and uses a structured Laplace approximation on each expert's second linear layer, with Kronecker-factored curvature, to produce calibrated uncertainty and better likelihood estimates.
AI.motivation: Uncertainty estimation in large language models is crucial for reliable downstream decisions. Prior Bayesian approaches targeted added adapters, not the main MoE pathways. A post-hoc, parameter-free calibration on the existing MoE structure aims for scalable, tractable posterior estimation and improved calibration.
AI.method: Apply a structured Laplace approximation to the second linear layer of every expert in the Mixture-of-Experts architecture. Use Kronecker-factored low-rank approximations to model curvature, enabling scalable estimates of predictive uncertainty and marginal likelihood without changing training. Operates post-hoc on fine-tuned LLMs with MoE.
AI.result: Experiments on common-sense reasoning benchmarks using Qwen1.5-MoE and DeepSeek-MoE show improved expected calibration error (ECE) and negative log-likelihood (NLL) over baselines, indicating better calibrated uncertainty.
AI.conclusion: Bayesian-MoE provides a practical, effective post-hoc Bayesian calibration method for MoE-based LLMs, achieving reliable uncertainty estimates without retraining or extra parameters.

title: Efficient and Effective In-context Demonstration Selection with Coreset
comment: This paper is accepted by AAAI26
summary: In-context learning (ICL) has emerged as a powerful paradigm for Large Visual Language Models (LVLMs), enabling them to leverage a few examples directly from input contexts. However, the effectiveness of this approach is heavily reliant on the selection of demonstrations, a process that is NP-hard. Traditional strategies, including random, similarity-based sampling and infoscore-based sampling, often lead to inefficiencies or suboptimal performance, struggling to balance both efficiency and effectiveness in demonstration selection. In this paper, we propose a novel demonstration selection framework named Coreset-based Dual Retrieval (CoDR). We show that samples within a diverse subset achieve a higher expected mutual information. To implement this, we introduce a cluster-pruning method to construct a diverse coreset that aligns more effectively with the query while maintaining diversity. Additionally, we develop a dual retrieval mechanism that enhances the selection process by achieving global demonstration selection while preserving efficiency. Experimental results demonstrate that our method significantly improves the ICL performance compared to the existing strategies, providing a robust solution for effective and efficient demonstration selection.

AI.tldr: A coreset-based dual retrieval framework (CoDR) improves demonstration selection for in-context learning in LVLMs by balancing diversity and relevance, leading to better ICL performance.
AI.motivation: Demonstration selection for in-context learning is NP-hard, and existing sampling strategies (random, similarity-based, infoscore-based) are inefficient or suboptimal. There is a need for an efficient and effective method to select demonstrations that maximize information gain.
AI.method: Introduce CoDR: a coreset-based approach with cluster-pruning to construct a diverse subset that aligns with the query. A dual retrieval mechanism enables global demonstration selection while maintaining efficiency, combining diversity with relevance.
AI.result: Experimental results show that CoDR significantly improves ICL performance over existing strategies, indicating better demonstration selection in LVLMs.
AI.conclusion: CoDR offers a robust solution for effective and efficient demonstration selection in in-context learning, improving both the quality and efficiency of demonstration retrieval.

title: Selective Sinkhorn Routing for Improved Sparse Mixture of Experts
summary: Sparse Mixture-of-Experts (SMoE) has gained prominence as a scalable and computationally efficient architecture, enabling significant growth in model capacity without incurring additional inference costs. However, existing SMoE models often rely on auxiliary losses (e.g., z-loss, load balancing) and additional trainable parameters (e.g., noisy gating) to encourage expert diversity, leading to objective misalignment and increased model complexity. Moreover, existing Sinkhorn-based methods suffer from significant training overhead due to their heavy reliance on the computationally expensive Sinkhorn algorithm. In this work, we formulate token-to-expert assignment as an optimal transport problem, incorporating constraints to ensure balanced expert utilization. We demonstrate that introducing a minimal degree of optimal transport-based routing enhances SMoE performance without requiring auxiliary balancing losses. Unlike previous methods, our approach derives gating scores directly from the transport map, enabling more effective token-to-expert balancing, supported by both theoretical analysis and empirical results. Building on these insights, we propose Selective Sinkhorn Routing (SSR), a routing mechanism that replaces auxiliary loss with lightweight Sinkhorn-based routing. SSR promotes balanced token assignments while preserving flexibility in expert selection. Across both language modeling and image classification tasks, SSR achieves faster training, higher accuracy, and greater robustness to input corruption.

AI.tldr: Selective Sinkhorn Routing (SSR) for Sparse Mixture-of-Experts (SMoE) uses optimal transport routing to balance token-to-expert assignments, deriving gating directly from transport maps, avoiding auxiliary balancing losses, and achieving faster training, higher accuracy, and robustness in NLP and CV.
AI.motivation: Current SMoEs rely on auxiliary losses (e.g., z-loss, load balancing) and extra trainable parameters (e.g., noisy gating) to encourage expert diversity, causing objective misalignment and increased model complexity. Sinkhorn-based methods can be computationally heavy, leading to training overhead. A clean, aligned routing mechanism is needed.
AI.method: Formulate token-to-expert assignment as an optimal transport problem with balanced constraints. Derive gating scores from the transport map. Propose Selective Sinkhorn Routing (SSR), a lightweight Sinkhorn-based routing that replaces auxiliary loss with OT-inspired routing.
AI.result: Across language modeling and image classification tasks, SSR achieves faster training, higher accuracy, and greater robustness to input corruption.
AI.conclusion: OT-based routing with minimal auxiliary components enables balanced yet flexible expert selection in SMoE, improving efficiency and performance. SSR provides a practical, scalable routing mechanism that mitigates objective misalignment and reduces model complexity.

title: WDT-MD: Wavelet Diffusion Transformers for Microaneurysm Detection in Fundus Images
comment: 9 pages, 6 figures, 8 tables, accepted by AAAI 2026
summary: Microaneurysms (MAs), the earliest pathognomonic signs of Diabetic Retinopathy (DR), present as sub-60 $μm$ lesions in fundus images with highly variable photometric and morphological characteristics, rendering manual screening not only labor-intensive but inherently error-prone. While diffusion-based anomaly detection has emerged as a promising approach for automated MA screening, its clinical application is hindered by three fundamental limitations. First, these models often fall prey to "identity mapping", where they inadvertently replicate the input image. Second, they struggle to distinguish MAs from other anomalies, leading to high false positives. Third, their suboptimal reconstruction of normal features hampers overall performance. To address these challenges, we propose a Wavelet Diffusion Transformer framework for MA Detection (WDT-MD), which features three key innovations: a noise-encoded image conditioning mechanism to avoid "identity mapping" by perturbing image conditions during training; pseudo-normal pattern synthesis via inpainting to introduce pixel-level supervision, enabling discrimination between MAs and other anomalies; and a wavelet diffusion Transformer architecture that combines the global modeling capability of diffusion Transformers with multi-scale wavelet analysis to enhance reconstruction of normal retinal features. Comprehensive experiments on the IDRiD and e-ophtha MA datasets demonstrate that WDT-MD outperforms state-of-the-art methods in both pixel-level and image-level MA detection. This advancement holds significant promise for improving early DR screening.

AI.tldr: A Wavelet Diffusion Transformer framework (WDT-MD) for microaneurysm detection in diabetic retinopathy. It tackles identity mapping, false positives, and poor normal feature reconstruction via (1) noise-encoded image conditioning, (2) pseudo-normal pattern synthesis through inpainting, and (3) a wavelet diffusion Transformer that fuses global diffusion modeling with multi-scale wavelet analysis. It achieves state-of-the-art performance on IDRiD and e-ophtha MA datasets for pixel-level and image-level detection.
AI.motivation: Microaneurysms are tiny, heterogeneously appearing lesions in fundus images, making early DR screening challenging. Diffusion-based anomaly detection, while promising, suffers from identity mapping (reconstructing inputs), difficulty distinguishing MAs from other anomalies (false positives), and weak reconstruction of normal features, limiting clinical utility.
AI.method: Proposed WDT-MD with three innovations: (1) noise-encoded image conditioning to perturb training conditions and avoid identity mapping; (2) pseudo-normal pattern synthesis via inpainting to create pixel-level supervision that helps discriminate MAs from other anomalies; (3) a wavelet diffusion Transformer architecture that combines the global modeling of diffusion Transformers with multi-scale wavelet analysis to better reconstruct normal retinal features.
AI.result: Comprehensive experiments on IDRiD and e-ophtha MA datasets show that WDT-MD outperforms state-of-the-art methods in both pixel-level and image-level MA detection.
AI.conclusion: WDT-MD advances early DR screening by delivering more accurate and reliable MA detection, with strong potential for clinical deployment.

title: Data reuse enables cost-efficient randomized trials of medical AI models
summary: Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) are indispensable for establishing the clinical value of medical artificial-intelligence (AI) tools, yet their high cost and long timelines hinder timely validation as new models emerge rapidly. Here, we propose BRIDGE, a data-reuse RCT design for AI-based risk models. AI risk models support a broad range of interventions, including screening, treatment selection, and clinical alerts. BRIDGE trials recycle participant-level data from completed trials of AI models when legacy and updated models make concordant predictions, thereby reducing the enrollment requirement for subsequent trials. We provide a practical checklist for investigators to assess whether reusing data from previous trials allows for valid causal inference and preserves type I error. Using real-world datasets across breast cancer, cardiovascular disease, and sepsis, we demonstrate concordance between successive AI models, with up to 64.8% overlap in top 5% high-risk cohorts. We then simulate a series of breast cancer screening studies, where our design reduced required enrollment by 46.6%--saving over US$2.8 million--while maintaining 80% power. By transforming trials into adaptive, modular studies, our proposed design makes Level I evidence generation feasible for every model iteration, thereby accelerating cost-effective translation of AI into routine care.

AI.tldr: BRIDGE is a data-reuse RCT design for AI-based risk models that reuses participant-level data from completed trials when legacy and updated models give concordant predictions, reducing new enrollment and enabling faster, modular Level I evidence across model iterations.
AI.motivation: RCTs for medical AI are expensive and slow, hindering timely validation as models evolve; BRIDGE aims to democratize evidence by reusing existing trial data to validate new model iterations without starting from scratch.
AI.method: Reuses participant-level data from prior AI-model trials when predictions align; provides a practical validity/checklist to preserve causal inference and control type I error; uses real-world datasets (breast cancer, cardiovascular disease, sepsis) to assess concordance; simulates breast cancer screening studies to quantify enrollment reduction and power.
AI.result: Demonstrates concordance between successive AI models with up to 64.8% overlap in the top-5% high-risk cohort; simulations show 46.6% enrollment reduction and savings of $2.8M while maintaining 80% power.
AI.conclusion: Transforms trials into adaptive, modular studies; BRIDGE enables feasible Level I evidence generation for every model iteration, accelerating cost-effective translation of AI into routine care.

title: An ICTM-RMSAV Framework for Bias-Field Aware Image Segmentation under Poisson and Multiplicative Noise
summary: Image segmentation is a core task in image processing, yet many methods degrade when images are heavily corrupted by noise and exhibit intensity inhomogeneity. Within the iterative-convolution thresholding method (ICTM) framework, we propose a variational segmentation model that integrates denoising terms. Specifically, the denoising component consists of an I-divergence term and an adaptive total-variation (TV) regularizer, making the model well suited to images contaminated by Gamma--distributed multiplicative noise and Poisson noise. A spatially adaptive weight derived from a gray-level indicator guides diffusion differently across regions of varying intensity. To further address intensity inhomogeneity, we estimate a smoothly varying bias field, which improves segmentation accuracy. Regions are represented by characteristic functions, with contour length encoded accordingly. For efficient optimization, we couple ICTM with a relaxed modified scalar auxiliary variable (RMSAV) scheme. Extensive experiments on synthetic and real-world images with intensity inhomogeneity and diverse noise types show that the proposed model achieves superior accuracy and robustness compared with competing approaches.

AI.tldr: A robust ICTM-based variational segmentation model with integrated denoising terms (I-divergence and adaptive TV), spatially adaptive diffusion weights, and bias-field correction, optimized via RMSAV, achieving superior performance under Gamma and Poisson noise and intensity inhomogeneity.
AI.motivation: Image segmentation degrades under heavy noise (Gamma-distributed multiplicative noise, Poisson noise) and intensity inhomogeneity. A joint denoising-segmentation approach within the ICTM framework is needed to improve accuracy and robustness.
AI.method: Develop a variational segmentation model within the ICTM framework that includes an I-divergence data fidelity term and an adaptive TV regularizer for denoising, a spatially adaptive diffusion weight derived from a gray-level indicator, estimation of a smoothly varying bias field to correct intensity inhomogeneity, and region representation via characteristic functions. Optimization is performed using a relaxed modified scalar auxiliary variable (RMSAV) scheme.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on synthetic and real-world images with intensity inhomogeneity and various noise types demonstrate superior accuracy and robustness of the proposed model compared with competing approaches.
AI.conclusion: The integration of denoising terms, adaptive diffusion, and bias-field correction within the ICTM framework, together with RMSAV optimization, yields more accurate and robust image segmentation under challenging noise and intensity inhomogeneity conditions; the approach shows strong potential for broad applicability.

title: Fast $k$-means clustering in Riemannian manifolds via Fréchet maps: Applications to large-dimensional SPD matrices
summary: We introduce a novel, efficient framework for clustering data on high-dimensional, non-Euclidean manifolds that overcomes the computational challenges associated with standard intrinsic methods. The key innovation is the use of the $p$-Fréchet map $F^p : \mathcal{M} \to \mathbb{R}^\ell$ -- defined on a generic metric space $\mathcal{M}$ -- which embeds the manifold data into a lower-dimensional Euclidean space $\mathbb{R}^\ell$ using a set of reference points $\{r_i\}_{i=1}^\ell$, $r_i \in \mathcal{M}$. Once embedded, we can efficiently and accurately apply standard Euclidean clustering techniques such as k-means. We rigorously analyze the mathematical properties of $F^p$ in the Euclidean space and the challenging manifold of $n \times n$ symmetric positive definite matrices $\mathit{SPD}(n)$. Extensive numerical experiments using synthetic and real $\mathit{SPD}(n)$ data demonstrate significant performance gains: our method reduces runtime by up to two orders of magnitude compared to intrinsic manifold-based approaches, all while maintaining high clustering accuracy, including scenarios where existing alternative methods struggle or fail.

AI.tldr: A novel, efficient framework for clustering data on high-dimensional, non-Euclidean manifolds using a p-Fréchet map to embed manifold data into a lower-dimensional Euclidean space, enabling standard Euclidean clustering (e.g., k-means) with substantial runtime gains while preserving accuracy.
AI.motivation: To address the computational bottlenecks of intrinsic manifold clustering methods in high-dimensional, non-Euclidean spaces and provide a scalable alternative without sacrificing clustering quality.
AI.method: Introduce the p-Fréchet map F^p: M -> R^l defined on a generic metric space M using a set of reference points {r_i} in M. The map embeds data into R^l, after which standard Euclidean clustering methods are applied. The paper analyzes the mathematical properties of F^p in Euclidean space and specifically on the SPD(n) manifold. Extensive experiments on synthetic and real SPD(n) data validate performance improvements.
AI.result: The method achieves significant runtime reductions—up to two orders of magnitude—compared to intrinsic manifold-based approaches, while maintaining high clustering accuracy. It performs well even in scenarios where existing alternatives struggle or fail.
AI.conclusion: The p-Fréchet embedding offers an effective, scalable approach for clustering on non-Euclidean manifolds, enabling efficient use of Euclidean clustering techniques with strong empirical performance on SPD(n) data and beyond.

title: T-Rex-Omni: Integrating Negative Visual Prompt in Generic Object Detection
comment: Accepted by AAAI 2026. Main paper: 7 pages with 4 figures; Appendix: 8 pages with 7 figures
summary: Object detection methods have evolved from closed-set to open-set paradigms over the years. Current open-set object detectors, however, remain constrained by their exclusive reliance on positive indicators based on given prompts like text descriptions or visual exemplars. This positive-only paradigm experiences consistent vulnerability to visually similar but semantically different distractors. We propose T-Rex-Omni, a novel framework that addresses this limitation by incorporating negative visual prompts to negate hard negative distractors. Specifically, we first introduce a unified visual prompt encoder that jointly processes positive and negative visual prompts. Next, a training-free Negating Negative Computing (NNC) module is proposed to dynamically suppress negative responses during the probability computing stage. To further boost performance through fine-tuning, our Negating Negative Hinge (NNH) loss enforces discriminative margins between positive and negative embeddings. T-Rex-Omni supports flexible deployment in both positive-only and joint positive-negative inference modes, accommodating either user-specified or automatically generated negative examples. Extensive experiments demonstrate remarkable zero-shot detection performance, significantly narrowing the performance gap between visual-prompted and text-prompted methods while showing particular strength in long-tailed scenarios (51.2 AP_r on LVIS-minival). This work establishes negative prompts as a crucial new dimension for advancing open-set visual recognition systems.

AI.tldr: A negative-prompt framework for open-set object detection that augments positive prompts with negative visual prompts, using a unified prompt encoder, a training-free negation module, and a discriminative loss to improve zero-shot and long-tail performance.
AI.motivation: Current open-set detectors rely only on positive indicators from prompts (e.g., text descriptions or visual exemplars), making them vulnerable to visually similar but semantically different distractors. Incorporating negative prompts can suppress hard negatives and improve recognition.
AI.method: Proposes T-Rex-Omni with a unified visual prompt encoder that processes positive and negative prompts together; a training-free Negating Negative Computing (NNC) module to suppress negative responses during probability computation; optional fine-tuning via Negating Negative Hinge (NNH) loss to enforce discriminative margins between positive and negative embeddings; supports both positive-only and joint positive-negative inference and accepts user-specified or automatically generated negatives.
AI.result: Achieves strong zero-shot performance, significantly narrowing the gap between visual-prompted and text-prompted methods; excels in long-tailed scenarios (e.g., 51.2 AP_r on LVIS-minival). Demonstrates that negative prompts are a crucial dimension for advancing open-set visual recognition systems.
AI.conclusion: Negative prompts extend open-set recognition capabilities; T-Rex-Omni demonstrates robust open-set detection with negative guidance and flexible deployment options.

title: FLAD: Federated Learning for LLM-based Autonomous Driving in Vehicle-Edge-Cloud Networks
summary: Large Language Models (LLMs) have impressive data fusion and reasoning capabilities for autonomous driving (AD). However, training LLMs for AD faces significant challenges including high computation transmission costs, and privacy concerns associated with sensitive driving data. Federated Learning (FL) is promising for enabling autonomous vehicles (AVs) to collaboratively train models without sharing raw data. We present Federated LLM-based Autonomous Driving (FLAD), an FL framework that leverages distributed multimodal sensory data across AVs in heterogeneous environment. FLAD has three key innovations: (1) a cloud-edge-vehicle collaborative architecture that reduces communication delay and preserving data privacy; (2) an intelligent parallelized collaborative training with a communication scheduling mechanism that optimizes training efficiency, leveraging end-devices otherwise having insufficient resources for model training; and (3) a knowledge distillation method that personalizes LLM according to heterogeneous edge data. In addition, we prototype FLAD in a testbed with NVIDIA Jetsons, overcoming practical implementation challenges including CPU/GPU memory sharing in resource-constrained devices, dynamic model partitions, and fault-tolerant training.Extensive experimental evaluation demonstrates that FLAD achieves superior end-to-end AD performance while efficiently utilizing distributed vehicular resources, opening up new possibilities for future collaborative AD model training and knowledge sharing.

AI.tldr: Federated LLM-based Autonomous Driving (FLAD) enables privacy-preserving, distributed training of LLMs for autonomous driving using a cloud-edge-vehicle FL architecture, parallelized training with scheduling, and knowledge distillation for heterogeneous edge data; validated on NVIDIA Jetson devices with fault-tolerant, memory-sharing considerations.
AI.motivation: Tackle high computational load, bandwidth costs, and privacy concerns that hinder training of large LLMs for autonomous driving; enable collaborative learning without raw data sharing.
AI.method: Introduce FLAD: (1) a cloud-edge-vehicle collaborative architecture to minimize latency and preserve privacy; (2) intelligent parallelized collaborative training with a communication scheduling mechanism to utilize devices with limited resources; (3) knowledge distillation to personalize LLMs for heterogeneous edge data; prototype/testbed on NVIDIA Jetsons addressing memory sharing, dynamic model partitioning, and fault-tolerant training.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show FLAD achieves superior end-to-end autonomous driving performance while efficiently utilizing distributed vehicular resources, validating feasibility in resource-constrained, dynamic environments.
AI.conclusion: FLAD provides a viable framework for collaborative AD model training and knowledge sharing across vehicles, balancing performance, privacy, and resource constraints, and suggests directions for future multimodal FL research in autonomous driving.

title: Causally-Grounded Dual-Path Attention Intervention for Object Hallucination Mitigation in LVLMs
summary: Object hallucination remains a critical challenge in Large Vision-Language Models (LVLMs), where models generate content inconsistent with visual inputs. Existing language-decoder based mitigation approaches often regulate visual or textual attention independently, overlooking their interaction as two key causal factors. To address this, we propose Owl (Bi-mOdal attention reWeighting for Layer-wise hallucination mitigation), a causally-grounded framework that models hallucination process via a structural causal graph, treating decomposed visual and textual attentions as mediators. We introduce VTACR (Visual-to-Textual Attention Contribution Ratio), a novel metric that quantifies the modality contribution imbalance during decoding. Our analysis reveals that hallucinations frequently occur in low-VTACR scenarios, where textual priors dominate and visual grounding is weakened. To mitigate this, we design a fine-grained attention intervention mechanism that dynamically adjusts token- and layer-wise attention guided by VTACR signals. Finally, we propose a dual-path contrastive decoding strategy: one path emphasizes visually grounded predictions, while the other amplifies hallucinated ones -- letting visual truth shine and hallucination collapse. Experimental results on the POPE and CHAIR benchmarks show that Owl achieves significant hallucination reduction, setting a new SOTA in faithfulness while preserving vision-language understanding capability. Our code is available at https://github.com/CikZ2023/OWL

AI.tldr: A causally-grounded framework (Owl) mitigates LVLM hallucinations by modeling visual and textual attentions as mediators in a structural causal graph, introducing VTACR to measure modality contribution imbalance, and employing fine-grained attention intervention plus dual-path contrastive decoding, achieving SOTA faithfulness on POPE and CHAIR without sacrificing vision-language understanding.
AI.motivation: Object hallucination in large vision-language models remains unresolved when visual and textual cues are treated independently; a causal treatment of their interaction as mediators promises more faithful grounding.
AI.method: Propose Owl, a structural causal-model framework where decomposed visual/textual attentions are mediators. Introduce VTACR (Visual-to-Textual Attention Contribution Ratio) to quantify modality imbalance. Develop a fine-grained attention intervention guided by VTACR at token- and layer-wise levels. Propose a dual-path contrastive decoding strategy with one path biasing visually grounded predictions and the other amplifying hallucinations, to separate truth from hallucination.
AI.result: Experiments on POPE and CHAIR benchmarks show significant reduction in hallucinations and state-of-the-art faithfulness while preserving vision-language understanding capabilities.
AI.conclusion: A principled causal framework (Owl) with VTACR-guided attention reweighting and dual-path decoding mitigates hallucinations in LVLMs and improves faithfulness without sacrificing multimodal understanding.

title: FedSDWC: Federated Synergistic Dual-Representation Weak Causal Learning for OOD
summary: Amid growing demands for data privacy and advances in computational infrastructure, federated learning (FL) has emerged as a prominent distributed learning paradigm. Nevertheless, differences in data distribution (such as covariate and semantic shifts) severely affect its reliability in real-world deployments. To address this issue, we propose FedSDWC, a causal inference method that integrates both invariant and variant features. FedSDWC infers causal semantic representations by modeling the weak causal influence between invariant and variant features, effectively overcoming the limitations of existing invariant learning methods in accurately capturing invariant features and directly constructing causal representations. This approach significantly enhances FL's ability to generalize and detect OOD data. Theoretically, we derive FedSDWC's generalization error bound under specific conditions and, for the first time, establish its relationship with client prior distributions. Moreover, extensive experiments conducted on multiple benchmark datasets validate the superior performance of FedSDWC in handling covariate and semantic shifts. For example, FedSDWC outperforms FedICON, the next best baseline, by an average of 3.04% on CIFAR-10 and 8.11% on CIFAR-100.

AI.tldr: FedSDWC combines invariant and variant features via causal inference to improve federated learning under covariate and semantic shifts, inferring causal semantic representations from weak causal links and establishing a bound tied to client priors; empirically outperforms FedICON on CIFAR-10/100.
AI.motivation: Data heterogeneity across clients undermines FL reliability; existing invariant learning methods struggle to accurately capture invariant features and handle semantic shift; there is a need for a method that connects causal representations to FL generalization.
AI.method: Integrates invariant and variant features; models weak causal influence between them to infer causal semantic representations; constructs causal representations and uses them to generalize; derives a generalization bound under specific conditions and links it to client prior distributions; experimental validation across benchmark datasets with comparisons to FedICON.
AI.result: Demonstrates improved generalization and out-of-distribution detection; average gains over FedICON: 3.04% on CIFAR-10 and 8.11% on CIFAR-100.
AI.conclusion: FedSDWC advances FL robustness to distribution shifts through causal-informed representation learning; provides theoretical generalization guarantees tied to client priors; empirically validated on multiple datasets.

title: Dense Cross-Scale Image Alignment With Fully Spatial Correlation and Just Noticeable Difference Guidance
summary: Existing unsupervised image alignment methods exhibit limited accuracy and high computational complexity. To address these challenges, we propose a dense cross-scale image alignment model. It takes into account the correlations between cross-scale features to decrease the alignment difficulty. Our model supports flexible trade-offs between accuracy and efficiency by adjusting the number of scales utilized. Additionally, we introduce a fully spatial correlation module to further improve accuracy while maintaining low computational costs. We incorporate the just noticeable difference to encourage our model to focus on image regions more sensitive to distortions, eliminating noticeable alignment errors. Extensive quantitative and qualitative experiments demonstrate that our method surpasses state-of-the-art approaches.

AI.tldr: Proposes a dense cross-scale image alignment model that uses cross-scale correlations and a fully spatial correlation module to improve unsupervised alignment accuracy with adjustable scale usage and JND-based focus on distortion-sensitive regions, achieving state-of-the-art performance with lower computational cost.
AI.motivation: Unsupervised image alignment so far suffers from limited accuracy and high computational complexity. There is a need for methods that leverage cross-scale information, balance accuracy and efficiency, and focus on perceptually important regions.
AI.method: Introduce a dense cross-scale alignment framework that models correlations across multiple scales. Allows flexible trade-offs by adjusting the number of scales. Adds a fully spatial correlation module to boost accuracy without heavy cost. Incorporates a just noticeable difference (JND) mechanism to emphasize distortion-sensitive regions during alignment.
AI.result: Extensive experiments (quantitative and qualitative) show improvements over state-of-the-art methods in accuracy and efficiency, validating the effectiveness of cross-scale correlations, the spatial correlation module, and JND-based focus.
AI.conclusion: The proposed dense cross-scale alignment approach achieves better accuracy-efficiency trade-offs in unsupervised image alignment and is robust to distortions, outperforming prior methods.

title: Fairness-Aware Few-Shot Learning for Audio-Visual Stress Detection
summary: Fairness in AI-driven stress detection is critical for equitable mental healthcare, yet existing models frequently exhibit gender bias, particularly in data-scarce scenarios. To address this, we propose FairM2S, a fairness-aware meta-learning framework for stress detection leveraging audio-visual data. FairM2S integrates Equalized Odds constraints during both meta-training and adaptation phases, employing adversarial gradient masking and fairness-constrained meta-updates to effectively mitigate bias. Evaluated against five state-of-the-art baselines, FairM2S achieves 78.1% accuracy while reducing the Equal Opportunity to 0.06, demonstrating substantial fairness gains. We also release SAVSD, a smartphone-captured dataset with gender annotations, designed to support fairness research in low-resource, real-world contexts. Together, these contributions position FairM2S as a state-of-the-art approach for equitable and scalable few-shot stress detection in mental health AI. We release our dataset and FairM2S publicly with this paper.

AI.tldr: FairM2S is a fairness-aware meta-learning framework for stress detection that uses audio-visual data and Equalized Odds to mitigate gender bias, with adversarial gradient masking and fairness-constrained meta-updates. It achieves 78.1% accuracy and reduces Equal Opportunity to 0.06, against five baselines, and introduces SAVSD dataset for low-resource fairness research; both the method and dataset are publicly released, making it a leading approach for fair few-shot mental health AI.
AI.motivation: To address gender bias in AI-driven stress detection, especially in data-scarce settings, enabling equitable mental healthcare and accountable AI systems.
AI.method: A meta-learning framework (FairM2S) that enforces Equalized Odds during meta-training and adaptation, incorporates adversarial gradient masking, and applies fairness-constrained meta-updates on multi-modal audio-visual data (and follows a few-shot learning paradigm). Also introduces SAVSD, a smartphone-captured dataset with gender annotations.
AI.result: Outperforms five state-of-the-art baselines, achieving 78.1% accuracy and reducing Equal Opportunity to 0.06; demonstrates substantial fairness gains and scalability in low-resource contexts.
AI.conclusion: FairM2S advances fair, scalable few-shot stress detection in mental health AI and, together with the SAVSD dataset, provides a publicly available benchmark and framework for future fairness research in audio-visual stress detection.

title: USF-Net: A Unified Spatiotemporal Fusion Network for Ground-Based Remote Sensing Cloud Image Sequence Extrapolation
summary: Ground-based remote sensing cloud image sequence extrapolation is a key research area in the development of photovoltaic power systems. However, existing approaches exhibit several limitations:(1)they primarily rely on static kernels to augment feature information, lacking adaptive mechanisms to extract features at varying resolutions dynamically;(2)temporal guidance is insufficient, leading to suboptimal modeling of long-range spatiotemporal dependencies; and(3)the quadratic computational cost of attention mechanisms is often overlooked, limiting efficiency in practical deployment. To address these challenges, we propose USF-Net, a Unified Spatiotemporal Fusion Network that integrates adaptive large-kernel convolutions and a low-complexity attention mechanism, combining temporal flow information within an encoder-decoder framework. Specifically, the encoder employs three basic layers to extract features. Followed by the USTM, which comprises:(1)a SiB equipped with a SSM that dynamically captures multi-scale contextual information, and(2)a TiB featuring a TAM that effectively models long-range temporal dependencies while maintaining computational efficiency. In addition, a DSM with a TGM is introduced to enable unified modeling of temporally guided spatiotemporal dependencies. On the decoder side, a DUM is employed to address the common "ghosting effect." It utilizes the initial temporal state as an attention operator to preserve critical motion signatures. As a key contribution, we also introduce and release the ASI-CIS dataset. Extensive experiments on ASI-CIS demonstrate that USF-Net significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods, establishing a superior balance between prediction accuracy and computational efficiency for ground-based cloud extrapolation. The dataset and source code will be available at https://github.com/she1110/ASI-CIS.

AI.tldr: A unified spatiotemporal fusion network (USF-Net) for ground-based cloud extrapolation, combining adaptive large-kernel convolutions with low-complexity attention, achieving state-of-the-art performance on the ASI-CIS dataset while balancing accuracy and efficiency.
AI.motivation: Limitations of existing methods: static kernels and limited adaptability, insufficient temporal guidance for long-range dependencies, and computationally expensive attention (quadratic complexity), hindering practical deployment for cloud extrapolation in PV systems.
AI.method: Propose USF-Net in an encoder–decoder framework. Encoder with three basic layers; USTM includes SiB with SSM for dynamic multi-scale contextual information and TiB with TAM for long-range temporal dependencies with efficiency. DSM with TGM for unified temporally guided spatiotemporal dependencies. Decoder uses DUM to mitigate ghosting by using initial temporal state as an attention operator. Release ASI-CIS dataset.
AI.result: Empirical results on ASI-CIS show USF-Net significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods and achieves a favorable accuracy–efficiency balance.
AI.conclusion: Dataset and source code will be released at the provided GitHub URL; demonstrates strong potential for ground-based cloud extrapolation in PV systems.

title: GeoGNN: Quantifying and Mitigating Semantic Drift in Text-Attributed Graphs
summary: Graph neural networks (GNNs) on text--attributed graphs (TAGs) typically encode node texts using pretrained language models (PLMs) and propagate these embeddings through linear neighborhood aggregation. However, the representation spaces of modern PLMs are highly non--linear and geometrically structured, where textual embeddings reside on curved semantic manifolds rather than flat Euclidean spaces. Linear aggregation on such manifolds inevitably distorts geometry and causes semantic drift--a phenomenon where aggregated representations deviate from the intrinsic manifold, losing semantic fidelity and expressive power. To quantitatively investigate this problem, this work introduces a local PCA--based metric that measures the degree of semantic drift and provides the first quantitative framework to analyze how different aggregation mechanisms affect manifold structure. Building upon these insights, we propose Geodesic Aggregation, a manifold--aware mechanism that aggregates neighbor information along geodesics via log--exp mappings on the unit sphere, ensuring that representations remain faithful to the semantic manifold during message passing. We further develop GeoGNN, a practical instantiation that integrates spherical attention with manifold interpolation. Extensive experiments across four benchmark datasets and multiple text encoders show that GeoGNN substantially mitigates semantic drift and consistently outperforms strong baselines, establishing the importance of manifold--aware aggregation in text--attributed graph learning.

AI.tldr: GNNs on text-attributed graphs suffer semantic drift because PLM embeddings live on curved semantic manifolds; the paper introduces Geodesic Aggregation on the unit sphere using log-exp mappings to preserve manifold geometry, with a practical GeoGNN that combines spherical attention and manifold interpolation; experiments show reduced semantic drift and improved performance over baselines.
AI.motivation: Modern pretrained language models embed text in highly structured, non-Euclidean manifolds. Linear aggregation on graphs can distort this geometry, causing semantic drift and loss of expressive power in downstream GNNs for text-attributed graphs.
AI.method: Introduce a local PCA-based metric to quantify semantic drift. Propose Geodesic Aggregation that aggregates neighbor information along geodesics via log-exp mappings on the unit sphere. Develop GeoGNN, which integrates spherical attention with manifold interpolation.
AI.result: GeoGNN substantially mitigates semantic drift and consistently outperforms strong baselines across four benchmark datasets with multiple text encoders.
AI.conclusion: Manifold-aware, geodesic-based aggregation is crucial for preserving semantic fidelity in text-attributed graph learning; the approach demonstrates the importance of aligning aggregation with the intrinsic geometry of semantic spaces.

title: 4KDehazeFlow: Ultra-High-Definition Image Dehazing via Flow Matching
summary: Ultra-High-Definition (UHD) image dehazing faces challenges such as limited scene adaptability in prior-based methods and high computational complexity with color distortion in deep learning approaches. To address these issues, we propose 4KDehazeFlow, a novel method based on Flow Matching and the Haze-Aware vector field. This method models the dehazing process as a progressive optimization of continuous vector field flow, providing efficient data-driven adaptive nonlinear color transformation for high-quality dehazing. Specifically, our method has the following advantages: 1) 4KDehazeFlow is a general method compatible with various deep learning networks, without relying on any specific network architecture. 2) We propose a learnable 3D lookup table (LUT) that encodes haze transformation parameters into a compact 3D mapping matrix, enabling efficient inference through precomputed mappings. 3) We utilize a fourth-order Runge-Kutta (RK4) ordinary differential equation (ODE) solver to stably solve the dehazing flow field through an accurate step-by-step iterative method, effectively suppressing artifacts. Extensive experiments show that 4KDehazeFlow exceeds seven state-of-the-art methods. It delivers a 2dB PSNR increase and better performance in dense haze and color fidelity.

AI.tldr: 4KDehazeFlow introduces a flow-matching, haze-aware vector-field approach for UHD dehazing that uses a learnable 3D LUT and an RK4 solver, achieving compatibility with any DL backbone and surpassing seven SOTA methods with ~2 dB PSNR gains.
AI.motivation: Address the limitations of prior UHD dehazing methods: (i) poor scene adaptability in conventional priors and (ii) high computational cost and color distortion in some DL-based methods. A compact, data-driven, architecture-agnostic framework is needed to deliver high-quality dehazing with efficient inference.
AI.method: Model dehazing as progressive optimization of a continuous haze/scene flow field (vector field). Use a haze-aware vector field and RK4 ODE solver for stable, step-by-step integration. Introduce a learnable 3D LUT encoding haze transformation parameters into a compact 3D mapping for fast inference, enabling compatibility with any DL network without relying on a specific architecture.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation shows 4KDehazeFlow surpasses seven state-of-the-art methods, achieving about a 2 dB PSNR improvement and better color fidelity, particularly in dense haze scenarios.
AI.conclusion: 4KDehazeFlow is a general, efficient, and robust dehazing framework for UHD imagery, compatible with various networks and capable of reducing artifacts and improving both sharpness and color accuracy; it represents a significant advancement in high-quality dehazing with scalable inference.

title: Preference is More Than Comparisons: Rethinking Dueling Bandits with Augmented Human Feedback
comment: Extended version of our AAAI 2026 paper
summary: Interactive preference elicitation (IPE) aims to substantially reduce human effort while acquiring human preferences in wide personalization systems. Dueling bandit (DB) algorithms enable optimal decision-making in IPE building on pairwise comparisons. However, they remain inefficient when human feedback is sparse. Existing methods address sparsity by heavily relying on parametric reward models, whose rigid assumptions are vulnerable to misspecification. In contrast, we explore an alternative perspective based on feedback augmentation, and introduce critical improvements to the model-free DB framework. Specifically, we introduce augmented confidence bounds to integrate augmented human feedback under generalized concentration properties, and analyze the multi-factored performance trade-off via regret analysis. Our prototype algorithm achieves competitive performance across several IPE benchmarks, including recommendation, multi-objective optimization, and response optimization for large language models, demonstrating the potential of our approach for provably efficient IPE in broader applications.

AI.tldr: Augments model-free dueling-bandit interactive preference elicitation with augmented confidence bounds to handle sparse feedback, offering regret-based guarantees and competitive results across IPE benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Sparse human feedback and misspecification risk of parametric reward models hinder efficient IPE; a robust, model-free approach is needed.
AI.method: Introduce augmented confidence bounds that integrate augmented human feedback under generalized concentration properties within a model-free dueling-bandit framework; perform regret analysis and validate on benchmarks.
AI.result: Prototype algorithm delivers competitive performance on diverse IPE tasks (recommendation, multi-objective optimization, LLM response optimization) with provable efficiency characteristics.
AI.conclusion: Augmented confidence-bound approach strengthens model-free DB IPE, enabling provably efficient and broadly applicable IPE with reduced reliance on rigid reward models.
