title: PAN: A World Model for General, Interactable, and Long-Horizon World Simulation
summary: A world model enables an intelligent agent to imagine, predict, and reason about how the world evolves in response to its actions, and accordingly to plan and strategize. While recent video generation models produce realistic visual sequences, they typically operate in the prompt-to-full-video manner without causal control, interactivity, or long-horizon consistency required for purposeful reasoning. Existing world modeling efforts, on the other hand, often focus on restricted domains (e.g., physical, game, or 3D-scene dynamics) with limited depth and controllability, and struggle to generalize across diverse environments and interaction formats. In this work, we introduce PAN, a general, interactable, and long-horizon world model that predicts future world states through high-quality video simulation conditioned on history and natural language actions. PAN employs the Generative Latent Prediction (GLP) architecture that combines an autoregressive latent dynamics backbone based on a large language model (LLM), which grounds simulation in extensive text-based knowledge and enables conditioning on language-specified actions, with a video diffusion decoder that reconstructs perceptually detailed and temporally coherent visual observations, to achieve a unification between latent space reasoning (imagination) and realizable world dynamics (reality). Trained on large-scale video-action pairs spanning diverse domains, PAN supports open-domain, action-conditioned simulation with coherent, long-term dynamics. Extensive experiments show that PAN achieves strong performance in action-conditioned world simulation, long-horizon forecasting, and simulative reasoning compared to other video generators and world models, taking a step towards general world models that enable predictive simulation of future world states for reasoning and acting.

AI.tldr: PAN is a general, interactable, long-horizon world model that unifies imagination and perceptual reality by leveraging a Generative Latent Prediction (GLP) architecture: an LLM-based autoregressive latent dynamics backbone conditioned on language actions and a video diffusion decoder for high-quality visuals, trained on diverse video-action data to enable open-domain, action-conditioned, long-horizon simulation.
AI.motivation: Current video generators lack causal control and long-horizon consistency; existing world models fit narrow domains and poorly generalize. A general, interactive world model is needed for planning, reasoning, and action in diverse environments.
AI.method: Introduce GLP architecture combining an LLM-backed latent dynamics model with a video diffusion decoder; condition dynamics on natural language actions; train on large-scale video-action pairs across domains to ground simulation in language knowledge and produce coherent visuals.
AI.result: PAN achieves strong action-conditioned world simulation, long-horizon forecasting, and simulative reasoning; outperforms baselines among video generators and world models; demonstrates generalization across varied environments and interaction formats.
AI.conclusion: A step toward general world models enabling predictive simulation for reasoning and acting, by bridging latent imagination with realizable world dynamics and supporting open-domain, interactive planning.

title: Guaranteeing Conservation of Integrals with Projection in Physics-Informed Neural Networks
summary: We propose a novel projection method that guarantees the conservation of integral quantities in Physics-Informed Neural Networks (PINNs). While the soft constraint that PINNs use to enforce the structure of partial differential equations (PDEs) enables necessary flexibility during training, it also permits the discovered solution to violate physical laws. To address this, we introduce a projection method that guarantees the conservation of the linear and quadratic integrals, both separately and jointly. We derived the projection formulae by solving constrained non-linear optimization problems and found that our PINN modified with the projection, which we call PINN-Proj, reduced the error in the conservation of these quantities by three to four orders of magnitude compared to the soft constraint and marginally reduced the PDE solution error. We also found evidence that the projection improved convergence through improving the conditioning of the loss landscape. Our method holds promise as a general framework to guarantee the conservation of any integral quantity in a PINN if a tractable solution exists.

AI.tldr: Introduces PINN-Proj, a projection method that guarantees conservation of linear and quadratic integrals in PINNs; achieves 3–4 orders of magnitude improvement in conservation accuracy with only marginal PDE error change, suggesting a general framework for conserving integral quantities.
AI.motivation: PINNs rely on soft constraints to enforce PDE structure, which can allow solutions that violate essential physical conservation laws. A method that enforces exact conservation of integral quantities would improve physical fidelity.
AI.method: Derive projection formulae by solving constrained non-linear optimization problems and apply them to PINNs, producing PINN-Proj. The projection can enforce linear, quadratic, or both types of integral conserved quantities, individually or jointly.
AI.result: Conservation error decreases by 3–4 orders of magnitude compared to the soft constraint. PDE solution error is marginally reduced. Evidence suggests improved convergence via better conditioning of the loss landscape.
AI.conclusion: The projection-based approach provides a general framework to guarantee conservation of integral quantities in PINNs, given a tractable projection; could be extended to other integral quantities beyond linear and quadratic.

title: VietMEAgent: Culturally-Aware Few-Shot Multimodal Explanation for Vietnamese Visual Question Answering
summary: Contemporary Visual Question Answering (VQA) systems remain constrained when confronted with culturally specific content, largely because cultural knowledge is under-represented in training corpora and the reasoning process is not rendered interpretable to end users. This paper introduces VietMEAgent, a multimodal explainable framework engineered for Vietnamese cultural understanding. The method integrates a cultural object detection backbone with a structured program generation layer, yielding a pipeline in which answer prediction and explanation are tightly coupled. A curated knowledge base of Vietnamese cultural entities serves as an explicit source of background information, while a dual-modality explanation module combines attention-based visual evidence with structured, human-readable textual rationales. We further construct a Vietnamese Cultural VQA dataset sourced from public repositories and use it to demonstrate the practicality of programming-based methodologies for cultural AI. The resulting system provides transparent explanations that disclose both the computational rationale and the underlying cultural context, supporting education and cultural preservation with an emphasis on interpretability and cultural sensitivity.

AI.tldr: VietMEAgent is a multimodal, explainable VQA framework for Vietnamese culture that integrates a cultural object detection backbone, a structured program generation layer, and a Vietnamese cultural knowledge base, with a dual-modality explanation module; it also introduces a Vietnamese Cultural VQA dataset, demonstrating interpretable, culturally aware AI for education and preservation.
AI.motivation: Cultural knowledge is under-represented in training data and existing VQA systems often produce opaque reasoning. There is a need for culturally aware, interpretable AI that can reason with explicit cultural context to support education and preservation.
AI.method: A multimodal pipeline: (1) cultural object detection backbone to identify culturally salient visual concepts; (2) a structured program generation layer to perform reasoning via executable steps; (3) an explicit Vietnamese cultural knowledge base as background information; (4) a dual-modality explanation module that combines attention-based visual evidence with structured, human-readable textual rationales; (5) a Vietnamese Cultural VQA dataset to validate programming-based approaches for cultural AI.
AI.result: The approach demonstrates practicality of programming-based methodologies for cultural AI and yields transparent explanations that disclose both computational rationale and cultural context, indicating potential benefits for education and cultural preservation.
AI.conclusion: VietMEAgent provides transparent, interpretable explanations that fuse computational reasoning with Vietnamese cultural knowledge, supporting education, preservation, and culturally sensitive AI.

title: Break the Tie: Learning Cluster-Customized Category Relationships for Categorical Data Clustering
summary: Categorical attributes with qualitative values are ubiquitous in cluster analysis of real datasets. Unlike the Euclidean distance of numerical attributes, the categorical attributes lack well-defined relationships of their possible values (also called categories interchangeably), which hampers the exploration of compact categorical data clusters. Although most attempts are made for developing appropriate distance metrics, they typically assume a fixed topological relationship between categories when learning distance metrics, which limits their adaptability to varying cluster structures and often leads to suboptimal clustering performance. This paper, therefore, breaks the intrinsic relationship tie of attribute categories and learns customized distance metrics suitable for flexibly and accurately revealing various cluster distributions. As a result, the fitting ability of the clustering algorithm is significantly enhanced, benefiting from the learnable category relationships. Moreover, the learned category relationships are proved to be Euclidean distance metric-compatible, enabling a seamless extension to mixed datasets that include both numerical and categorical attributes. Comparative experiments on 12 real benchmark datasets with significance tests show the superior clustering accuracy of the proposed method with an average ranking of 1.25, which is significantly higher than the 5.21 ranking of the current best-performing method.

AI.tldr: Learns customized, Euclidean-compatible distance metrics for categorical attributes to flexibly reveal various cluster distributions, enabling seamless mixing with numerical data and achieving superior clustering performance.
AI.motivation: Categorical attributes lack a natural or fixed distance, and assuming a fixed category topology constrains clustering and fails to capture diverse cluster structures. A learnable, adaptable relationship among categories could improve clustering accuracy and generality, especially when integrating with numerical features.
AI.method: Breaks the intrinsic, fixed relationship among categories and learns category-wise distance metrics. The learned category relationships are designed to be compatible with Euclidean distance, enabling extension to mixed datasets (numerical + categorical). The approach focuses on tailoring the metric to reveal different cluster distributions rather than imposing a predetermined topology.
AI.result: Empirical validation on 12 real benchmark datasets with significance tests shows superior clustering accuracy, achieving an average ranking of 1.25 compared to 5.21 for the current best method.
AI.conclusion: Learned category relationships materially boost clustering performance on categorical data and are compatible with Euclidean metrics for mixed data, suggesting broad applicability and improved adaptability to varied cluster structures.

title: Diversifying Counterattacks: Orthogonal Exploration for Robust CLIP Inference
summary: Vision-language pre-training models (VLPs) demonstrate strong multimodal understanding and zero-shot generalization, yet remain vulnerable to adversarial examples, raising concerns about their reliability. Recent work, Test-Time Counterattack (TTC), improves robustness by generating perturbations that maximize the embedding deviation of adversarial inputs using PGD, pushing them away from their adversarial representations. However, due to the fundamental difference in optimization objectives between adversarial attacks and counterattacks, generating counterattacks solely based on gradients with respect to the adversarial input confines the search to a narrow space. As a result, the counterattacks could overfit limited adversarial patterns and lack the diversity to fully neutralize a broad range of perturbations. In this work, we argue that enhancing the diversity and coverage of counterattacks is crucial to improving adversarial robustness in test-time defense. Accordingly, we propose Directional Orthogonal Counterattack (DOC), which augments counterattack optimization by incorporating orthogonal gradient directions and momentum-based updates. This design expands the exploration of the counterattack space and increases the diversity of perturbations, which facilitates the discovery of more generalizable counterattacks and ultimately improves the ability to neutralize adversarial perturbations. Meanwhile, we present a directional sensitivity score based on averaged cosine similarity to boost DOC by improving example discrimination and adaptively modulating the counterattack strength. Extensive experiments on 16 datasets demonstrate that DOC improves adversarial robustness under various attacks while maintaining competitive clean accuracy. Code is available at https://github.com/bookman233/DOC.

AI.tldr: A Directional Orthogonal Counterattack (DOC) with a directional sensitivity score broadens the counterattack search space and adaptively tunes attack strength to improve test-time robustness of vision-language models, achieving better defense across 16 datasets while preserving clean accuracy; code is released.
AI.motivation: Vision-language pre-training models (VLPs) are vulnerable to adversarial inputs, raising reliability concerns. Existing Test-Time Counterattack (TTC) methods rely on gradient-based perturbations tied to adversarial inputs, which can limit exploration to a narrow space and cause overfitting to specific perturbation patterns. A broader, more diverse counterattack strategy is needed to generalize defenses against a wide range of perturbations.
AI.method: Introduce Directional Orthogonal Counterattack (DOC): augment counterattack optimization with orthogonal gradient directions and momentum-based updates to expand the search of perturbation space and increase perturbation diversity. Add a directional sensitivity score based on averaged cosine similarity to improve example discrimination and adaptively modulate counterattack strength.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on 16 datasets show that DOC improves adversarial robustness under various attacks while maintaining competitive clean accuracy, outperforming baseline counterattacks. The authors also provide code for reproducibility.
AI.conclusion: Enhancing the diversity and coverage of counterattacks is crucial for robust test-time defenses in VLPs. DOC demonstrates more generalizable, effective counterattacks that better neutralize perturbations, with adaptive strength guided by directional sensitivity.

title: Human-Corrected Labels Learning: Enhancing Labels Quality via Human Correction of VLMs Discrepancies
summary: Vision-Language Models (VLMs), with their powerful content generation capabilities, have been successfully applied to data annotation processes. However, the VLM-generated labels exhibit dual limitations: low quality (i.e., label noise) and absence of error correction mechanisms. To enhance label quality, we propose Human-Corrected Labels (HCLs), a novel setting that efficient human correction for VLM-generated noisy labels. As shown in Figure 1(b), HCL strategically deploys human correction only for instances with VLM discrepancies, achieving both higher-quality annotations and reduced labor costs. Specifically, we theoretically derive a risk-consistent estimator that incorporates both human-corrected labels and VLM predictions to train classifiers. Besides, we further propose a conditional probability method to estimate the label distribution using a combination of VLM outputs and model predictions. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our approach achieves superior classification performance and is robust to label noise, validating the effectiveness of HCL in practical weak supervision scenarios. Code https://github.com/Lilianach24/HCL.git

AI.tldr: Proposes Human-Corrected Labels (HCL) to improve VLM-generated annotations by selectively correcting VLM-discrepant labels; introduces a risk-consistent estimator and a conditional-probability label-distribution estimator to fuse human corrections with VLM predictions; demonstrates improved classification accuracy and robustness to label noise; code available.
AI.motivation: VLMs enable scalable data labeling but produce noisy labels and lack error correction. Efficiently combining human corrections with VLM outputs can elevate label quality while reducing labor.
AI.method: Selective human correction (on VLM-discrepant instances) forming HCL; derive a risk-consistent estimator that integrates human-corrected labels with VLM predictions for training classifiers; propose a conditional probability approach to estimate the label distribution from a mix of VLM outputs and model predictions.
AI.result: Experiments show superior classification performance and robustness to label noise under weak supervision; HCL yields higher-quality annotations with lower labor costs; code available.
AI.conclusion: HCL is an effective, cost-efficient strategy for improving VLM-generated labels by combining selective human corrections with principled statistical estimation.

title: Composition-Incremental Learning for Compositional Generalization
summary: Compositional generalization has achieved substantial progress in computer vision on pre-collected training data. Nonetheless, real-world data continually emerges, with possible compositions being nearly infinite, long-tailed, and not entirely visible. Thus, an ideal model is supposed to gradually improve the capability of compositional generalization in an incremental manner. In this paper, we explore Composition-Incremental Learning for Compositional Generalization (CompIL) in the context of the compositional zero-shot learning (CZSL) task, where models need to continually learn new compositions, intending to improve their compositional generalization capability progressively. To quantitatively evaluate CompIL, we develop a benchmark construction pipeline leveraging existing datasets, yielding MIT-States-CompIL and C-GQA-CompIL. Furthermore, we propose a pseudo-replay framework utilizing a visual synthesizer to synthesize visual representations of learned compositions and a linguistic primitive distillation mechanism to maintain aligned primitive representations across the learning process. Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed framework.

AI.tldr: A study on Composition-Incremental Learning (CompIL) for compositional generalization in CZSL, introducing benchmarks MIT-States-CompIL and C-GQA-CompIL, and a pseudo-replay framework with a visual synthesizer and linguistic primitive distillation to progressively improve generalization.
AI.motivation: Compositional generalization in vision is hindered by real-world data's continual emergence, long-tail distributions, and unseen compositions; an ideal model should improve incrementally as new compositions appear.
AI.method: Proposes a pseudo-replay framework that synthesizes visual representations of learned compositions via a visual synthesizer and maintains aligned primitive representations through linguistic primitive distillation; constructs two benchmarks MIT-States-CompIL and C-GQA-CompIL from existing datasets to evaluate incremental compositional learning in CZSL.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show the proposed approach effectively improves compositional generalization in a continual learning setting for CZSL.
AI.conclusion: CompIL provides a practical pathway toward progressive improvement of compositional generalization in CZSL, supported by benchmark pipelines and a pseudo-replay mechanism.

title: Factorization-in-Loop: Proximal Fill-in Minimization for Sparse Matrix Reordering
summary: Fill-ins are new nonzero elements in the summation of the upper and lower triangular factors generated during LU factorization. For large sparse matrices, they will increase the memory usage and computational time, and be reduced through proper row or column arrangement, namely matrix reordering. Finding a row or column permutation with the minimal fill-ins is NP-hard, and surrogate objectives are designed to derive fill-in reduction permutations or learn a reordering function. However, there is no theoretical guarantee between the golden criterion and these surrogate objectives. Here we propose to learn a reordering network by minimizing \(l_1\) norm of triangular factors of the reordered matrix to approximate the exact number of fill-ins. The reordering network utilizes a graph encoder to predict row or column node scores. For inference, it is easy and fast to derive the permutation from sorting algorithms for matrices. For gradient based optimization, there is a large gap between the predicted node scores and resultant triangular factors in the optimization objective. To bridge the gap, we first design two reparameterization techniques to obtain the permutation matrix from node scores. The matrix is reordered by multiplying the permutation matrix. Then we introduce the factorization process into the objective function to arrive at target triangular factors. The overall objective function is optimized with the alternating direction method of multipliers and proximal gradient descent. Experimental results on benchmark sparse matrix collection SuiteSparse show the fill-in number and LU factorization time reduction of our proposed method is 20% and 17.8% compared with state-of-the-art baselines.

AI.tldr: A learning-based reordering method for LU factorization minimizes the l1 norm of triangular factors to approximate fill-ins, using a graph encoder to predict row/column scores, reparameterized permutations, and optimization via ADMM and proximal gradient descent, achieving notable reductions in fill-ins and LU time on SuiteSparse.
AI.motivation: Fill-ins from LU factorization blow up memory and compute; finding the optimal row/column permutation is NP-hard; surrogate objectives lack guarantees linking to true fill-ins. The work aims to bridge this gap by learning a reordering that directly targets triangular factorization properties.
AI.method: Train a graph encoder to assign scores to matrix rows/columns. Derive a permutation via reparameterization techniques from node scores to a permutation matrix, reorder the matrix, and incorporate the factorization process into the objective to target triangular factors. Optimize via alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM) and proximal gradient descent. Inference uses sorting-based permutation extraction for efficiency. Evaluate on SuiteSparse against state-of-the-art baselines.
AI.result: The proposed approach reduces fill-in count by ~20% and LU factorization time by ~17.8% on benchmark SuiteSparse matrices compared to baselines.
AI.conclusion: A practical reordering network can bridge the gap between surrogate objectives and the true fill-in criterion, yielding faster LU factorizations with fewer fill-ins. Inference is efficient, but theoretical guarantees linking the surrogate loss to exact fill-ins remain unestablished.

title: Ultra-Light Test-Time Adaptation for Vision--Language Models
summary: Vision-Language Models (VLMs) such as CLIP achieve strong zero-shot recognition by comparing image embeddings to text-derived class prototypes. However, under domain shift, they suffer from feature drift, class-prior mismatch, and severe miscalibration. Existing test-time adaptation (TTA) methods often require backpropagation through large backbones, covariance estimation, or heavy memory/state, which is problematic for streaming and edge scenarios. We propose Ultra-Light Test-Time Adaptation (UL-TTA), a fully training-free and backprop-free framework that freezes the backbone and adapts only logit-level parameters: class prototypes, class priors, and temperature. UL-TTA performs an online EM-style procedure with (i) selective sample filtering to use only confident predictions, (ii) closed-form Bayesian updates for prototypes and priors anchored by text and Dirichlet priors, (iii) decoupled temperatures for prediction vs. calibration, and (iv) lightweight guards (norm clipping, prior KL constraints, smoothed temperature) to prevent drift in long streams. Across large-scale cross-domain and OOD benchmarks (PACS, Office-Home, DomainNet, Terra Incognita, ImageNet-R/A/V2/Sketch; ~726K test samples) and strong TTA baselines including Tent, T3A, CoTTA, SAR, Tip-Adapter, and FreeTTA, UL-TTA consistently improves top-1 accuracy (e.g., +4.7 points over zero-shot CLIP on average) while reducing ECE by 20-30%, with less than 8% latency overhead. Long-stream experiments up to 200K samples show no collapse. Our results demonstrate that logit-level Bayesian adaptation is sufficient to obtain state-of-the-art accuracy-calibration trade-offs for VLMs under domain shift, without updating any backbone parameters.

AI.tldr: UL-TTA is a training-free, backprop-free method that adapts only logit-level parameters (class prototypes, priors, temperature) for Vision-Language Models at test time via an online EM-style update with selective filtering and Bayesian closed-form updates, yielding strong accuracy and calibration with minimal latency and no backbone updates.
AI.motivation: Vision-Language Models like CLIP struggle under domain shift due to feature drift, class-prior mismatch, and miscalibration. Many existing test-time adaptation methods require backpropagation, covariance estimation, or heavy memory, making them unsuitable for streaming or edge scenarios. A lightweight, training-free TTA at the logit level could provide robust adaptation with low resource demands.
AI.method: Freeze the backbone and adapt only logit-level parameters: prototypes for each class, class priors, and temperature. Use an online EM-style procedure with (i) selective sample filtering to use confident predictions, (ii) closed-form Bayesian updates anchored by text and Dirichlet priors, (iii) decoupled temperatures for prediction versus calibration, and (iv) lightweight safeguards (norm clipping, prior KL constraints, smoothed temperature) to prevent drift in long streams. Evaluation across large cross-domain and OOD benchmarks (~726K test samples) against strong TTA baselines.
AI.result: UL-TTA consistently improves top-1 accuracy (e.g., around +4.7 points on average over zero-shot CLIP) and reduces calibration error (ECE) by 20–30%, with latency overhead under 8%. Long streams up to 200K samples show no collapse. The approach achieves state-of-the-art accuracy-calibration trade-offs without updating backbone parameters.
AI.conclusion: Logit-level Bayesian adaptation is sufficient to obtain strong accuracy and calibration for Vision-Language Models under domain shift, enabling high-performance TTA in streaming/edge contexts without backpropagation or backbone updates.

title: FedPM: Federated Learning Using Second-order Optimization with Preconditioned Mixing of Local Parameters
comment: 18 pages, 7 figures. Accepted for publication in the Proceedings of the AAAI Conference on Artificial Intelligence (AAAI-26)
summary:
We propose Federated Preconditioned Mixing (FedPM), a novel Federated Learning (FL) method that leverages second-order optimization. Prior methods--such as LocalNewton, LTDA, and FedSophia--have incorporated second-order optimization in FL by performing iterative local updates on clients and applying simple mixing of local parameters on the server. However, these methods often suffer from drift in local preconditioners, which significantly disrupts the convergence of parameter training, particularly in heterogeneous data settings. To overcome this issue, we refine the update rules by decomposing the ideal second-order update--computed using globally preconditioned global gradients--into parameter mixing on the server and local parameter updates on clients. As a result, our FedPM introduces preconditioned mixing of local parameters on the server, effectively mitigating drift in local preconditioners.
  We provide a theoretical convergence analysis demonstrating a superlinear rate for strongly convex objectives in scenarios involving a single local update. To demonstrate the practical benefits of FedPM, we conducted extensive experiments. The results showed significant improvements with FedPM in the test accuracy compared to conventional methods incorporating simple mixing, fully leveraging the potential of second-order optimization.

AI.tldr: FedPM is a federated learning method that uses preconditioned server-side mixing to realize second-order optimization, reducing drift of local preconditioners; it achieves near-superlinear convergence for strongly convex objectives with a single local update, and experiments show improved test accuracy over existing methods with simple mixing.
AI.motivation: Existing FL methods embedding second-order info (LocalNewton, LTDA, FedSophia) suffer from drift in local preconditioners due to local updates and naive server mixing, hindering convergence in heterogeneous data settings. A principled update decomposition could preserve the benefits of second-order methods while stabilizing training.
AI.method: Decompose the ideal second-order update into a server-side preconditioned mixing step and local client updates. FedPM performs preconditioned mixing of local parameters on the server, mitigating drift and aligning local updates with a globally preconditioned gradient.
AI.result: Theoretical analysis shows a superlinear convergence rate for strongly convex objectives with a single local update. Empirical results demonstrate significant accuracy gains over conventional mixing-based second-order FL methods.
AI.conclusion: FedPM mitigates drift in local preconditioners by separating server-side preconditioning and mixing from local updates, enabling more reliable convergence and practical gains from second-order optimization in federated learning, especially under data heterogeneity.

title: DKDS: A Benchmark Dataset of Degraded Kuzushiji Documents with Seals for Detection and Binarization
summary: Kuzushiji, a pre-modern Japanese cursive script, can currently be read and understood by only a few thousand trained experts in Japan. With the rapid development of deep learning, researchers have begun applying Optical Character Recognition (OCR) techniques to transcribe Kuzushiji into modern Japanese. Although existing OCR methods perform well on clean pre-modern Japanese documents written in Kuzushiji, they often fail to consider various types of noise, such as document degradation and seals, which significantly affect recognition accuracy. To the best of our knowledge, no existing dataset specifically addresses these challenges. To address this gap, we introduce the Degraded Kuzushiji Documents with Seals (DKDS) dataset as a new benchmark for related tasks. We describe the dataset construction process, which required the assistance of a trained Kuzushiji expert, and define two benchmark tracks: (1) text and seal detection and (2) document binarization. For the text and seal detection track, we provide baseline results using multiple versions of the You Only Look Once (YOLO) models for detecting Kuzushiji characters and seals. For the document binarization track, we present baseline results from traditional binarization algorithms, traditional algorithms combined with K-means clustering, and Generative Adversarial Network (GAN)-based methods. The DKDS dataset and the implementation code for baseline methods are available at https://ruiyangju.github.io/DKDS.

AI.tldr: Introduces the DKDS dataset for degraded Kuzushiji with seals, establishing two benchmark tracks (text/seal detection and document binarization) with baseline methods (YOLO variants for detection; traditional methods, K-means, and GAN-based approaches for binarization); dataset and code are publicly available.
AI.motivation: Kuzushiji is difficult to read even for trained experts; real-world documents exhibit noise from degradation and seals, which degrades OCR performance. There is no dataset targeting these noisy conditions, hindering robust OCR research for Kuzushiji.
AI.method: Construct a dataset (with Kuzushiji expert assistance) called Degraded Kuzushiji Documents with Seals (DKDS). Define two benchmark tracks: (1) text and seal detection using YOLO variants to detect Kuzushiji characters and seals; (2) document binarization using traditional binarization algorithms, combinations of traditional methods with K-means clustering, and GAN-based methods. Provide baseline results and release code and dataset publicly.
AI.result: Baseline results are provided for both tracks: YOLO-based text/seal detection and various binarization approaches. Specific numerical results are not stated in the abstract but the paper claims to present these baselines.
AI.conclusion: DKDS fills a gap by offering a realistic, noisy Kuzushiji dataset with corresponding tasks and baselines, enabling robust evaluation and encouraging development of OCR methods that handle degradation and seals; resources (data and code) are publicly available for the community.

title: Cost-Minimized Label-Flipping Poisoning Attack to LLM Alignment
comment: accepted for AAAI 2026 Special Track on AI Alignment
summary: Large language models (LLMs) are increasingly deployed in real-world systems, making it critical to understand their vulnerabilities. While data poisoning attacks during RLHF/DPO alignment have been studied empirically, their theoretical foundations remain unclear. We investigate the minimum-cost poisoning attack required to steer an LLM's policy toward an attacker's target by flipping preference labels during RLHF/DPO, without altering the compared outputs. We formulate this as a convex optimization problem with linear constraints, deriving lower and upper bounds on the minimum attack cost. As a byproduct of this theoretical analysis, we show that any existing label-flipping attack can be post-processed via our proposed method to reduce the number of label flips required while preserving the intended poisoning effect. Empirical results demonstrate that this cost-minimization post-processing can significantly reduce poisoning costs over baselines, particularly when the reward model's feature dimension is small relative to the dataset size. These findings highlight fundamental vulnerabilities in RLHF/DPO pipelines and provide tools to evaluate their robustness against low-cost poisoning attacks.

AI.tldr: Introduces a convex-optimization framework to compute the minimum-cost data-poisoning attack on RLHF/DPO by flipping preference labels; derives lower/upper bounds on attack cost and a post-processing method to reduce label flips; empirically shows cost reductions, especially when the reward model's feature dimension is small relative to dataset size.
AI.motivation: To understand and quantify fundamental vulnerabilities of RLHF/DPO pipelines to low-cost poisoning and provide a theoretical basis for evaluating robustness.
AI.method: Formulates the poisoning problem as a convex optimization with linear constraints representing label-flip costs and the poisoning objective; derives tight lower and upper bounds on the minimum attack cost; introduces a post-processing technique that reuses existing flips to minimize additional flips while preserving the poisoning effect.
AI.result: Bounds on minimum attack cost; demonstration that the post-processing reduces the required flips and costs compared to baseline attacks; empirical results show significant reductions in poisoning costs, particularly when RM feature dimension is small relative to dataset size.
AI.conclusion: Reveals fundamental vulnerabilities in RLHF/DPO pipelines; provides a practical framework to evaluate robustness against low-cost poisoning and a tool for reducing attack cost via post-processing of label flips.

title: PIFF: A Physics-Informed Generative Flow Model for Real-Time Flood Depth Mapping
summary: Flood mapping is crucial for assessing and mitigating flood impacts, yet traditional methods like numerical modeling and aerial photography face limitations in efficiency and reliability. To address these challenges, we propose PIFF, a physics-informed, flow-based generative neural network for near real-time flood depth estimation. Built on an image-to-image generative framework, it efficiently maps Digital Elevation Models (DEM) to flood depth predictions. The model is conditioned on a simplified inundation model (SPM) that embeds hydrodynamic priors into the training process. Additionally, a transformer-based rainfall encoder captures temporal dependencies in precipitation. Integrating physics-informed constraints with data-driven learning, PIFF captures the causal relationships between rainfall, topography, SPM, and flooding, replacing costly simulations with accurate, real-time flood maps. Using a 26 km study area in Tainan, Taiwan, with 182 rainfall scenarios ranging from 24 mm to 720 mm over 24 hours, our results demonstrate that PIFF offers an effective, data-driven alternative for flood prediction and response.

AI.tldr: PIFF is a physics-informed, flow-based generative network that maps DEM to flood depth in near real-time, using a hydrodynamic-prior SP model and a transformer rainfall encoder to learn rainfall-topography-flood causal relationships; validated on a 26 km study area in Taiwan with 182 rainfall scenarios.
AI.motivation: Traditional flood mapping methods (numerical modeling, aerial photography) struggle with efficiency and reliability for rapid flood estimation. A data-driven, physics-informed approach aims to deliver fast, accurate flood depth maps to improve decision-making and emergency response.
AI.method: An image-to-image generative framework that converts DEM to flood depth, conditioned on a simplified inundation model (SPM) embedding hydrodynamic priors. A transformer-based rainfall encoder captures temporal rainfall dependencies. Physics-informed constraints guide learning to reflect rainfall, topography, SPM, and flooding relationships.
AI.result: PIFF demonstrates effective data-driven flood prediction and near real-time flood mapping capability in a 26 km study area (Tainan, Taiwan) across 182 rainfall scenarios (24–720 mm over 24 h), offering a more efficient alternative to costly simulations.
AI.conclusion: Integrating physics-informed constraints with data-driven learning, PIFF provides a viable near real-time flood-depth estimation method by combining topographic data, hydrodynamic priors, and rainfall dynamics; suitable as a fast alternative to traditional simulations under limited computational resources.

title: Towards a Generalisable Cyber Defence Agent for Real-World Computer Networks
comment: CAMLIS 2025. To be published in the Proceedings of Machine Learning Research (PMLR)
summary: Recent advances in deep reinforcement learning for autonomous cyber defence have resulted in agents that can successfully defend simulated computer networks against cyber-attacks. However, many of these agents would need retraining to defend networks with differing topology or size, making them poorly suited to real-world networks where topology and size can vary over time. In this research we introduce a novel set of Topological Extensions for Reinforcement Learning Agents (TERLA) that provide generalisability for the defence of networks with differing topology and size, without the need for retraining. Our approach involves the use of heterogeneous graph neural network layers to produce a fixed-size latent embedding representing the observed network state. This representation learning stage is coupled with a reduced, fixed-size, semantically meaningful and interpretable action space. We apply TERLA to a standard deep reinforcement learning Proximal Policy Optimisation (PPO) agent model, and to reduce the sim-to-real gap, conduct our research using Cyber Autonomy Gym for Experimentation (CAGE) Challenge 4. This Cyber Operations Research Gym environment has many of the features of a real-world network, such as realistic Intrusion Detection System (IDS) events and multiple agents defending network segments of differing topology and size. TERLA agents retain the defensive performance of vanilla PPO agents whilst showing improved action efficiency. Generalisability has been demonstrated by showing that all TERLA agents have the same network-agnostic neural network architecture, and by deploying a single TERLA agent multiple times to defend network segments with differing topology and size, showing improved defensive performance and efficiency.

AI.tldr: A reinforcement learning defender for computer networks uses heterogeneous graph neural networks to create a fixed-size latent state representation and a fixed-size, interpretable action space, enabling a single TERLA agent to defend networks of varying topology and size without retraining. It integrates with PPO in the CAGE Challenge 4 environment, retaining performance while improving action efficiency and generalization.
AI.motivation: Existing deep RL agents for autonomous cyber defence struggle to generalize across networks with different topology and size, requiring retraining for real-world applicability. This limits deployment on dynamic networks.
AI.method: Introduce TERLA: a set of topological extensions using heterogeneous graph neural network layers to produce a fixed-size latent embedding of the observed network state, paired with a reduced, fixed-size, semantically meaningful action space. Apply this within a PPO agent and evaluate in CAGE Challenge 4 (Cyber Autonomy Gym).
AI.result: TERLA agents maintain the defensive performance of vanilla PPO agents while achieving improved action efficiency. They generalize across networks with different topology and size, demonstrated by a single network-agnostic architecture deployed across segments with varying topology, resulting in improved defensive performance and efficiency.
AI.conclusion: TERLA enables topology- and size-generalizable cyber defence with DRL without retraining, potentially reducing the sim-to-real gap and enabling deployment across diverse real-world networks.

title: MACEval: A Multi-Agent Continual Evaluation Network for Large Models
summary: Hundreds of benchmarks dedicated to evaluating large models from multiple perspectives have been presented over the past few years. Albeit substantial efforts, most of them remain closed-ended and are prone to overfitting due to the potential data contamination in the ever-growing training corpus of large models, thereby undermining the credibility of the evaluation. Moreover, the increasing scale and scope of current benchmarks with transient metrics, as well as the heavily human-dependent curation procedure, pose significant challenges for timely maintenance and adaptation to gauge the advancing capabilities of large models. In this paper, we introduce MACEval, a \Multi-Agent Continual Evaluation network for dynamic evaluation of large models, and define a new set of metrics to quantify performance longitudinally and sustainably. MACEval adopts an interactive and autonomous evaluation mode that employs role assignment, in-process data generation, and evaluation routing through a cascaded agent network. Extensive experiments on 9 open-ended tasks with 23 participating large models demonstrate that MACEval is (1) human-free and automatic, mitigating laborious result processing with inter-agent judgment guided; (2) efficient and economical, reducing a considerable amount of data and overhead to obtain similar results compared to related benchmarks; and (3) flexible and scalable, migrating or integrating existing benchmarks via customized evaluation topologies. We hope that MACEval can broaden future directions of large model evaluation.

AI.tldr: MACEval is a scalable, autonomous multi-agent evaluation framework for large models that minimizes human labor, reduces data overhead, and maintains dynamic longitudinal metrics, demonstrated on 9 tasks with 23 models.
AI.motivation: Current benchmarks for evaluating large models are largely closed-ended, susceptible to data contamination and overfitting due to growing training corpora. They rely heavily on human curation, making maintenance and adaptation slow and expensive. There is a need for longitudinal, sustainable, and scalable evaluation as models advance.
AI.method: Introduce MACEval, a Multi-Agent Continual Evaluation network that conducts interactive, autonomous evaluation. It uses role assignment, in-process data generation, and evaluation routing through a cascaded agent network, along with new metrics to quantify performance over time. Evaluation conducted on 9 open-ended tasks with 23 models.
AI.result: MACEval operates with minimal human intervention, guided by inter-agent judgment, and is efficient and economical in data usage and overhead. It is flexible and scalable, capable of migrating or integrating existing benchmarks via customized evaluation topologies, and demonstrates comparable results to related benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: MACEval broadens the future direction of large model evaluation by enabling dynamic, sustainable, and low-labor evaluation at scale, with the ability to integrate with existing benchmarks.

title: Trusted Multi-view Learning for Long-tailed Classification
comment: This paper has been accepted to AAAI2026
summary: Class imbalance has been extensively studied in single-view scenarios; however, addressing this challenge in multi-view contexts remains an open problem, with even scarcer research focusing on trustworthy solutions. In this paper, we tackle a particularly challenging class imbalance problem in multi-view scenarios: long-tailed classification. We propose TMLC, a Trusted Multi-view Long-tailed Classification framework, which makes contributions on two critical aspects: opinion aggregation and pseudo-data generation. Specifically, inspired by Social Identity Theory, we design a group consensus opinion aggregation mechanism that guides decision making toward the direction favored by the majority of the group. In terms of pseudo-data generation, we introduce a novel distance metric to adapt SMOTE for multi-view scenarios and develop an uncertainty-guided data generation module that produces high-quality pseudo-data, effectively mitigating the adverse effects of class imbalance. Extensive experiments on long-tailed multi-view datasets demonstrate that our model is capable of achieving superior performance. The code is released at https://github.com/cncq-tang/TMLC.

AI.tldr: A framework (TMLC) for long-tailed multi-view classification that uses group consensus opinion aggregation and uncertainty-guided SMOTE-style pseudo-data generation to address class imbalance, achieving superior performance on multi-view datasets.
AI.motivation: Class imbalance in multi-view settings is under-explored and requires trustworthy, robust solutions; leveraging social-psychology ideas and data augmentation could improve multi-view decision making and minority-class coverage.
AI.method: Opinion aggregation via a group consensus mechanism inspired by Social Identity Theory; a novel distance metric to adapt SMOTE for multi-view data; an uncertainty-guided pseudo-data generation module to create high-quality minority samples.
AI.result: Empirical results on long-tailed multi-view datasets show superior performance over baselines; code is released for replication.
AI.conclusion: Combining trusted group-based opinion aggregation with uncertainty-aware pseudo-data synthesis effectively mitigates imbalance in multi-view long-tailed classification and provides a practical, replicable approach.

title: PressTrack-HMR: Pressure-Based Top-Down Multi-Person Global Human Mesh Recovery
summary: Multi-person global human mesh recovery (HMR) is crucial for understanding crowd dynamics and interactions. Traditional vision-based HMR methods sometimes face limitations in real-world scenarios due to mutual occlusions, insufficient lighting, and privacy concerns. Human-floor tactile interactions offer an occlusion-free and privacy-friendly alternative for capturing human motion. Existing research indicates that pressure signals acquired from tactile mats can effectively estimate human pose in single-person scenarios. However, when multiple individuals walk randomly on the mat simultaneously, how to distinguish intermingled pressure signals generated by different persons and subsequently acquire individual temporal pressure data remains a pending challenge for extending pressure-based HMR to the multi-person situation. In this paper, we present \textbf{PressTrack-HMR}, a top-down pipeline that recovers multi-person global human meshes solely from pressure signals. This pipeline leverages a tracking-by-detection strategy to first identify and segment each individual's pressure signal from the raw pressure data, and subsequently performs HMR for each extracted individual signal. Furthermore, we build a multi-person interaction pressure dataset \textbf{MIP}, which facilitates further research into pressure-based human motion analysis in multi-person scenarios. Experimental results demonstrate that our method excels in multi-person HMR using pressure data, with 89.2~$mm$ MPJPE and 112.6~$mm$ WA-MPJPE$_{100}$, and these showcase the potential of tactile mats for ubiquitous, privacy-preserving multi-person action recognition. Our dataset \& code are available at https://github.com/Jiayue-Yuan/PressTrack-HMR.

AI.tldr: A top-down, pressure-signal–based multi-person HMR pipeline (PressTrack-HMR) that segments individual pressure signals via tracking-by-detection and reconstructs their meshes, accompanied by the MIP dataset; achieves 89.2 mm MPJPE and 112.6 mm WA-MPJPE_100.
AI.motivation: Vision-based HMR is limited by occlusions, lighting, and privacy, while tactile pressure mats offer occlusion-free, privacy-preserving sensing; multi-person separation of mixed pressure signals remains unsolved.
AI.method: A tracking-by-detection pipeline to identify and segment each individual's pressure signal from raw data, followed by HMR for each extracted signal; introduces the multi-person interaction pressure dataset MIP.
AI.result: Demonstrates strong performance on multi-person HMR using pressure data, reporting 89.2 mm MPJPE and 112.6 mm WA-MPJPE_100; dataset and code are released to enable further research.
AI.conclusion: Shows that pressure-based HMR is viable for privacy-preserving multi-person motion capture; tactile mats hold promise for ubiquitous multi-person action recognition, with the MIP dataset as a resource for future work.

title: Practical Global and Local Bounds in Gaussian Process Regression via Chaining
comment: Accepted as a conference paper at AAAI2026
summary: Gaussian process regression (GPR) is a popular nonparametric Bayesian method that provides predictive uncertainty estimates and is widely used in safety-critical applications. While prior research has introduced various uncertainty bounds, most existing approaches require access to specific input features and rely on posterior mean and variance estimates or tuning hyperparameters. These limitations hinder robustness and fail to capture the model's global behavior in expectation. To address these limitations, we propose a chaining-based framework for estimating upper and lower bounds on the expected extreme values over unseen data, without requiring access to specific input locations. We provide kernel-specific refinements for commonly used kernels such as RBF and Matérn, in which our bounds are tighter than generic constructions. We further improve numerical tightness by avoiding analytical relaxations. In addition to global estimation, we also develop a novel method for local uncertainty quantification at specified inputs. This approach leverages chaining geometry through partition diameters, adapting to local structure without relying on posterior variance scaling. Our experimental results validate the theoretical findings and demonstrate that our method outperforms existing approaches on both synthetic and real-world datasets.

AI.tldr: A chaining-based framework for global and local uncertainty bounds in Gaussian process regression, independent of input locations, with kernel-specific refinements (RBF, Matérn); avoids relaxations for tighter bounds and demonstrates improved performance on synthetic and real data.
AI.motivation: Existing uncertainty bounds often depend on access to specific input features and rely on posterior mean/variance or hyperparameter tuning, hindering robustness and failing to capture global behavior in expectation. There is a need for bounds that are input-location agnostic and reflect the model's global behavior, as well as methods for local uncertainty quantification.
AI.method: Introduce a chaining-based framework to estimate upper and lower bounds on the expected extreme values over unseen data without requiring access to specific input locations. Provide kernel-specific refinements for common kernels (RBF, Matérn) to yield tighter bounds. Avoid analytical relaxations to improve numerical tightness. Develop a local uncertainty quantification approach at specified inputs by leveraging chaining geometry through partition diameters, adapting to local structure without relying on posterior variance scaling.
AI.result: Derives theoretically tighter global bounds for GPR, with kernel-specific refinements that outperform generic constructions. Demonstrates improved numerical tightness by avoiding analytical relaxations. Presents a novel local uncertainty quantification method that adapts to local data geometry. Empirical results on synthetic and real-world datasets show the approach outperforms existing methods.
AI.conclusion: The proposed chaining-based framework enables robust global and local uncertainty quantification for Gaussian process regression without needing access to specific input locations. Kernel-specific refinements provide tighter bounds, and avoiding relaxations yields better numerical tightness. The approach is validated experimentally and offers practical benefits for safety-critical applications.

title: Enabling Agents to Communicate Entirely in Latent Space
summary: While natural language is the de facto communication medium for LLM-based agents, it presents a fundamental constraint. The process of downsampling rich, internal latent states into discrete tokens inherently limits the depth and nuance of information that can be transmitted, thereby hindering collaborative problem-solving. Inspired by human mind-reading, we propose Interlat (Inter-agent Latent Space Communication), a paradigm that leverages the last hidden states of an LLM as a representation of its mind for direct transmission (termed latent communication). An additional compression process further compresses latent communication via entirely latent space reasoning. Experiments demonstrate that Interlat outperforms both fine-tuned chain-of-thought (CoT) prompting and single-agent baselines, promoting more exploratory behavior and enabling genuine utilization of latent information. Further compression not only substantially accelerates inference but also maintains competitive performance through an efficient information-preserving mechanism. We position this work as a feasibility study of entirely latent space inter-agent communication, and our results highlight its potential, offering valuable insights for future research.

AI.tldr: Proposes Interlat, a latent-space inter-agent communication paradigm that uses LLM hidden states as a direct “mind” representation, with additional latent-space compression; it outperforms CoT baselines and single-agent setups, showing feasibility and potential for faster, richer collaboration.
AI.motivation: Discrete tokenization of natural language caps information depth and hampers collaborative problem-solving. By transmitting latent representations (akin to mind-reading) and compressing them, agents can exchange richer information to improve performance.
AI.method: Use the last hidden states of LLMs as a representation of each agent’s mind for direct transmission (latent communication). Apply an additional latent-space compression/reasoning step. Evaluate against fine-tuned chain-of-thought prompting and single-agent baselines, focusing on exploratory behavior and latent-information utilization, plus a mechanism for information-preserving compression to speed inference.
AI.result: Interlat outperforms both fine-tuned CoT prompting and single-agent baselines, promoting more exploratory behavior and enabling genuine utilization of latent information. Further compression accelerates inference while maintaining competitive performance via an information-preserving mechanism.
AI.conclusion: Feasibility study of entirely latent-space inter-agent communication. Results indicate the approach has potential and offers insights for future research into richer, faster inter-agent collaboration without relying on discrete tokenized communication.

title: DBINDS -- Can Initial Noise from Diffusion Model Inversion Help Reveal AI-Generated Videos?
comment: Preprint. Submitted to IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing (TDSC) on 16 September 2025
summary: AI-generated video has advanced rapidly and poses serious challenges to content security and forensic analysis. Existing detectors rely mainly on pixel-level visual cues and generalize poorly to unseen generators. We propose DBINDS, a diffusion-model-inversion based detector that analyzes latent-space dynamics rather than pixels. We find that initial noise sequences recovered by diffusion inversion differ systematically between real and generated videos. Building on this, DBINDS forms an Initial Noise Difference Sequence (INDS) and extracts multi-domain, multi-scale features. With feature optimization and a LightGBM classifier tuned by Bayesian search, DBINDS (trained on a single generator) achieves strong cross-generator performance on GenVidBench, demonstrating good generalization and robustness in limited-data settings.

AI.tldr: DBINDS uses diffusion-model-inversion to compare latent-space initial noise between real and generated videos, forming an INDS for multi-domain, multi-scale features. Trained on one generator, it generalizes across generators, showing robust, data-efficient detection on GenVidBench.
AI.motivation: AI-generated video poses content security risks and standard pixel-based detectors generalize poorly to unseen generators; a detector leveraging latent-space dynamics could offer better cross-generator generalization and robustness, especially in limited-data scenarios.
AI.method: Apply diffusion inversion to recover initial noise sequences from videos, compute an Initial Noise Difference Sequence (INDS) between real and generated content, extract multi-domain and multi-scale features, optimize features, and train a LightGBM classifier with Bayesian-tuned hyperparameters. The model is trained on data from a single generator and evaluated on multiple generators.
AI.result: DBINDS achieves strong cross-generator performance on GenVidBench, indicating effective generalization to unseen generators and robustness in limited-data settings.
AI.conclusion: Latent-space dynamics revealed by diffusion-inversion can be leveraged to build detectors that generalize beyond seen generators, offering a promising direction for robust, data-efficient AI-generated video detection.

title: Unsupervised Feature Selection Through Group Discovery
summary: Unsupervised feature selection (FS) is essential for high-dimensional learning tasks where labels are not available. It helps reduce noise, improve generalization, and enhance interpretability. However, most existing unsupervised FS methods evaluate features in isolation, even though informative signals often emerge from groups of related features. For example, adjacent pixels, functionally connected brain regions, or correlated financial indicators tend to act together, making independent evaluation suboptimal. Although some methods attempt to capture group structure, they typically rely on predefined partitions or label supervision, limiting their applicability. We propose GroupFS, an end-to-end, fully differentiable framework that jointly discovers latent feature groups and selects the most informative groups among them, without relying on fixed a priori groups or label supervision. GroupFS enforces Laplacian smoothness on both feature and sample graphs and applies a group sparsity regularizer to learn a compact, structured representation. Across nine benchmarks spanning images, tabular data, and biological datasets, GroupFS consistently outperforms state-of-the-art unsupervised FS in clustering and selects groups of features that align with meaningful patterns.

AI.tldr: End-to-end differentiable GroupFS learns latent feature groups and performs group-based unsupervised feature selection via Laplacian smoothness and group sparsity.
AI.motivation: Unsupervised feature selection often evaluates features individually, missing informative signals that arise from groups of related features. Prior methods rely on predefined partitions or supervision, limiting applicability across data modalities.
AI.method: GroupFS jointly discovers latent feature groups and selects informative groups in an end-to-end differentiable framework. It enforces Laplacian smoothness on both feature and sample graphs and uses a group sparsity regularizer to produce a compact, structured representation without relying on fixed groups or labels.
AI.result: Across nine benchmarks spanning images, tabular data, and biological datasets, GroupFS consistently outperforms state-of-the-art unsupervised FS in clustering and yields groups of features that align with meaningful patterns.
AI.conclusion: Learning latent, structured feature groups in an unsupervised, differentiable framework enhances clustering performance and interpretability across diverse data types, without requiring predefined partitions or labels.

title: Towards Trustworthy Dermatology MLLMs: A Benchmark and Multimodal Evaluator for Diagnostic Narratives
summary: Multimodal large language models (LLMs) are increasingly used to generate dermatology diagnostic narratives directly from images. However, reliable evaluation remains the primary bottleneck for responsible clinical deployment. We introduce a novel evaluation framework that combines DermBench, a meticulously curated benchmark, with DermEval, a robust automatic evaluator, to enable clinically meaningful, reproducible, and scalable assessment. We build DermBench, which pairs 4,000 real-world dermatology images with expert-certified diagnostic narratives and uses an LLM-based judge to score candidate narratives across clinically grounded dimensions, enabling consistent and comprehensive evaluation of multimodal models. For individual case assessment, we train DermEval, a reference-free multimodal evaluator. Given an image and a generated narrative, DermEval produces a structured critique along with an overall score and per-dimension ratings. This capability enables fine-grained, per-case analysis, which is critical for identifying model limitations and biases. Experiments on a diverse dataset of 4,500 cases demonstrate that DermBench and DermEval achieve close alignment with expert ratings, with mean deviations of 0.251 and 0.117 (out of 5), respectively, providing reliable measurement of diagnostic ability and trustworthiness across different multimodal LLMs.

AI.tldr: A new two-part evaluation framework (DermBench + DermEval) to assess multimodal dermatology LLMs: a large, expert-labeled benchmark and a reference-free evaluator for per-case critique; achieves close alignment with expert ratings (mean deviations 0.251 and 0.117 on a 5-point scale) across 4,500 cases.
AI.motivation: Reliable, clinically meaningful evaluation is the bottleneck for deploying multimodal dermatology LLMs. Existing metrics struggle with alignment to expert judgments, scalability, and per-case diagnostics.
AI.method: DermBench compiles 4,000 real-world dermatology images with expert-certified diagnostic narratives; an LLM-based judge assesses narratives across clinically grounded dimensions. DermEval is a reference-free multimodal evaluator that, given an image and a generated narrative, outputs a structured critique, an overall score, and per-dimension ratings. Evaluation is demonstrated on 4,500 cases across diverse multimodal LLMs to enable fine-grained analysis.
AI.result: DermBench and DermEval show alignment with expert ratings, with mean deviations of 0.251 and 0.117 on a 5-point scale, respectively, indicating reliable measurement of diagnostic ability and trustworthiness across diverse multimodal LLMs.
AI.conclusion: The framework provides a clinically meaningful, scalable, and reproducible evaluation paradigm for multimodal dermatology LLMs. DermBench offers a standardized benchmark; DermEval enables per-case critique and bias identification, supporting robust deployment and future methodological expansion.

title: Compact Memory for Continual Logistic Regression
summary: Despite recent progress, continual learning still does not match the performance of batch training. To avoid catastrophic forgetting, we need to build compact memory of essential past knowledge, but no clear solution has yet emerged, even for shallow neural networks with just one or two layers. In this paper, we present a new method to build compact memory for logistic regression. Our method is based on a result by Khan and Swaroop [2021] who show the existence of optimal memory for such models. We formulate the search for the optimal memory as Hessian-matching and propose a probabilistic PCA method to estimate them. Our approach can drastically improve accuracy compared to Experience Replay. For instance, on Split-ImageNet, we get 60% accuracy compared to 30% obtained by replay with memory-size equivalent to 0.3% of the data size. Increasing the memory size to 2% further boosts the accuracy to 74%, closing the gap to the batch accuracy of 77.6% on this task. Our work opens a new direction for building compact memory that can also be useful in the future for continual deep learning.

AI.tldr: A Hessian-matching based method with probabilistic PCA to estimate optimal memory for continual learning in logistic regression; achieves large gains on Split-ImageNet, approaching batch performance.
AI.motivation: Continual learning suffers from catastrophic forgetting; existing memory-based approaches (e.g., Experience Replay) are suboptimal and fail to match batch training; exploring optimal, compact memory for simple models can guide future deep-learning methods.
AI.method: Formulate memory optimization as Hessian-matching to find the optimal memory; estimate Hessians using probabilistic PCA; evaluate on logistic regression with memory sizes as low as 0.3% of data and up to 2%, reporting accuracy on Split-ImageNet.
AI.result: Significant accuracy gains over Experience Replay: 60% accuracy with 0.3% memory vs 30% with replay; 74% accuracy with 2% memory; batch accuracy on task is 77.6%, close to the memory-augmented results.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates that compact, optimally chosen memory can substantially reduce forgetting and close the gap to batch training; suggests a promising direction for continual learning approaches, potentially extendable to deeper models.

title: Taming Object Hallucinations with Verified Atomic Confidence Estimation
summary: Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) often suffer from hallucinations, particularly errors in object existence, attributes, or relations, which undermine their reliability. We introduce TACO (Verified Atomic Confidence Estimation), a simple framework that mitigates hallucinations through self-verification and confidence calibration without relying on external vision experts. TACO decomposes responses into atomic queries, paraphrases them to reduce sensitivity to wording, and estimates confidence using self-consistency (black-box) or self-confidence (gray-box) aggregation, before refining answers with a language model. Experiments on five benchmarks (POPE, MME, HallusionBench, AMBER, and MM-Hal Bench) with two MLLMs (\texttt{LLaVA-1.5-7B} and \texttt{CogVLM2}) show that TACO consistently outperforms direct prompting and Visual Contrastive Decoding, reduces systematic biases, and improves confidence calibration, demonstrating its effectiveness in enhancing the faithfulness of MLLMs.

AI.tldr: TACO provides a self-verifying, confidence-calibrated framework to mitigate hallucinations in Multimodal LLMs by decomposing tasks into atomic queries, paraphrasing, and aggregating with self-consistency or self-confidence, then refining answers.
AI.motivation: MLLMs frequently hallucinate (existence, attributes, relations). These errors undermine reliability and often require external vision expertise to mitigate. A lightweight, calibration-friendly approach without external experts is desirable.
AI.method: Decompose responses into atomic queries; paraphrase them to reduce sensitivity to wording; estimate confidence using either black-box self-consistency or gray-box self-confidence aggregation; refine answers with a language model.
AI.result: Outperforms direct prompting and Visual Contrastive Decoding on five benchmarks (POPE, MME, HallusionBench, AMBER, MM-Hal Bench) using two MLLMs (LLaVA-1.5-7B and CogVLM2); reduces systematic biases; improves confidence calibration; enhances faithfulness of MLLMs.
AI.conclusion: TACO effectively reduces hallucinations and improves the faithfulness of Multimodal LLMs without relying on external vision experts, demonstrating robustness across multiple datasets and models.

title: Data Fusion-Enhanced Decision Transformer for Stable Cross-Domain Generalization
summary: Cross-domain shifts present a significant challenge for decision transformer (DT) policies. Existing cross-domain policy adaptation methods typically rely on a single simple filtering criterion to select source trajectory fragments and stitch them together. They match either state structure or action feasibility. However, the selected fragments still have poor stitchability: state structures can misalign, the return-to-go (RTG) becomes incomparable when the reward or horizon changes, and actions may jump at trajectory junctions. As a result, RTG tokens lose continuity, which compromises DT's inference ability. To tackle these challenges, we propose Data Fusion-Enhanced Decision Transformer (DFDT), a compact pipeline that restores stitchability. Particularly, DFDT fuses scarce target data with selectively trusted source fragments via a two-level data filter, maximum mean discrepancy (MMD) mismatch for state-structure alignment, and optimal transport (OT) deviation for action feasibility. It then trains on a feasibility-weighted fusion distribution. Furthermore, DFDT replaces RTG tokens with advantage-conditioned tokens, which improves the continuity of the semantics in the token sequence. It also applies a $Q$-guided regularizer to suppress junction value and action jumps. Theoretically, we provide bounds that tie state value and policy performance gaps to the MMD-mismatch and OT-deviation measures, and show that the bounds tighten as these two measures shrink. We show that DFDT improves return and stability over strong offline RL and sequence-model baselines across gravity, kinematic, and morphology shifts on D4RL-style control tasks, and further corroborate these gains with token-stitching and sequence-semantics stability analyses.

AI.tldr: Data Fusion-Enhanced Decision Transformer (DFDT) restores stitchability in cross-domain decision transformer policies by two-level data filtering, MMD-based state-structure alignment, OT-based action-feasibility alignment, and feasibility-weighted fusion; it replaces RTG with advantage-conditioned tokens and uses a Q-guided regularizer, yielding improved return and stability on D4RL-like shifts.
AI.motivation: Cross-domain shifts degrade decision transformer performance due to poor stitchability from using a single filtering criterion. Misaligned state structures, incomparable RTG due to reward/horizon changes, and abrupt action jumps at junctions degrade continuity of RTG tokens and the model's inference.
AI.method: A two-level data filter selects trusted source fragments; MMD mismatch aligns state structures; OT deviation enforces action feasibility; train on a feasibility-weighted fusion distribution; replace RTG tokens with advantage-conditioned tokens to maintain semantic continuity; apply a Q-guided regularizer to suppress junction value and action jumps; provide theoretical bounds linking state-value and policy gaps to MMD and OT; evaluate on gravity, kinematic, and morphology shifts in D4RL-style control tasks with token-stitching and sequence-semantics analyses.
AI.result: DFDT improves return and stability over strong offline RL and sequence-model baselines across the tested cross-domain shifts; token-stitching and sequence-semantics analyses corroborate the gains.
AI.conclusion: DFDT offers a principled data-fusion pipeline to restore stitchability and improve cross-domain transfer for decision transformers; theoretical bounds show improvements tighten as MMD-mismatch and OT-deviation decrease.

title: Spatial Information Bottleneck for Interpretable Visual Recognition
summary: Deep neural networks typically learn spatially entangled representations that conflate discriminative foreground features with spurious background correlations, thereby undermining model interpretability and robustness. We propose a novel understanding framework for gradient-based attribution from an information-theoretic perspective. We prove that, under mild conditions, the Vector-Jacobian Products (VJP) computed during backpropagation form minimal sufficient statistics of input features with respect to class labels. Motivated by this finding, we propose an encoding-decoding perspective : forward propagation encodes inputs into class space, while VJP in backpropagation decodes this encoding back to feature space. Therefore, we propose Spatial Information Bottleneck (S-IB) to spatially disentangle information flow. By maximizing mutual information between foreground VJP and inputs while minimizing mutual information in background regions, S-IB encourages networks to encode information only in class-relevant spatial regions. Since post-hoc explanation methods fundamentally derive from VJP computations, directly optimizing VJP's spatial structure during training improves visualization quality across diverse explanation paradigms. Experiments on five benchmarks demonstrate universal improvements across six explanation methods, achieving better foreground concentration and background suppression without method-specific tuning, alongside consistent classification accuracy gains.

AI.tldr: S-IB uses an information-theoretic objective to disentangle gradient information by shaping VJPs; it maximizes mutual information of foreground VJPs with inputs and minimizes mutual information in background, improving explanation quality across methods with no tuning and preserving accuracy.
AI.motivation: Gradient-based attributions are often confounded by spurious background correlations, hurting interpretability and robustness. A framework that steers gradient signals to class-relevant spatial regions is needed.
AI.method: The paper proves that Vector-Jacobian Products (VJPs) during backprop form minimal sufficient statistics of inputs for class labels under mild conditions. It then adopts an encoding-decoding view where forward pass encodes inputs into class space and backprop decodes via VJPs. The Spatial Information Bottleneck (S-IB) objective is introduced to maximize mutual information between foreground VJPs and inputs while minimizing mutual information for background regions, encouraging information to reside only in class-relevant spatial regions.
AI.result: Experiments on five benchmarks show universal improvements across six explanation methods: better foreground concentration and background suppression, no method-specific tuning, and consistent/classification accuracy gains.
AI.conclusion: S-IB offers a general, gradient-guided regularization framework that shapes spatial information flow to align gradient-based explanations with class-relevant regions, improving interpretability and robustness without sacrificing performance.

title: FSampler: Training Free Acceleration of Diffusion Sampling via Epsilon Extrapolation
comment: 10 pages; diffusion models; accelerated sampling; ODE solvers; epsilon extrapolation; training free inference
summary: FSampler is a training free, sampler agnostic execution layer that accelerates diffusion sampling by reducing the number of function evaluations (NFE). FSampler maintains a short history of denoising signals (epsilon) from recent real model calls and extrapolates the next epsilon using finite difference predictors at second order, third order, or fourth order, falling back to lower order when history is insufficient. On selected steps the predicted epsilon substitutes the model call while keeping each sampler's update rule unchanged. Predicted epsilons are validated for finiteness and magnitude; a learning stabilizer rescales predictions on skipped steps to correct drift, and an optional gradient estimation stabilizer compensates local curvature. Protected windows, periodic anchors, and a cap on consecutive skips bound deviation over the trajectory. Operating at the sampler level, FSampler integrates with Euler/DDIM, DPM++ 2M/2S, LMS/AB2, and RES family exponential multistep methods and drops into standard workflows. FLUX.1 dev, Qwen Image, and Wan 2.2, FSampler reduces time by 8 to 22% and model calls by 15 to 25% at high fidelity (Structural Similarity Index (SSIM) 0.95 to 0.99), without altering sampler formulas. With an aggressive adaptive gate, reductions can reach 45 to 50% fewer model calls at lower fidelity (SSIM 0.73 to 0.74).

AI.tldr: A training-free extrapolation-based acceleration layer (FSampler) for diffusion samplers that predicts epsilon using finite-difference history to skip model calls, achieving notable speedups without changing sampler formulas.
AI.motivation: Diffusion model sampling is slow due to many function evaluations. A training-free, sampler-agnostic layer that reduces NFEs while preserving sampler behavior would greatly speed up inference without retraining.
AI.method: Maintain a short history of denoising signals (epsilon) from real model calls. Use second- to fourth-order finite-difference predictors to extrapolate the next epsilon.
