AI.conclusion: MAI enables tractable learning for nonstationary RMABs and facilitates robust policy synthesis in MARBLE. The QWI approach effectively handles latent regime switches, making MARBLE a promising framework for decision-making under nonstationarity in real-world systems.

title: RF-DETR: Neural Architecture Search for Real-Time Detection Transformers
summary: Open-vocabulary detectors achieve impressive performance on COCO, but often fail to generalize to real-world datasets with out-of-distribution classes not typically found in their pre-training. Rather than simply fine-tuning a heavy-weight vision-language model (VLM) for new domains, we introduce RF-DETR, a light-weight specialist detection transformer that discovers accuracy-latency Pareto curves for any target dataset with weight-sharing neural architecture search (NAS). Our approach fine-tunes a pre-trained base network on a target dataset and evaluates thousands of network configurations with different accuracy-latency tradeoffs without re-training. Further, we revisit the "tunable knobs" for NAS to improve the transferability of DETRs to diverse target domains. Notably, RF-DETR significantly improves on prior state-of-the-art real-time methods on COCO and Roboflow100-VL. RF-DETR (nano) achieves 48.0 AP on COCO, beating D-FINE (nano) by 5.3 AP at similar latency, and RF-DETR (2x-large) outperforms GroundingDINO (tiny) by 1.2 AP on Roboflow100-VL while running 20x as fast. To the best of our knowledge, RF-DETR (2x-large) is the first real-time detector to surpass 60 AP on COCO. Our code is at https://github.com/roboflow/rf-detr

AI.tldr: RF-DETR is a lightweight, NAS-driven DETR that finds accuracy-latency Pareto-optimal models for a target dataset by fine-tuning a base network and evaluating thousands of configurations without re-training, enabling real-time, transferable open-vocabulary detection.
AI.motivation: Open-vocabulary detectors excel on standard data but struggle with real-world out-of-distribution classes and require expensive re-training of large vision-language models. A lightweight, transferable search-based approach can yield real-time detectors with strong accuracy on target domains without heavy retraining.
AI.method: Fine-tune a pre-trained base network on the target dataset and perform weight-sharing NAS to explore thousands of network configurations with different accuracy-latency tradeoffs, without additional training. The method revisits tunable knobs to improve transferability of DETRs across diverse domains, producing Pareto-optimal models (nano to 2x-large).
AI.result: RF-DETR achieves state-of-the-art real-time performance on COCO and Roboflow100-VL among open-vocabulary / DETR-based methods. RF-DETR (nano) reaches 48.0 AP on COCO (5.3 AP higher than D-FINE nano at similar latency), and RF-DETR (2x-large) surpasses GroundingDINO (tiny) by 1.2 AP on Roboflow100-VL while running 20x faster. It is claimed to be the first real-time detector to exceed 60 AP on COCO.
AI.conclusion: A lightweight NAS-driven DETR framework can deliver robust open-vocabulary detection with favorable accuracy-latency tradeoffs across target domains, enabling practical real-time deployment without expensive model re-training; code is released.

title: GAMMA_FLOW: Guided Analysis of Multi-label spectra by MAtrix Factorization for Lightweight Operational Workflows
summary: GAMMA_FLOW is an open-source Python package for real-time analysis of spectral data. It supports classification, denoising, decomposition, and outlier detection of both single- and multi-component spectra. Instead of relying on large, computationally intensive models, it employs a supervised approach to non-negative matrix factorization (NMF) for dimensionality reduction. This ensures a fast, efficient, and adaptable analysis while reducing computational costs. gamma_flow achieves classification accuracies above 90% and enables reliable automated spectral interpretation. Originally developed for gamma-ray spectra, it is applicable to any type of one-dimensional spectral data. As an open and flexible alternative to proprietary software, it supports various applications in research and industry.

AI.tldr: GAMMA_FLOW is an open-source Python package for real-time spectral data analysis using supervised NMF, enabling fast classification, denoising, decomposition, and outlier detection for 1D spectra, achieving >90% accuracy; applicable beyond gamma-ray spectra.
AI.motivation: Provide fast, cost-efficient, adaptable spectral analysis without heavy deep models; enable real-time interpretation; replace proprietary tools; broaden applicability to researchers and industry dealing with 1D spectra.
AI.method: Employ supervised non-negative matrix factorization for dimensionality reduction and analysis; supports classification, denoising, decomposition, outlier detection for single- and multi-component spectra; real-time processing; open-source and flexible.
AI.result: Classification accuracies above 90%; reliable automated spectral interpretation; reduced computational costs; fast and adaptable analysis.
AI.conclusion: GAMMA_FLOW is a versatile, open, and efficient tool for 1D spectral analysis beyond gamma-ray data, suitable for diverse research and industry applications as an alternative to proprietary software.

title: Distribution-Based Feature Attribution for Explaining the Predictions of Any Classifier
comment: Accepted for an oral presentation at the 40th Annual AAAI Conference on Artificial Intelligence (AAAI-26). This document is the extended version which includes the appendix
summary: The proliferation of complex, black-box AI models has intensified the need for techniques that can explain their decisions. Feature attribution methods have become a popular solution for providing post-hoc explanations, yet the field has historically lacked a formal problem definition. This paper addresses this gap by introducing a formal definition for the problem of feature attribution, which stipulates that explanations be supported by an underlying probability distribution represented by the given dataset. Our analysis reveals that many existing model-agnostic methods fail to meet this criterion, while even those that do often possess other limitations. To overcome these challenges, we propose Distributional Feature Attribution eXplanations (DFAX), a novel, model-agnostic method for feature attribution. DFAX is the first feature attribution method to explain classifier predictions directly based on the data distribution. We show through extensive experiments that DFAX is more effective and efficient than state-of-the-art baselines.

AI.tldr: Proposes a formal problem definition for feature attribution grounded in the data distribution and introduces DFAX, a model-agnostic method that explains classifier predictions via distribution-based explanations, showing superior effectiveness and efficiency to baselines.
AI.motivation: To address the lack of a formal, distribution-consistent definition for feature attribution and to overcome limitations of existing methods by aligning explanations with the data-generating process.
AI.method: Define a distribution-informed attribution framework and present DFAX, a model-agnostic algorithm that explains predictions directly from the data distribution rather than surrogate proxies.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show DFAX is more effective and efficient than state-of-the-art baselines.
AI.conclusion: A distribution-based definition is essential for trustworthy explanations; DFAX demonstrates that exploiting the data distribution yields superior attribution performance.

title: Potent but Stealthy: Rethink Profile Pollution against Sequential Recommendation via Bi-level Constrained Reinforcement Paradigm
summary: Sequential Recommenders, which exploit dynamic user intents through interaction sequences, is vulnerable to adversarial attacks. While existing attacks primarily rely on data poisoning, they require large-scale user access or fake profiles thus lacking practicality. In this paper, we focus on the Profile Pollution Attack that subtly contaminates partial user interactions to induce targeted mispredictions. Previous PPA methods suffer from two limitations, i.e., i) over-reliance on sequence horizon impact restricts fine-grained perturbations on item transitions, and ii) holistic modifications cause detectable distribution shifts. To address these challenges, we propose a constrained reinforcement driven attack CREAT that synergizes a bi-level optimization framework with multi-reward reinforcement learning to balance adversarial efficacy and stealthiness. We first develop a Pattern Balanced Rewarding Policy, which integrates pattern inversion rewards to invert critical patterns and distribution consistency rewards to minimize detectable shifts via unbalanced co-optimal transport. Then we employ a Constrained Group Relative Reinforcement Learning paradigm, enabling step-wise perturbations through dynamic barrier constraints and group-shared experience replay, achieving targeted pollution with minimal detectability. Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of CREAT.

AI.tldr: CREAT is a constrained reinforcement learning based Profile Pollution Attack on sequential recommender systems that subtly perturbs partial user interactions to achieve targeted mispredictions while keeping perturbations stealthy. It overcomes two limitations of prior PPA methods—over-reliance on horizon-wide perturbations and detectable distribution shifts—via a Pattern Balanced Rewarding Policy and a Constrained Group Relative RL framework employing bi-level optimization, dynamic barrier constraints, and group-shared experience replay. Empirical results show strong attack effectiveness with low detectability.
AI.motivation: To enable practical, targeted attacks on sequential recommender systems by contaminating only parts of user interactions (partial profiles) without requiring large-scale fake profiles or extensive access, thereby increasing realism and stealth.
AI.method: Bi-level optimization with multi-reward reinforcement learning. Pattern Balanced Rewarding Policy combines pattern inversion rewards (to flip critical patterns) with distribution-consistency rewards (to minimize detectable shifts via unbalanced co-optimal transport). Constrained Group Relative Reinforcement Learning introduces step-wise perturbations through dynamic barrier constraints and group-shared experience replay to enable targeted pollution with minimal detectability.
AI.result: Extensive experiments demonstrate that CREAT achieves effective targeted pollution with low detectability, outperforming baselines across multiple settings.
AI.conclusion: CREAT offers a practical and stealthy PPA approach for sequential recommenders by integrating constrained RL techniques; it addresses core limitations of prior methods and suggests directions for defense and broader applicability.

title: From Decision Trees to Boolean Logic: A Fast and Unified SHAP Algorithm
summary:
SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP) is a key tool for interpreting decision tree ensembles by assigning contribution values to features. It is widely used in finance, advertising, medicine, and other domains. Two main approaches to SHAP calculation exist: Path-Dependent SHAP, which leverages the tree structure for efficiency, and Background SHAP, which uses a background dataset to estimate feature distributions.
  We introduce WOODELF, a SHAP algorithm that integrates decision trees, game theory, and Boolean logic into a unified framework. For each consumer, WOODELF constructs a pseudo-Boolean formula that captures their feature values, the structure of the decision tree ensemble, and the entire background dataset. It then leverages this representation to compute Background SHAP in linear time. WOODELF can also compute Path-Dependent SHAP, Shapley interaction values, Banzhaf values, and Banzhaf interaction values.
  WOODELF is designed to run efficiently on CPU and GPU hardware alike. Available via the WOODELF Python package, it is implemented using NumPy, SciPy, and CuPy without relying on custom C++ or CUDA code. This design enables fast performance and seamless integration into existing frameworks, supporting large-scale computation of SHAP and other game-theoretic values in practice.
  For example, on a dataset with 3,000,000 rows, 5,000,000 background samples, and 127 features, WOODELF computed all Background Shapley values in 162 seconds on CPU and 16 seconds on GPU - compared to 44 minutes required by the best method on any hardware platform, representing 16x and 165x speedups, respectively.

AI.tldr: WOODELF is a fast SHAP algorithm that unifies decision trees, game theory, and Boolean logic to compute Background SHAP in linear time, with added support for Path-Dependent SHAP, Shapley/Banzhaf values, on CPU and GPU using Python (NumPy/SciPy/CuPy).
AI.motivation: SHAP computation on large tree ensembles is computationally expensive, especially for Background SHAP with large background datasets. There is a need for scalable, framework-friendly methods that can run on commodity hardware.
AI.method: Constructs a pseudo-Boolean formula that encodes feature values, the tree ensemble structure, and the background dataset, enabling linear-time Background SHAP computation. It also supports Path-Dependent SHAP, Shapley interaction values, Banzhaf values and Banzhaf interactions. Implemented in Python using NumPy/SciPy/CuPy without custom C++/CUDA code, designed to run efficiently on CPU and GPU.
AI.result: Empirical demonstration on a dataset with 3,000,000 rows and 5,000,000 background samples across 127 features showed Background SHAP values computed in 162 seconds on CPU and 16 seconds on GPU, versus 44 minutes for the best prior method, yielding 16x and 165x speedups respectively.
AI.conclusion: WOODELF enables fast, scalable computation of SHAP and related game-theoretic values, with a Python-based, hardware-friendly implementation that integrates trees, game theory, and Boolean logic. It is available as a Python package and supports large-scale SHAP analyses.

title: Spatio-Temporal Graph Unlearning
summary: Spatio-temporal graphs are widely used in modeling complex dynamic processes such as traffic forecasting, molecular dynamics, and healthcare monitoring. Recently, stringent privacy regulations such as GDPR and CCPA have introduced significant new challenges for existing spatio-temporal graph models, requiring complete unlearning of unauthorized data. Since each node in a spatio-temporal graph diffuses information globally across both spatial and temporal dimensions, existing unlearning methods primarily designed for static graphs and localized data removal cannot efficiently erase a single node without incurring costs nearly equivalent to full model retraining. Therefore, an effective approach for complete spatio-temporal graph unlearning is a pressing need. To address this, we propose CallosumNet, a divide-and-conquer spatio-temporal graph unlearning framework inspired by the corpus callosum structure that facilitates communication between the brain's two hemispheres. CallosumNet incorporates two novel techniques: (1) Enhanced Subgraph Construction (ESC), which adaptively constructs multiple localized subgraphs based on several factors, including biologically-inspired virtual ganglions; and (2) Global Ganglion Bridging (GGB), which reconstructs global spatio-temporal dependencies from these localized subgraphs, effectively restoring the full graph representation. Empirical results on four diverse real-world datasets show that CallosumNet achieves complete unlearning with only 1%-2% relative MAE loss compared to the gold model, significantly outperforming state-of-the-art baselines. Ablation studies verify the effectiveness of both proposed techniques.

AI.tldr: CallosumNet offers a divide-and-conquer approach for complete unlearning in spatio-temporal graphs, using Enhanced Subgraph Construction (ESC) and Global Ganglion Bridging (GGB) to reconstruct global dependencies, achieving 1-2% MAE loss versus a gold model on four real-world datasets.
AI.motivation: Spatio-temporal graphs diffuse information globally across both space and time, making unauthorized data removal costly. There is a need for efficient, complete unlearning that matches or approximates retraining performance without costly entire-model retraining.
AI.method: A divide-and-conquer framework called CallosumNet. ESC adaptively constructs multiple localized subgraphs guided by biologically-inspired virtual ganglions. GGB reconstructs global spatio-temporal dependencies from these localized subgraphs to restore the full graph representation.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on four real-world datasets shows complete unlearning with only 1-2% relative MAE loss compared to the gold model, significantly outperforming state-of-the-art baselines. Ablation studies validate the contributions of ESC and GGB.
AI.conclusion: CallosumNet provides an effective, scalable solution for complete unlearning in spatio-temporal graphs, balancing privacy compliance with minimal performance degradation, and offering a practical path for privacy-preserving dynamic graph modeling.

title: Diffusion-based Sinogram Interpolation for Limited Angle PET
summary: Accurate PET imaging increasingly requires methods that support unconstrained detector layouts from walk-through designs to long-axial rings where gaps and open sides lead to severely undersampled sinograms. Instead of constraining the hardware to form complete cylinders, we propose treating the missing lines-of-responses as a learnable prior. Data-driven approaches, particularly generative models, offer a promising pathway to recover this missing information. In this work, we explore the use of conditional diffusion models to interpolate sparsely sampled sinograms, paving the way for novel, cost-efficient, and patient-friendly PET geometries in real clinical settings.

AI.tldr: Use conditional diffusion models to interpolate undersampled PET sinograms in non-traditional detector geometries.
AI.motivation: Undersampled sinograms due to walk-through or sparse geometries degrade image quality; learning a prior for missing lines-of-response enables cost-efficient, patient-friendly PET designs.
AI.method: Apply conditional diffusion models to interpolate missing sinogram data given sparsely measured lines-of-response, treating the absent data as a learnable prior within a data-driven framework.
AI.result: Feasibility study indicating that conditional diffusion models can interpolate sparsely sampled sinograms; specific quantitative results are not provided in the abstract.
AI.conclusion: Conditional diffusion-based interpolation enables exploring novel PET geometries by recovering missing LOR information, with potential cost and design benefits; further validation required.

title: LLM-Guided Dynamic-UMAP for Personalized Federated Graph Learning
summary: We propose a method that uses large language models to assist graph machine learning under personalization and privacy constraints. The approach combines data augmentation for sparse graphs, prompt and instruction tuning to adapt foundation models to graph tasks, and in-context learning to supply few-shot graph reasoning signals. These signals parameterize a Dynamic UMAP manifold of client-specific graph embeddings inside a Bayesian variational objective for personalized federated learning. The method supports node classification and link prediction in low-resource settings and aligns language model latent representations with graph structure via a cross-modal regularizer. We outline a convergence argument for the variational aggregation procedure, describe a differential privacy threat model based on a moments accountant, and present applications to knowledge graph completion, recommendation-style link prediction, and citation and product graphs. We also discuss evaluation considerations for benchmarking LLM-assisted graph machine learning.

AI.tldr: LLM-assisted personalized federated graph learning that uses data augmentation for sparse graphs, prompt/instruction tuning, and in-context learning to align foundation models with graph structure, via a Dynamic UMAP manifold inside a Bayesian variational objective for client-specific embeddings, enabling node classification and link prediction under privacy constraints.
AI.motivation: Address the need for personalized, privacy-preserving graph ML in low-resource settings by leveraging large language models to augment sparse graph data, supply reasoning signals, and bridge language and graph representations.
AI.method: Data augmentation for sparse graphs; prompt and instruction tuning to adapt foundation models to graph tasks; in-context learning to provide few-shot graph reasoning signals. These signals parameterize a Dynamic UMAP manifold of client-specific graph embeddings within a Bayesian variational objective for personalized federated learning. Also introduce a cross-modal regularizer aligning LM latent representations with graph structure; provide a convergence argument for the variational aggregation; propose a moments-accountant-based differential privacy threat model; discuss applications to knowledge graph completion, recommendation-style link prediction, and citation/product graphs.
AI.result: The paper presents a proposed framework with theoretical grounding (convergence of variational aggregation) and privacy considerations (moments accountant DP threat model), along with application scenarios. It outlines methodology and evaluation considerations but does not report empirical results within the abstract.
AI.conclusion: The work advances LLM-assisted graph ML under personalization and privacy constraints, offering a concrete framework that integrates data augmentation, prompting, in-context signals, and cross-modal regularization within a Bayesian federated learning setting, with broad potential applications and guidance for benchmarking.

title: Abstract Gradient Training: A Unified Certification Framework for Data Poisoning, Unlearning, and Differential Privacy
summary: The impact of inference-time data perturbation (e.g., adversarial attacks) has been extensively studied in machine learning, leading to well-established certification techniques for adversarial robustness. In contrast, certifying models against training data perturbations remains a relatively under-explored area. These perturbations can arise in three critical contexts: adversarial data poisoning, where an adversary manipulates training samples to corrupt model performance; machine unlearning, which requires certifying model behavior under the removal of specific training data; and differential privacy, where guarantees must be given with respect to substituting individual data points. This work introduces Abstract Gradient Training (AGT), a unified framework for certifying robustness of a given model and training procedure to training data perturbations, including bounded perturbations, the removal of data points, and the addition of new samples. By bounding the reachable set of parameters, i.e., establishing provable parameter-space bounds, AGT provides a formal approach to analyzing the behavior of models trained via first-order optimization methods.

AI.tldr: Abstract Gradient Training (AGT) unifies certification for training-data perturbations by bounding the parameter space of models trained with first-order methods, covering poisoning, data removal, and data addition.
AI.motivation: While inference-time robustness is well-studied, training-time perturbations (poisoning, unlearning, differential privacy) lack formal guarantees. A framework is needed to certify model behavior under changes to the training data.
AI.method: Introduce AGT, a framework that derives provable bounds on the reachable parameter set during training under bounded perturbations, data removal, and data augmentation/addition, for models trained with first-order optimization.
AI.result: AGT yields provable parameter-space bounds, providing a formal mechanism to analyze and certify robustness of training procedures against data perturbations.
AI.conclusion: AGT offers a unified, formal approach to training-data robustness, enabling certifiable guarantees for poisoning, unlearning, and differential privacy scenarios in first-order trained models.

title: How does the Performance of the Data-driven Traffic Flow Forecasting Models deteriorate with Increasing Forecasting Horizon? An Extensive Approach Considering Statistical, Machine Learning and Deep Learning Models
summary: With rapid urbanization in recent decades, traffic congestion has intensified due to increased movement of people and goods. As planning shifts from demand-based to supply-oriented strategies, Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS) have become essential for managing traffic within existing infrastructure. A core ITS function is traffic forecasting, enabling proactive measures like ramp metering, signal control, and dynamic routing through platforms such as Google Maps. This study assesses the performance of statistical, machine learning (ML), and deep learning (DL) models in forecasting traffic speed and flow using real-world data from California's Harbor Freeway, sourced from the Caltrans Performance Measurement System (PeMS). Each model was evaluated over 20 forecasting windows (up to 1 hour 40 minutes) using RMSE, MAE, and R-Square metrics. Results show ANFIS-GP performs best at early windows with RMSE of 0.038, MAE of 0.0276, and R-Square of 0.9983, while Bi-LSTM is more robust for medium-term prediction due to its capacity to model long-range temporal dependencies, achieving RMSE of 0.1863, MAE of 0.0833, and R-Square of 0.987 at a forecasting of 20. The degradation in model performance was quantified using logarithmic transformation, with slope values used to measure robustness. Among DL models, Bi-LSTM had the flattest slope (0.0454 RMSE, 0.0545 MAE for flow), whereas ANFIS-GP had 0.1058 for RMSE and 0.1037 for flow MAE. The study concludes by identifying hybrid models as a promising future direction.

AI.tldr: A comparative study evaluates statistical, ML, and DL models for traffic speed/flow forecasting on PeMS data; ANFIS-GP excels at short horizons, Bi-LSTM handles medium-term forecasts well, and robustness slopes favor DL; hybrid models are a promising future direction.
AI.motivation: Urban congestion from rapid urbanization motivates the use of ITS and traffic forecasting to enable proactive control (e.g., ramp metering, signal control). The paper assesses multiple modeling paradigms to identify strengths and robustness across forecasting horizons.
AI.method: Empirical evaluation on California’s Harbor Freeway PeMS data. Forecast windows up to 1 hour 40 minutes (20 steps). Models include statistical, ML, and DL (notably ANFIS-GP and Bi-LSTM). Metrics: RMSE, MAE, R-Squared. Robustness analyzed via logarithmic transformation with slope as a robustness measure.
AI.result: ANFIS-GP yields best early-window performance: RMSE 0.038, MAE 0.0276, R2 0.9983. Bi-LSTM offers stronger robustness and mid-term accuracy: RMSE 0.1863, MAE 0.0833, R2 0.987 at step 20. Robustness slopes: Bi-LSTM ~0.0454 RMSE, 0.0545 MAE for flow (flattest); ANFIS-GP ~0.1058 RMSE, 0.1037 MAE for flow. Overall, DL models show robustness advantages; hybrid models are highlighted as a promising future direction.
AI.conclusion: Hybrid models that combine strengths of statistical, ML, and DL approaches appear promising for traffic forecasting and deserve further exploration, especially for leveraging early- and mid-term horizon strengths.

title: AdaCuRL: Adaptive Curriculum Reinforcement Learning with Invalid Sample Mitigation and Historical Revisiting
summary: Reinforcement learning (RL) has demonstrated considerable potential for enhancing reasoning in large language models (LLMs). However, existing methods suffer from Gradient Starvation and Policy Degradation when training directly on samples with mixed difficulty. To mitigate this, prior approaches leverage Chain-of-Thought (CoT) data, but the construction of high-quality CoT annotations remains labor-intensive. Alternatively, curriculum learning strategies have been explored but frequently encounter challenges, such as difficulty mismatch, reliance on manual curriculum design, and catastrophic forgetting. To address these issues, we propose AdaCuRL, a Adaptive Curriculum Reinforcement Learning framework that integrates coarse-to-fine difficulty estimation with adaptive curriculum scheduling. This approach dynamically aligns data difficulty with model capability and incorporates a data revisitation mechanism to mitigate catastrophic forgetting. Furthermore, AdaCuRL employs adaptive reference and sparse KL strategies to prevent Policy Degradation. Extensive experiments across diverse reasoning benchmarks demonstrate that AdaCuRL consistently achieves significant performance improvements on both LLMs and MLLMs.

AI.tldr: AdaCuRL adaptively tunes curriculum in RL for LLM/MLLM reasoning by coarse-to-fine difficulty estimation, data revisitation, and adaptive KL, addressing gradient starvation and policy degradation to achieve strong improvements.
AI.motivation: RL for LLM reasoning suffers from training on mixed-difficulty data, causing gradient starvation and policy degradation; constructing high-quality Chain-of-Thought data is labor-intensive; existing curriculum methods struggle with difficulty mismatch and forgetting.
AI.method: Adaptive Curriculum Reinforcement Learning (AdaCuRL) that combines coarse-to-fine difficulty estimation with adaptive curriculum scheduling, a data revisitation mechanism to mitigate forgetting, and adaptive reference plus sparse KL constraints to prevent policy degradation.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on diverse reasoning benchmarks show AdaCuRL yields significant performance gains for both LLMs and MLLMs and outperforms baselines, demonstrating robustness across models and tasks.
AI.conclusion: AdaCuRL provides a general, scalable framework that tackles gradient starvation, policy degradation, and forgetting in RL-based reasoning, reducing reliance on manual CoT annotations and improving reasoning capability across model families.

title: Probing then Editing: A Push-Pull Framework for Retain-Free Machine Unlearning in Industrial IoT
summary: In dynamic Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) environments, models need the ability to selectively forget outdated or erroneous knowledge. However, existing methods typically rely on retain data to constrain model behavior, which increases computational and energy burdens and conflicts with industrial data silos and privacy compliance requirements. To address this, we propose a novel retain-free unlearning framework, referred to as Probing then Editing (PTE). PTE frames unlearning as a probe-edit process: first, it probes the decision boundary neighborhood of the model on the to-be-forgotten class via gradient ascent and generates corresponding editing instructions using the model's own predictions. Subsequently, a push-pull collaborative optimization is performed: the push branch actively dismantles the decision region of the target class using the editing instructions, while the pull branch applies masked knowledge distillation to anchor the model's knowledge on retained classes to their original states. Benefiting from this mechanism, PTE achieves efficient and balanced knowledge editing using only the to-be-forgotten data and the original model. Experimental results demonstrate that PTE achieves an excellent balance between unlearning effectiveness and model utility across multiple general and industrial benchmarks such as CWRU and SCUT-FD.

AI.tldr: Probing-then-Editing (PTE) provides a retain-free unlearning framework for IIoT models by probing the forgotten class boundary and editing the model to suppress it, achieving unlearning with minimal data while preserving performance.
AI.motivation: In dynamic IIoT, models must forget outdated or wrong information. Existing retain-data methods increase compute/energy needs and clash with data silos and privacy constraints. A retain-free approach is needed.
AI.method: PTE treats unlearning as a probe-edit process: probe the decision boundary neighbourhood of the to-be-forgotten class with gradient ascent; generate editing instructions from the model’s predictions; apply a push-pull optimization where the push dismantles the target region using the editing instructions, and the pull uses masked knowledge distillation to anchor retained classes to their original states using only the forgotten data and the original model.
AI.result: Empirically, PTE achieves a strong balance between unlearning effectiveness and model utility, working across general and industrial benchmarks (e.g., CWRU and SCUT-FD) using only the to-be-forgotten data and the original model.
AI.conclusion: PTE enables retain-free unlearning in dynamic IIoT, offering efficient, privacy-conscious model editing with preserved utility and applicability to industrial settings; it reduces reliance on retained data while maintaining performance.

title: Transformer Semantic Genetic Programming for d-dimensional Symbolic Regression Problems
summary: Transformer Semantic Genetic Programming (TSGP) is a semantic search approach that uses a pre-trained transformer model as a variation operator to generate offspring programs with controlled semantic similarity to a given parent. Unlike other semantic GP approaches that rely on fixed syntactic transformations, TSGP aims to learn diverse structural variations that lead to solutions with similar semantics. We find that a single transformer model trained on millions of programs is able to generalize across symbolic regression problems of varying dimension. Evaluated on 24 real-world and synthetic datasets, TSGP significantly outperforms standard GP, SLIM_GSGP, Deep Symbolic Regression, and Denoising Autoencoder GP, achieving an average rank of 1.58 across all benchmarks. Moreover, TSGP produces more compact solutions than SLIM_GSGP, despite its higher accuracy. In addition, the target semantic distance $\mathrm{SD}_t$ is able to control the step size in the semantic space: small values of $\mathrm{SD}_t$ enable consistent improvement in fitness but often lead to larger programs, while larger values promote faster convergence and compactness. Thus, $\mathrm{SD}_t$ provides an effective mechanism for balancing exploration and exploitation.

AI.tldr: A pre-trained Transformer acts as a semantic variation operator in genetic programming to generate semantically similar offspring, generalizing across problems and outperforming baselines on 24 datasets, with semantic distance SD_t controlling exploration/exploitation and solution compactness.
AI.motivation: Conventional semantic GP relies on fixed syntactic transformations, limiting diversity and scalability. Leveraging a large, pre-trained transformer as a learned variation operator can produce diverse, semantically similar offspring that generalize across problem dimensions while enabling better search efficiency and more compact solutions.
AI.method: Train a single Transformer on millions of programs to serve as a variation operator. Generate offspring with controlled semantic similarity to a parent using semantic distance SD_t. Evaluate on 24 real-world and synthetic symbolic-regression datasets, comparing against standard GP, SLIM_GSGP, Deep Symbolic Regression, and Denoising Autoencoder GP.
AI.result: TSGP significantly outperforms the baselines, achieving an average rank of 1.58 across benchmarks. It also yields more compact solutions than SLIM_GSGP despite higher accuracy. The target semantic distance SD_t effectively controls step size in semantic space: smaller SD_t yields steady improvement but larger programs, while larger SD_t accelerates convergence and promotes compactness, offering a mechanism to balance exploration and exploitation.
AI.conclusion: A transformer-based semantic GP can generalize across problem dimensions, improving accuracy and compactness while providing a tunable mechanism (SD_t) to manage exploration–exploitation in semantic space. This approach shows strong promise for scalable, high-quality symbolic regression.

title: Several Supporting Evidences for the Adaptive Feature Program
summary: Theoretically exploring the advantages of neural networks might be one of the most challenging problems in the AI era. An adaptive feature program has recently been proposed to analyze the feature learning characteristic property of neural networks in a more abstract way. Motivated by the celebrated Le Cam equivalence, we advocate the over-parametrized sequence models to further simplify the analysis of the training dynamics of adaptive feature program and present several supporting evidences for the adaptive feature program. More precisely, after having introduced the feature error measure (FEM) to characterize the quality of the learned feature, we show that the FEM is decreasing during the training process of several concrete adaptive feature models including linear regression, single/multiple index models, etc. We believe that this hints at the potential successes of the adaptive feature program.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces an adaptive feature program for analyzing neural network feature learning, defines a feature error measure (FEM), and shows FEM decreases during training in several over-parameterized models, supporting the program's promise.
AI.motivation: To understand why neural networks learn effective representations and to provide a principled, abstract framework; leveraging Le Cam equivalence and over-parameterized models to simplify training dynamics analysis.
AI.method: Define FEM, analyze its behavior in training dynamics; study linear regression, single/multiple index models; use adaptive feature program and Le Cam-inspired arguments.
AI.result: FEM is decreasing during training across models, suggesting that the learned features improve; provides supporting evidence for adaptive feature program.
AI.conclusion: Adaptive feature program is a promising direction for theory of neural networks; further work to generalize and validate across broader architectures.

title: Group Equivariance Meets Mechanistic Interpretability: Equivariant Sparse Autoencoders
comment: NeurIPS 2025 Mechanistic Interpretability and UniReps workshops
summary: Sparse autoencoders (SAEs) have proven useful in disentangling the opaque activations of neural networks, primarily large language models, into sets of interpretable features. However, adapting them to domains beyond language, such as scientific data with group symmetries, introduces challenges that can hinder their effectiveness. We show that incorporating such group symmetries into the SAEs yields features more useful in downstream tasks. More specifically, we train autoencoders on synthetic images and find that a single matrix can explain how their activations transform as the images are rotated. Building on this, we develop adaptively equivariant SAEs that can adapt to the base model's level of equivariance. These adaptive SAEs discover features that lead to superior probing performance compared to regular SAEs, demonstrating the value of incorporating symmetries in mechanistic interpretability tools.

AI.tldr: Adaptive, symmetry-aware sparse autoencoders improve mechanistic interpretability by leveraging group symmetries (e.g., rotations) in synthetic images, yielding better probing performance than standard SAEs.
AI.motivation: Current sparse autoencoders help interpret neural activations but struggle in domains with symmetries. Incorporating group symmetries can yield more interpretable, task-relevant features and better mechanistic insights.
AI.method: Train sparse autoencoders on synthetic images and show a single matrix explains how activations transform under rotations; develop adaptively equivariant SAEs that align with the base model's level of equivariance; compare probing performance against regular SAEs.
AI.result: Adaptive, equivariant SAEs discover features that lead to superior probing performance compared to regular SAEs, demonstrating the value of incorporating symmetries for mechanistic interpretability tools.
AI.conclusion: Incorporating group symmetries into SAEs enhances their usefulness for interpreting neural mechanisms, especially in symmetry-rich domains, and adaptive equivariant architectures can match the base model's equivariance to improve downstream tasks.

title: Enhancing Explainability in Solar Energetic Particle Event Prediction: A Global Feature Mapping Approach
comment: 10 pages, 3 Figures. This is a pre-print of an accepted paper at ICDMW: SABID 2025
summary: Solar energetic particle (SEP) events, as one of the most prominent manifestations of solar activity, can generate severe hazardous radiation when accelerated by solar flares or shock waves formed aside from coronal mass ejections (CMEs). However, most existing data-driven methods used for SEP predictions are operated as black-box models, making it challenging for solar physicists to interpret the results and understand the underlying physical causes of such events rather than just obtain a prediction. To address this challenge, we propose a novel framework that integrates global explanations and ad-hoc feature mapping to enhance model transparency and provide deeper insights into the decision-making process. We validate our approach using a dataset of 341 SEP events, including 244 significant (>=10 MeV) proton events exceeding the Space Weather Prediction Center S1 threshold, spanning solar cycles 22, 23, and 24. Furthermore, we present an explainability-focused case study of major SEP events, demonstrating how our method improves explainability and facilitates a more physics-informed understanding of SEP event prediction.

AI.tldr: A transparent, explainable SEP prediction framework combining global explanations and ad-hoc feature mapping, validated on 341 SEP events across solar cycles 22–24, with a case study illustrating physics-informed insights.
AI.motivation: Black-box SEP prediction models hinder interpretation; there is a need for transparent methods that reveal the physical drivers of SEP events and support solar physicists in understanding predictions.
AI.method: Integrates global explanation techniques with ad-hoc feature mapping. Applied to a dataset of 341 SEP events (including 244 significant >=10 MeV proton events meeting the S1 threshold) spanning solar cycles 22–24, plus an explainability-focused case study of major SEP events.
AI.result: The framework improves explainability and provides deeper, physics-informed insights into the decision-making process of SEP predictions; the case study demonstrates practical gains in interpretability.
AI.conclusion: The proposed approach enhances transparency in SEP prediction models, enabling solar scientists to better interpret results and connect predictions to underlying solar physics.

title: Latent Planning via Embedding Arithmetic: A Contrastive Approach to Strategic Reasoning
summary: Planning in high-dimensional decision spaces is increasingly being studied through the lens of learned representations. Rather than training policies or value heads, we investigate whether planning can be carried out directly in an evaluation-aligned embedding space. We introduce SOLIS, which learns such a space using supervised contrastive learning. In this representation, outcome similarity is captured by proximity, and a single global advantage vector orients the space from losing to winning regions. Candidate actions are then ranked according to their alignment with this direction, reducing planning to vector operations in latent space. We demonstrate this approach in chess, where SOLIS uses only a shallow search guided by the learned embedding to reach competitive strength under constrained conditions. More broadly, our results suggest that evaluation-aligned latent planning offers a lightweight alternative to traditional dynamics models or policy learning.

AI.tldr: SOLIS: planning in an evaluation-aligned latent space learned via supervised contrastive learning; planning reduces to vector operations in latent space, guided by a global advantage direction; demonstrated with a shallow search in chess.
AI.motivation: Reduce reliance on explicit dynamics models or policy optimization by performing planning directly in a representation aligned with evaluation (outcome similarity), enabling efficient reasoning in high-dimensional spaces.
AI.method: Learn an evaluation-aligned embedding where proximity encodes outcome similarity using supervised contrastive learning. A single global advantage vector orients the space from losing to winning. Candidate actions are ranked by their alignment with this direction, enabling planning via simple vector operations in latent space. Demonstrated with chess using a shallow search guided by the embedding.
AI.result: The approach achieves competitive strength under constrained search in chess, illustrating that evaluation-aligned latent planning can be a lightweight alternative to traditional dynamics models or policy learning.
AI.conclusion: Evaluation-aligned latent planning is a viable and efficient alternative for planning in high-dimensional spaces, with potential applicability beyond games and reduced reliance on explicit dynamics or policy networks.

title: PDAC: Efficient Coreset Selection for Continual Learning via Probability Density Awareness
summary: Rehearsal-based Continual Learning (CL) maintains a limited memory buffer to store replay samples for knowledge retention, making these approaches heavily reliant on the quality of the stored samples. Current Rehearsal-based CL methods typically construct the memory buffer by selecting a representative subset (referred to as coresets), aiming to approximate the training efficacy of the full dataset with minimal storage overhead. However, mainstream Coreset Selection (CS) methods generally formulate the CS problem as a bi-level optimization problem that relies on numerous inner and outer iterations to solve, leading to substantial computational cost thus limiting their practical efficiency. In this paper, we aim to provide a more efficient selection logic and scheme for coreset construction. To this end, we first analyze the Mean Squared Error (MSE) between the buffer-trained model and the Bayes-optimal model through the perspective of localized error decomposition to investigate the contribution of samples from different regions to MSE suppression. Further theoretical and experimental analyses demonstrate that samples with high probability density play a dominant role in error suppression. Inspired by this, we propose the Probability Density-Aware Coreset (PDAC) method. PDAC leverages the Projected Gaussian Mixture (PGM) model to estimate each sample's joint density, enabling efficient density-prioritized buffer selection. Finally, we introduce the streaming Expectation Maximization (EM) algorithm to enhance the adaptability of PGM parameters to streaming data, yielding Streaming PDAC (SPDAC) for streaming scenarios. Extensive comparative experiments show that our methods outperforms other baselines across various CL settings while ensuring favorable efficiency.

AI.tldr: PDAC/SPDAC propose density-aware coreset construction for rehearsal-based continual learning. By modeling sample joint density with a Projected Gaussian Mixture and prioritizing high-density samples, they achieve efficient, effective memory buffers; a streaming EM variant enables adaptation in streaming data, yielding superior performance with reduced computation compared to bi-level coreset optimization.
AI.motivation: To overcome the high computational cost and limited practicality of bi-level optimized coreset selection in rehearsal-based continual learning, by focusing on samples that most suppress error in density-rich regions of the input space.
AI.method: Introduce PDAC, which uses a Projected Gaussian Mixture (PGM) to estimate each sample's joint density and constructs the buffer by density-prioritized sampling. Develop a streaming EM algorithm to adapt PGM parameters online, forming SPDAC for streaming scenarios.
AI.result: Experiments show PDAC/SPDAC outperform baselines across diverse CL settings, with improved efficiency and robustness in streaming contexts.
AI.conclusion: Density-aware coreset selection guided by a PGM and updated via streaming EM yields more effective and scalable rehearsal-based continual learning, addressing both buffer quality and computational efficiency.

title: AutoSynth: Automated Workflow Optimization for High-Quality Synthetic Dataset Generation via Monte Carlo Tree Search
summary: Supervised fine-tuning (SFT) of large language models (LLMs) for specialized tasks requires high-quality datasets, but manual curation is prohibitively expensive. Synthetic data generation offers scalability, but its effectiveness relies on complex, multi-stage workflows, integrating prompt engineering and model orchestration. Existing automated workflow methods face a cold start problem: they require labeled datasets for reward modeling, which is especially problematic for subjective, open-ended tasks with no objective ground truth. We introduce AutoSynth, a framework that automates workflow discovery and optimization without reference datasets by reframing the problem as a Monte Carlo Tree Search guided by a novel dataset-free hybrid reward. This reward enables meta-learning through two LLM-as-judge components: one evaluates sample quality using dynamically generated task-specific metrics, and another assesses workflow code and prompt quality. Experiments on subjective educational tasks show that while expert-designed workflows achieve higher human preference rates (96-99% win rates vs. AutoSynth's 40-51%), models trained on AutoSynth-generated data dramatically outperform baselines (40-51% vs. 2-5%) and match or surpass expert workflows on certain metrics, suggesting discovery of quality dimensions beyond human intuition. These results are achieved while reducing human effort from 5-7 hours to just 30 minutes (>90% reduction). AutoSynth tackles the cold start issue in data-centric AI, offering a scalable, cost-effective method for subjective LLM tasks. Code: https://github.com/bisz9918-maker/AutoSynth.

AI.tldr: AutoSynth automates discovery and optimization of synthetic-data generation workflows for SFT without reference datasets, using Monte Carlo Tree Search guided by a dataset-free hybrid reward. It reduces human effort and yields data that improves model performance, though expert workflows still win in human preference evaluations.
AI.motivation: High-quality datasets are essential for supervised fine-tuning but manual curation is expensive. Synthetic data helps scalability but current automation requires labeled data for reward modeling, creating a cold-start problem for subjective tasks.
AI.method: Frame the workflow search as Monte Carlo Tree Search guided by a dataset-free hybrid reward composed of two LLM-based judges: (1) a sample-quality judge with dynamic task-specific metrics, and (2) a workflow/prompt-quality judge. The reward enables meta-learning without ground-truth labels across subjective tasks.
AI.result: In subjective educational tasks, expert-designed workflows have higher human preference (96-99% wins) than AutoSynth (40-51%), but models trained on AutoSynth data outperform baselines (40-51% vs 2-5%) and can match or exceed expert workflows on certain metrics. Human effort is reduced from 5-7 hours to ~30 minutes ( >90% reduction).
AI.conclusion: AutoSynth addresses the cold-start problem in data-centric AI for subjective LLM tasks, offering a scalable, cost-effective approach to synthesize training data without reference datasets. Code is available at the provided GitHub link.

title: Quasi-Newton Compatible Actor-Critic for Deterministic Policies
summary: In this paper, we propose a second-order deterministic actor-critic framework in reinforcement learning that extends the classical deterministic policy gradient method to exploit curvature information of the performance function. Building on the concept of compatible function approximation for the critic, we introduce a quadratic critic that simultaneously preserves the true policy gradient and an approximation of the performance Hessian. A least-squares temporal difference learning scheme is then developed to estimate the quadratic critic parameters efficiently. This construction enables a quasi-Newton actor update using information learned by the critic, yielding faster convergence compared to first-order methods. The proposed approach is general and applicable to any differentiable policy class. Numerical examples demonstrate that the method achieves improved convergence and performance over standard deterministic actor-critic baselines.

AI.tldr: A second-order deterministic actor-critic with a quadratic critic captures curvature information (Hessian) via compatibility, using least-squares TD to estimate critic parameters and a quasi-Newton actor update, yielding faster convergence than first-order baselines across differentiable policies.
AI.motivation: Deterministic policy gradient methods can suffer from slow convergence; incorporating curvature information through a quadratic critic and Hessian approximation aims to accelerate learning and improve sample efficiency while preserving correct policy gradient properties.
AI.method: Introduce a quadratic critic within the compatible function approximation framework to simultaneously estimate the policy gradient and an approximation to the performance Hessian. Use a least-squares TD learning scheme to efficiently estimate the quadratic critic parameters. Perform a quasi-Newton actor update that leverages the learned curvature information. The approach is general to any differentiable policy class.
AI.result: Numerical experiments demonstrate improved convergence speed and performance over standard deterministic actor-critic baselines.
AI.conclusion: The proposed curvature-aware deterministic actor-critic framework offers a general, faster-converging alternative to first-order methods by exploiting Hessian information through a quadratic critic, applicable to any differentiable policy class.

title: GenePheno: Interpretable Gene Knockout-Induced Phenotype Abnormality Prediction from Gene Sequences
summary: Exploring how genetic sequences shape phenotypes is a fundamental challenge in biology and a key step toward scalable, hypothesis-driven experimentation. The task is complicated by the large modality gap between sequences and phenotypes, as well as the pleiotropic nature of gene-phenotype relationships. Existing sequence-based efforts focus on the degree to which variants of specific genes alter a limited set of phenotypes, while general gene knockout induced phenotype abnormality prediction methods heavily rely on curated genetic information as inputs, which limits scalability and generalizability. As a result, the task of broadly predicting the presence of multiple phenotype abnormalities under gene knockout directly from gene sequences remains underexplored. We introduce GenePheno, the first interpretable multi-label prediction framework that predicts knockout induced phenotypic abnormalities from gene sequences. GenePheno employs a contrastive multi-label learning objective that captures inter-phenotype correlations, complemented by an exclusive regularization that enforces biological consistency. It further incorporates a gene function bottleneck layer, offering human interpretable concepts that reflect functional mechanisms behind phenotype formation. To support progress in this area, we curate four datasets with canonical gene sequences as input and multi-label phenotypic abnormalities induced by gene knockouts as targets. Across these datasets, GenePheno achieves state-of-the-art gene-centric Fmax and phenotype-centric AUC, and case studies demonstrate its ability to reveal gene functional mechanisms.

AI.tldr: Introduces GenePheno, an interpretable multi-label framework that predicts knockout-induced phenotypic abnormalities from gene sequences, using contrastive multi-label learning, exclusive regularization, and a gene function bottleneck; validated on four curated datasets with state-of-the-art performance and interpretable insights into gene mechanisms.
AI.motivation: Bridging the large modality gap between genetic sequences and phenotypes, addressing pleiotropy, and enabling scalable, sequence-based, broad phenotype prediction for gene knockouts without heavy reliance on curated additional data.
AI.method: GenePheno employs a contrastive multi-label learning objective to capture inter-phenotype correlations, an exclusive regularization term to enforce biological consistency, and a gene function bottleneck layer that yields human-interpretable functional concepts. The authors curate four gene-sequence-to-phenotype knockout datasets and evaluate using gene-centric Fmax and phenotype-centric AUC, with qualitative case studies.
AI.result: GenePheno achieves state-of-the-art performance on all four datasets in terms of gene-centric Fmax and phenotype-centric AUC, and case studies demonstrate its ability to reveal underlying gene functional mechanisms.
AI.conclusion: GenePheno provides a scalable, interpretable framework for predicting knockout-induced phenotypes directly from gene sequences, advancing understanding of genotype-phenotype mappings and guiding hypothesis-driven experiments.

title: Event-Driven Digital-Time-Domain Inference Architectures for Tsetlin Machines
summary: Machine learning fits model parameters to approximate input-output mappings, predicting unknown samples. However, these models often require extensive arithmetic computations during inference, increasing latency and power consumption. This paper proposes a digital-time-domain computing approach for Tsetlin machine (TM) inference process to address these challenges. This approach leverages a delay accumulation mechanism to mitigate the costly arithmetic sums of classes and employs a Winner-Takes-All scheme to replace conventional magnitude comparators. Specifically, a Hamming distance-driven time-domain scheme is implemented for multi-class TMs. Furthermore, differential delay paths, combined with a leading-ones-detector logarithmic delay compression digital-time-domain scheme, are utilised for the coalesced TMs, accommodating both binary-signed and exponential-scale delay accumulation issues. Compared to the functionally equivalent, post-implementation digital TM architecture baseline, the proposed architecture demonstrates orders-of-magnitude improvements in energy efficiency and throughput.

AI.tldr: Digital-time-domain (DTD) TM inference using delay accumulation and winner-takes-all to reduce arithmetic, achieving high energy efficiency and throughput.
AI.motivation: Conventional TM inference incurs heavy arithmetic during classification, leading to latency and power drawbacks. A hardware-oriented DTD approach aims to mitigate these costs.
AI.method: A Hamming distance-driven time-domain scheme for multi-class TMs; delay accumulation to perform sums; winner-takes-all to replace magnitude comparators; differential delay paths; leading-ones-detector logarithmic delay compression for coalesced TMs; supports binary-signed and exponential-scale delays.
AI.result: Compared with a functional-equivalent post-implementation digital TM baseline, the architecture shows orders-of-magnitude improvements in energy efficiency and throughput.
AI.conclusion: Digital-time-domain TM inference is viable and substantially improves energy efficiency and throughput, suggesting a promising direction for hardware-accelerated TM implementations.

title: SiDGen: Structure-informed Diffusion for Generative modeling of Ligands for Proteins
summary: Designing ligands that are both chemically valid and structurally compatible with protein binding pockets is a key bottleneck in computational drug discovery. Existing approaches either ignore structural context or rely on expensive, memory-intensive encoding that limits throughput and scalability. We present SiDGen (Structure-informed Diffusion Generator), a protein-conditioned diffusion framework that integrates masked SMILES generation with lightweight folding-derived features for pocket awareness. To balance expressivity with efficiency, SiDGen supports two conditioning pathways: a streamlined mode that pools coarse structural signals from protein embeddings and a full mode that injects localized pairwise biases for stronger coupling. A coarse-stride folding mechanism with nearest-neighbor upsampling alleviates the quadratic memory costs of pair tensors, enabling training on realistic sequence lengths. Learning stability is maintained through in-loop chemical validity checks and an invalidity penalty, while large-scale training efficiency is restored \textit{via} selective compilation, dataloader tuning, and gradient accumulation. In automated benchmarks, SiDGen generates ligands with high validity, uniqueness, and novelty, while achieving competitive performance in docking-based evaluations and maintaining reasonable molecular properties. These results demonstrate that SiDGen can deliver scalable, pocket-aware molecular design, providing a practical route to conditional generation for high-throughput drug discovery.

AI.tldr: SiDGen is a structure-aware diffusion model for protein-conditioned ligand generation. It balances expressivity and efficiency via two conditioning modes, uses lightweight folding-derived features to inform pocket binding, and employs memory-saving strategies to enable scalable training, achieving high chemical validity and competitive docking performance.
AI.motivation: The ligand design bottleneck in drug discovery is producing chemically valid molecules that fit protein pockets; existing methods either ignore structural context or are resource-intensive, limiting throughput. A scalable, pocket-aware generative approach could accelerate high-throughput ligand design.
AI.method: A protein-conditioned diffusion framework (SiDGen) integrates masked SMILES generation with folding-derived pocket features. Two conditioning pathways are provided: (1) a streamlined mode using coarse protein embeddings, and (2) a full mode injecting localized pairwise biases for stronger coupling. A coarse-stride folding mechanism with nearest-neighbor upsampling reduces memory from pair tensors. In-loop chemical validity checks and an invalidity penalty maintain learning stability. Training efficiency is enhanced via selective compilation, dataloader tuning, and gradient accumulation.
AI.result: In automated benchmarks, SiDGen generates ligands with high validity, uniqueness, and novelty, while delivering competitive docking-based performance and maintaining reasonable molecular properties. The approach demonstrates scalable, pocket-aware molecular design suitable for high-throughput conditional generation in drug discovery.
AI.conclusion: SiDGen offers a scalable, pocket-aware generative framework that combines structure-informed conditioning with efficient training strategies, enabling high-throughput, conditional ligand design without sacrificing chemical validity or docking-relevant performance.

title: NSL-MT: Linguistically Informed Negative Samples for Efficient Machine Translation in Low-Resource Languages
summary: We introduce Negative Space Learning MT (NSL-MT), a training method that teaches models what not to generate by encoding linguistic constraints as severity-weighted penalties in the loss function. NSL-MT increases limited parallel data with synthetically generated violations of target language grammar, explicitly penalizing the model when it assigns high probability to these linguistically invalid outputs. We demonstrate that NSL-MT delivers improvements across all architectures: 3-12\% BLEU gains for well-performing models and 56-89\% gains for models lacking descent initial support. Furthermore, NSL-MT provides a 5x data efficiency multiplier -- training with 1,000 examples matches or exceeds normal training with 5,000 examples. Thus, NSL-MT provides a data-efficient alternative training method for settings where there is limited annotated parallel corporas.

AI.tldr: NSL-MT uses severity-weighted penalties for linguistically invalid outputs to teach models what not to generate, enabling data-efficient MT with little parallel data and broad gains across architectures.
AI.motivation: Parallel MT data is scarce; need to leverage unannotated data and explicitly penalize invalid outputs to improve quality when data is limited.
AI.method: Incorporates linguistic constraints as severity-weighted penalties in the loss function and trains on synthetically generated grammar violations, penalizing high-probability invalid outputs. Demonstrates effectiveness across architectures and yields data-efficiency gains.
AI.result: BLEU gains of 3-12% for well-performing models; 56-89% gains for models with weak initial support; 5x data efficiency (1,000 examples with NSL-MT matches or exceeds 5,000 examples with standard training).
AI.conclusion: NSL-MT offers a data-efficient alternative training method for MT in low-resource parallel-corpora settings and is effective across architectures by penalizing invalid outputs during training.
